But not only that, the other items on the agenda are no less important: support for rural areas, agriculture, increasing the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises, promoting sustainable tourism, as well as strengthening macro-regional cooperation. On the cultural and educational front, we certainly support the objectives of increasing the mobility of students and researchers, promoting Europe's cultural heritage, and using sport as an instrument of social inclusion. As I am from the Veneto region and given the historical and cultural similarities between my region and Croatia, I will help as much as possible to ensure that the objectives are achieved, wishing the Presidency good work and thus confirming my support and maximum cooperation. Thanks to the President, Prime Minister Plenković.

name: Geert BOURGEOIS
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, on behalf of the Flemish delegation, I am focusing on three of your very important priorities.  One, choose a budget of the future, not a budget of the 20th century. So we are betting on innovation, on research and development, on digitisation. There's no way the world is waiting for us. Two, do protect the citizen. You rightly mention the rule of law, but you also bet on border security, accelerated, not wait until 2024. Secondly, a Brexit with as few barriers as possible and the closest possible cooperation with our British friends. Finally, agree with your perspective for the Western Balkans. I believe that the new mechanism that the Commission is working on can provide a good basis, with clusters, with a dynamic process, merits-based.  I wish you every success with your presidency.

name: Alexandra Lesley PHILLIPS
text: – Madam President, I saw Ms von der Leyen leaving her hotel this morning, complete with a three-car cavalcade and police escort, and I wonder if tomorrow whether you’d like to give me a lift. I mean, it doesn’t seem very environmental not to offer a colleague a lift to the same building.  Welcome, Prime Minister. The vision for the EU over the next six months is simply astonishing: more cash to prop up weaker economies; open borders with two more countries – Albania and North Macedonia; and an ambition to keep the UK shackled to EU rules. Why on earth would we want to do that? If those policies were not bonkers enough, you want Croatia to also join the failing single currency. You would be locking your country and your people inside an economic prison and only the ECB would have the keys to set you free. The euro is the EU’s poster—child for weak growth, high unemployment and stagnant wages. Don’t do it. Keep the kuna. As Brexit has shown, citizens want freedom, not being dictated to by a faceless superstate. The UK is leading the way out of this fanatical, democratically—bankrupt project – and I’m telling you, unless the EU can show the will to reform and repeal its Gordian knot of regulations and directives, many brave nations will follow.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Madam President. Welcome home, Andrej. That the youngest Member State of the Union holds this Presidency is an example of enlargement being the only way forward for the European Union. Ambiguous messages about enlargement must end. They confuse our friends and allies, reduce our credibility, and open the door for other powers with dark interests to take our place. The day Europe closes the door to the Balkans, the deconstruction of the European Union will begin. I liked the plan presented for the Conference on the Future of Europe. After the pain that Brexit is going to bring to us, it is true, we must point the finger at Europe's enemies, we must point the finger at the nationalists, the separatists and the separators. Nationalism is the enemy of peace. And yes, it is true, as Andrej has raised, we must defend the rule of law with all our might. We must respect the independence of judges and courts. We must attend to and respect the decisions of judges and courts. And this Parliament has to accept the decisions of judges and courts, and if it wants to acknowledge that it respects the rule of law it has to respond to the requests of judges and courts. I hope that under your Presidency Brexit will be the last time it happens; Brexit to be Europe's last divorce; Brexit to be the last victory of nationalism.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Dear Chairman, Dear Mr. President of the Croatian Government, first of all, it is a great pleasure in this hall to discuss the first Croatian Presidency of the Council of the European Union. I am extremely pleased that the Programme of the Croatian Presidency also includes islands because, for example, they have proven that they can be at the foreman of the European energy transition. I ask you how Croatia as a country with over 1000 islands plans to strengthen this process? One of the welcome priorities is the renewal of enlargement policy and the holding of a summit in Zagreb for which I have an obligation to write recommendations on behalf of the European Parliament. The recent refusal to open negotiations with North Macedonia and Albania has brought the topic back into focus of European institutions. Suggestion: I think it would be good to include the countries of the Western Balkans in the work of the Conference on the Future of Europe.  Croatia as the youngest member has the freshest experience of negotiating membership. We know well how complex this process is, especially in the case of blockades of member states. Paris has some positive developments to be made. I ask you, do such signals come from other members who share france's views?

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, Prime Minister, welcome back to your home, to the European Parliament. I would like to congratulate the Croatian Presidency on the ambitious agenda, in particular in the part on the Western Balkans. The new year also started ambitiously for Ms von der Leyen, who from Zagreb said she had the green light or should have the green light for the Republic of North Macedonia and the Republic of Albania.  However, that is why, because of this ambition, I want to recall the lessons of last year. And they are: the first and most important— we must not promise things that cannot be accomplished or cannot be accomplished. Secondly, today global realities are such that we can no longer afford to keep the western Balkan countries in Europe's backyard. They must be an integral part of the European Union.  Many important initiatives lie ahead in the coming weeks. The first is to prepare and present the new methodology for the accession of the countries of the region to the European Union. They need to be consulted here. Otherwise, we condemn the process of failure from the very beginning. The second thing Mr Pizzula is talking about is a conference on the future of Europe. Any country that acquires the status of candidate member of the European Union must have a role and a place in the conference on the future of Europe.

name: Maximilian KRAH
text: Madam President, Prime Minister, I would like to thank the President-in-The-European President- Twenty-eight years ago today, Croatia was recognised as an independent state by most EU countries, and now you are sitting here holding the Presidency. First of all, congratulations! I must admit, however, that I was a little disappointed when I read through your programme. You are talking about Turkey, which is a candidate country, you want to include Kosovo in the EU. I do not believe that your founding president and party founder, Franjo Tusman, would have supported such a policy, I cannot imagine that the majority of people in Croatia support such a policy. And I can only warn you against thinking here, as a first-class European, that you have to pursue a policy that is contrary to the interests of your people. Look at how many people are leaving Croatia, how young people are leaving your country. And if you then take Franjo Tusman and his book 'Croatia and the question of nationality in the present day', you will find better answers to Europe's challenges than what the Commission and this Parliament are doing. The European Union is currently the largest global economy with the lowest growth performance, it has the lowest investment power, but it wants to spend EUR 3 trillion on climate change, which is not necessarily a technology of the future, even if the majority sees it differently here. In this respect, the solution to the question of Europe is more likely to be found in Tusman than in Brussels. I hoped croatia would bring the spirit of the 1990s here, so that we are partners in regionalisation and a return to common sense. Large states, supranational entities do nothing – you know that better than most here as children of Yugoslavia.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, Prime Minister, in your Presidency's priority programme, you mentioned, among other things, the climate-neutral EU and the related implementation of the Energy Union in the transport, telecommunications and energy chapters. I would like to ask you to increase your attention when applying already set goals – which are complicated both technically and economically. I am concerned that, as soon as we have given the industry a signal with targets, it is already on the agenda to increase them.  I believe that, at the moment, we should focus our forces primarily on strengthening Horizon Europe. Such a large topic cannot be solved without adequate contribution of new scientific knowledge without disproportionately large economic costs. I believe that, thanks to the Croatian Presidency, we will be able to agree and increase funding for Horizon Europe. Prime Minister, I wish you every success in the Croatian Presidency.

name: Carles PUIGDEMONT I CASAMAJÓ
text: – Madam President, Prime Minister, it’s a pleasure to welcome the Croatian Presidency of the European Union, a state that gained its independence recently, but has shown it has been a reliable Member of the European Union. I thank Prime Minister Plenković for endorsing dialogue between Catalonia and Spain. Catalonia is today a European internal affair and will be present during the Croatian Presidency. Therefore, a political solution must be found, through dialogue and negotiation. The EU must advance to find a common democratic mechanism for self—determination. Repression cannot be an acceptable solution.  Now it’s time for European politicians to speak up and show to the world that it is the better way: that the right of self-determination is the best and the most democratic way to solve territorial conflicts, not only in Europe, but all around the world. (The speaker declined to take two blue-card questions from Luis Garicano and Dolors Montserrat)

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Madam President, I would like to welcome back Prime Minister Plenković to the European Parliament. It’s great to see Croatia leading the European Union for six months. You are now a model for the whole Western Balkans region. Under the leadership of Prime Minister Plenković, Croatia has reached economic stability. You aim to join the euro area in the foreseeable future and Croatia fulfils all the conditions for joining the Schengen area.  Croatia can be a model for the whole Western Balkans. We need two things. Firstly, we need other Western Balkan countries to deliver on reforms, and secondly, we, the European Union, need to respect our promises to the Western Balkans. We need to say loud and clear to Western Balkan countries, ‘you are part of Europe, you belong to the European Union, and we want to help you on your way to the European Union’. Any contribution that the Croatian Presidency can make in this direction will be of historic importance. Prime Minister Plenković, you know the European Parliament very well and you will have an opportunity to show this in the negotiations that we will have on the European budget, and the philosophy of the European Parliament for the budget negotiation is the following: we want to finance properly old priorities and new priorities. Old priorities have been priorities for decades because they are important, not because they are outdated, and we agree together that we need to do more on new priorities: border protection, combating climate change and protecting the environment.  So please stand with Parliament and tell your colleagues in the European Council that fresh priorities require fresh funding. Tell your colleagues in the European Council to put their money where their statements are, and please assure them that we are doing a lot to make sure that the EU budget is well spent. Thank you very much. Good luck for your Presidency.

name: Johan DANIELSSON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Thank you for the floor and thank you to the Prime Minister for presenting the presidency programme.  It is an important time ahead of us. This is where we set the direction for the next five years. For me as a Social Democrat, it is absolutely crucial that we focus on creating security for ordinary people. In this respect, the EU has an important role to play, not least in terms of health and safety at work.  Today we have a situation in which 4 000 Europeans lose their lives at work every year, a situation in which 80 000 Europeans die of cancer every year due to exposure in their work. These are, of course, basically completely sick figures, which is why I was pleased when the Council decided in December to call for a new health and safety strategy with a zero vision for both fatal accidents and work-related cancer.  So let us work together for the next six months to make this happen. Because, although there were not one priority you prioritised in your opening speech, I hope that the Croatian Presidency puts health and safety at work high on the agenda, not least ensuring that we have a new strategy on health and safety at work. Europe's workers expect us to deliver on this issue.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are tired. We are tired of the pointless chatter and false promises of this Europe: we have war on our doorstep in Libya, and Europe is sleeping. There are and will be waves of illegal immigrants ready to land in Italy in the coming months, and Europe is pretending nothing. We have Islamic terrorists and foreign powers threatening our security, and Europe is giving billions of euros to Turkey by the Islamic dictator Erdoğan. It looks like a science fiction film and instead it is all damn true, complete with applause for Merkel, Macron and also for you, President von der Leyen. What else needs to happen? What are you waiting for? Why are you sitting waiting for the boat called Europa to sink? Either you wake up or this Europe will end the Titanic.

name: Robert ROOS
text: Mr President, the European Union wants to phase out fossil fuels because it considers CO2 to be a problem. You can't do that with solar and wind power alone. Nuclear energy is then needed in the energy mix. In a Dutch newspaper on 9 January, Commissioner Timmermans said of nuclear energy that it is too expensive and unsustainable. That is nonsense, because wind turbines and solar panels in 20 years' time will produce a mountain of waste for which we have no solution.  France has a share of more than 70% nuclear energy. The kWh price there is almost half that of Germany, where €200 billion has now been invested in renewable energy. Wind turbines and solar farms demolish nature because of the space seizure, can not do without fossil backup and the integration on the electricity grid is very complex. Our investments must be economically sound and energy must be affordable in order to maintain competition with the United States and China, otherwise we will lose jobs.  I urge the Croatian Presidency to put nuclear energy on the agenda.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Madam President of the Commission, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his excellent work on this Congratulations on this ambitious programme for your first Croatian Presidency. I would like to point out that it is important that agriculture and agricultural policy also remain central to the programme, especially when it comes to the multiannual financial framework. We need vibrant, sustainable rural areas in Europe, and in order for us to have such spaces, we need farmers who work in the countryside and populate the countryside. And today farmers are often called upon, but it is often forgotten that we also need income on farms, which means that farms must also be economically fit. Because only if they are economically fit will people stay in rural areas, they will stay on the farms and they will also work on them. We also need a policy that looks more closely at family businesses, which does not look so much at the big investors, but supports those who really work outside and who really worked the land with their families. I think that with your Presidency, with the multiannual financial framework and with the decision on the common agricultural policy, you can shape the future here.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating the Prime Minister on the first presidency of his country since accession. It's going to be a crucial year. Several people have already said it, but we know that Brexit is fast approaching. I think we should not forget that Brexit could have happened because ordinary people did not feel supported.  We need to make great strides to achieve a sustainable, social and ambitious multiannual budget. Unfortunately, the negotiations are not yet running too smoothly. I therefore want to know from the Croatian Presidency how it will provide sufficient resources to implement the social pillar, also mentioned by the Prime Minister in his contribution. Especially now that the Presidency is committed to social sustainability, because no one should be left behind.  Europe must strive for social progress and I wish you every success in your new role.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Madam President, Prime Minister, Madam President of the Commission, first of all I would like to greet the Croatian Presidency and greet in particular Prime Minister Plenković, not only because Croatia is the most recent member, but because Prime Minister Plenković is one of the European politicians most committed to the European project I know, and therefore I am sure that this Presidency will take great steps in European integration. I would also like to welcome the openness to the Balkans, and in particular to support for reforms in the Balkan countries that want access to the Union. There is one thing that is certain: there will be no Europe and there is no Europe without the integration of the Balkan countries. I would also like to welcome the priority given to cohesion and the multiannual financial framework, and I would finally like to welcome the commitment at the Conference on the Future of Europe, because there were doubts about whether the Council really wanted to move forward with this conference. With the Croatian Presidency the Council will clearly support the Conference on the Future of Europe.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, a strong Europe in a world of challenges: it is with this motto that Croatia proposes to assume its first rotating presidency of the European Union. I wish this mission all the best.  A strong Europe must be a Europe capable of action and moving forward. A developing Europe is a Europe capable of moving forward with an ambitious multiannual funding programme to promote convergence and cohesion and strengthen the Union's own resources.  A Europe that connects is a Europe capable of recovering its citizens for the extraordinary project of peace, freedom, solidarity and democracy that it constitutes, promoting the alliances necessary to strengthen it.  A Europe that protects is a Europe that has justice and tolerance as references and leaves no one behind in a time of disruptive transitions.   An influential Europe is a Europe that asserts itself and prestigious, not only by what it shares as values but, above all, by what it does specifically and serves as inspiration for other peoples and for other territories. The Presidency has chosen its priorities well. Now it's time to make them happen.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Madam President, so, first of all welcome back Prime Minister, it is great to have you here again. At the beginning of your speech you have mentioned three topics. The first one is MFF, the second, Brexit and the last, enlargement. I consider these topics as being well chosen, as the most important as a matter of time urgency. First of all we need to create stability in European finances. Second we shouldn’t miss the opportunity to negotiate as good a deal with the UK as possible, and last, we should avoid the destabilisation of your region of the Balkans. But there is something even bigger. The President of the Commission, Ms von der Leyen, and has mentioned the energy of your Presidency. She also has mentioned, together with Manfred Weber, your experience. And I guess all this is needed to do something even bigger than the files: to build a sense of cooperation, to build an agreement and make our unity of the European Union stronger. I wish you all the best in this.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: – Honourable Chair. Dear Prime Minister, you have a challenging and responsible task ahead of you, so I welcome your ambitions and support the agenda. However, we urgently need to restore confidence in the rule of law, prevent corruption and tax evasion, ensure their people's safety and quality of life, free ourselves from prejudice and hate speech, and regulate migration.  The future will also depend on the Schengen area. It is in our interest, of course, for Croatia to enter Schengen as soon as possible, but it is right here that you have a difficult task: to restore confidence in the rule of law and to respect the commitments made, to ensure secure external borders and to regulate Schengen so that it will work again. I expect your active support for the entry of the Western Balkan countries into the European Union and the positive developments already in March when it comes to the issue of North Macedonia and Albania. Our countries, Croatia and Slovenia, also simply need to do much more. Dear President. We can do it if we choose to do so, of course, and good luck.

name: Andrius KUBILIUS
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to the Prime Minister that, coming from Lithuania, it is a special pleasure to congratulate him and also the people of Croatia on their first Presidency. Your Presidency is also very important because of its very high symbolic value. Just 25 years after the War of Independence ended, Croatia is leading the whole European Union. Croatia is a most convincing example of the European miracle and power to bring stability and prosperity into its neighbourhood through enlargement. The Commission President was absolutely right in saying that the EU promise of enlargement is a most powerful incentive for countries to reform themselves. The Croatian example and the Croatian Presidency is a great inspiration to their neighbours in the Western Balkan region. The success of the Western Balkans’ integration is also a great inspiration for the Eastern Partnership region. I hope that the Eastern Partnership Summit, during the Croatian Presidency, will also be ambitious in delivering an inspiring regional strategy for the next ten years. Good luck, Mr Prime Minister.

name: Aurore LALUCQ
text: Madam President, Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, our economic model is now out of breath. While it has lifted billions of people out of poverty, it is also at the root of the dramatic environmental situation we find ourselves in today, when it is no longer able to significantly improve the social situation on our continent. Yet, despite this observation, we are struggling to change our economic model, we are struggling to get rid of the obsession with GDP or the level of public debt, as if we had an irrational attachment to these indicators, when, rationally, they cannot tell us anything about the state of inequality, the state of the environment or the state of poverty. Since you have chosen to make your presidency the one of a strong Europe that faces these challenges, the biggest challenge you face is to change our indicators of wealth in order to reorient our public policies. In other words, change the intellectual software of the European Union. We wish you the best of luck and we count on you.

name: Romana TOMC
text: – Honourable Chair. Dear Prime Minister, Mr Plenkovic, dear Andrei. I have experience of the Presidency and I know what it is like when a new Member State gets the Presidency, so of course I wish you well along the way.  I would like to highlight a Developing Europe among your priorities. Balanced development is important, cohesion funds are important, not only for those countries that get these funds, but for all members. If all Member States strengthen their competitiveness, we will, of course, be stronger as the Union. However, I would also like to touch on the demographics and its challenges, which are more important and stronger in the eastern part of our European Union at the moment. I therefore want more emphasis on the problem of tackling the elderly population in relation, of course, to the weak birth rate and in relation to the departure of young people abroad. Given that this area is run by your Commissioner, Mrs Dubravka Šuica, I am sure that you will be very active here. Happy.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: – Madam President, a strong Europe in the world of vision: I think that this is indeed a very good slogan of your Presidency, because Europe has its strengths and must learn to use them in the most effective way. He must learn to use his economic power. Indeed, it must also learn to use its attractiveness, which is documented by the interest of the candidate countries in joining the European Union, but it must also learn to speak louder, with one or more voices. I think that of your challenges, such as setting ceilings for policy-specific budgets, this challenge is probably one of the strongest, and we must ensure, and you in particular, must ensure that the interests of those who want to pay less are reconciled, because they are net payers, the interests of the European Parliament, which wants to increase the budget, and, at the same time, the interests of those who depend on cohesion funds. , i.e. countries such as Croatia or my country – Slovakia.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Madam President, dear fellow Prime Minister of Croatia, I would really like to wish you all the best. I am convinced, knowing your skills and capabilities, that you can strengthen the European Union and create a more upgraded image for European citizens. To make this possible, however, a strong economy is needed and a strong multiannual financial framework is needed, with an increase in the contribution of the Member States. Strong defense and security are required. I agree with you that there cannot be a European Union without securing our borders and without strict adherence to principles and values. But the European Union cannot be an observer either in Libya or Syria, and it cannot let countries like Turkey, in fact, create destabilisation in the region but also threaten European Union member countries such as Cyprus and Greece. I fully agree with the dear President of the European Commission that, where there is unity, there is real freedom. I would add that, where there is solidarity, there is unity, there is freedom. At the moment, Madam President, two Member States of the European Union — Cyprus and Greece — are calling for your solidarity with a terrorist country, such as Turkey, which is creating instability in the region.

name: Alessandra MORETTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Plenković, Mr von der Leyen, the world around us is ravaged by wars and tensions, and Europe often seems motionless and irrelevant on the international stage. There is a lack of courage to make clear and decisive choices, but I am convinced that having a female President like Ursula von der Leyen can contribute to an important change of pace. Firstly, two choices, in my opinion, are decisive: as far as the multiannual financial framework is concerned, it must be adapted to the challenges and the Finnish Presidency's proposal is far below what is necessary and would not allow the European Union's work programme, for which it obtained our vote in favour, to be implemented. Parliament will not be able to give its consent to the multiannual financial framework without a parallel agreement on the reform of the Union's own resources system. The New Green Deal must lead to a revolution not only ecological, but also social and economic, a great development plan that creates sustainable growth without leaving anyone behind. But I ask the Croatian Presidency to insist on the need to ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Sunčana GLAVAK
text: – Dear Chairman, Respected Mr. President of the Croatian Government, Croatia has shown throughout history that it is not afraid of challenges and the Presidency of Croatia is an opportunity to show responsibility, primarily for its actions towards citizens.  Therefore, we want a Europe that is evolving with a clear message that both smaller and larger, both rich and poor must have equal opportunities. I am sure that Croatia will be a strong advocate in the fair distribution of budgetary resources in the adoption of the multiannual financial framework, but also importantly, restore citizens' trust in the old continent, a Europe that must be a corrective and a force for new challenges.  For all those who express doubts about my homeland and do not know it at all, do not know the opportunities in it, do not know how successful Croatia is economically successful, strong message: If you are wondering if we are ready for these challenges, are we ready for them? I'm telling you, Croatia will show that we are!

name: Enikő GYŐRI
text: - Madam President, Prime Minister, I would like to thank you for your support. I have every confidence that the Croatian Presidency will steer the debate on the rule of law, which has been going on for years, in a sober direction. I hope that they will put an end to double standards and the singleing of some Member States. Please do everything possible to ensure that this value can no longer be debthret, i.e. that the rule of law cannot be the subject of political games. I also call for all Member States to be measured equally when examining how fundamental rights and freedoms are applied in certain corners of the Union. Put an end to the fact that some people have to account for all their domestic political events, which are not otherwise related to EU policy or are not competences, to account to the EU institutions or to each other. Have the wisdom not to want to play an arbi finalist. Moreover, today we are at the point where we are often the loudest supporters and most committed to the rule of law ... (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the Polish Prime Minister, I apologise, to the Croatian Prime Minister for presenting to us here in his priorities the adoption of the Multiannual Financial Framework. And I have been very pleased to hear this statement, just as I have heard with great satisfaction the importance of maintaining the value of cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy in the Multiannual Financial Framework.  We have on the table a proposal from the European Commission, a proposal that the European Commission has reinforced by saying that 7.5 billion fresh money will be allocated to the Just Energy Transition Fund. But we also have the Nego Boxes presented by the Finnish Presidency. So my question to the Prime Minister is exactly what his... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker)

name: Irena JOVEVA
text: – Honourable Chair. Mr Plenkovic, thank you for presenting the priorities of the Croatian Presidency. You take it over in really a lot of times in a period of big change, where they will be, you want to want to, some themes just at the forefront. Brexit, the budget, the future of Europe, environmental legislation, other topics you have set yourself, among which I particularly welcome addressing the problems of demographic change, the enlargement of the Union to the Western Balkans region and also respect for the union's main values, such as the rule of law. Your country, Croatia, and my country, Slovenia, are neighbours, so I believe that we will cooperate well in this spirit, but also because, Mr Plenkovic, I count on you not only to stay in words, that you will therefore truly implement respect for the rule of law and that you will also respect the human rights and rights of all, including migrants, in general. Happy.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, the Prime Minister mentioned a priority being securing Europe’s borders, but I have to question how Croatia can lead the European Union in areas of best practice in terms of human rights compliance in relation to migration and asylum when there are so many issues to be addressed regarding the documented violation by Croatian security forces of vulnerable migrants and the illegal push—backs at the Bosnia-Herzegovina borders. These are clearly a flagrant disregard of European Union asylum law, the Charter of Fundamental Rights, the Refugee Convention. It was highlighted obviously in the disgraceful arrest of two Nigerian athletes in Zagreb. You know, the most concerning part for me is that when we raise these issues at the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE Committee), the European Commission said that EUR 6 million of taxpayers’ funds were used for a monitoring mechanism in this area, to the UNHCR and the Croatian Law Society. It turned out these organisations ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Honourable Chair. Andrej Plenkovic, former colleague, hello, good to see you again in the European Parliament.  Allow me to start by immediately congratulating Croatia on taking over the Presidency and expressing my desire for great success in the next six months.  There are a whole range of challenges ahead of Europe, and I would particularly like to focus on the Multiannual Financial Framework. As a new member, I want a country that knows exactly what agricultural funds mean, what cohesion funds mean, that a great deal of emphasis is also placed on the fact that we can continue to do so through policies to ensure the steady development of Europe, which is stopping internal migration in the European Union. I am also working on a smart village project that we want to develop and link to digitisation, environmental challenges, economic challenges and enable people to work where they were born. I wish for every success, and I volunteer to work with you.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, Prime Minister Plenkovia is indeed the first time that Croatia has held the six-monthly presidency of the European Union, and we welcome you with the best wishes. But at the same time, we stress that it is an opportunity, which it cannot waste, to make a difference from the bad forecasts that the Multiannual Financial Framework announces with regard to regional and cohesion policy, which must not fail to be an absolute priority, compatible with the Green Deal.  And I also stress the importance it has in the context of Brexit, which will be consummated under his Presidency — the first to coincide with a fully effective Commission since its investiture — which secures the rights of citizenship, with reciprocity, and regains the importance that the area of freedom, justice and security deserves. Because it is true that the UK opt-out with respect to many policies. But it is essential to define in the future agreement what the UK's role in cooperation, security, data protection — because there have been bankruptcies in the principle of data protection retention by the United Kingdom, transferring it to third countries — at the same time as in Schengen, restoring the principle that , certainly none of the recently accession countries, including their own, have the full right to be part of the free movement of persons.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: President of the Commission. – Mr President, I want to refer to the three topics that have been raised the most here. The first one is our budget and the MFF, the second one is Brexit and the third one is the Western Balkans. First of all, where the budget is concerned, I think, dear Prime Minister, it is very important that Croatia and the Presidency convinces the Council to stick to its own strategic agenda, because – and I’m emphasising this – we need the modernisation of the budget, why this? The budget we have right now was agreed in 2013. You remember the year 2013 because it was the year when Croatia joined the European Union. The world was completely different. In the year 2013, we did not have any idea of Daesh. It existed already but we didn’t know anything of it. There hadn’t been the migration crisis yet. Russia had not annexed Crimea and had not yet started the hybrid war in the Ukraine. At that time, we had no Paris climate agreement. We were not speaking of 5G or artificial intelligence. These few highlights show that the world is completely different and that we do need a completely different budget – that means modernisation. One message from my part, and I think I have the support of the Parliament on this: if the overall ceiling is too low, if the budget in itself is too small, the only way out is our own new resources at European level. (Applause) There is an opportunity to introduce that with an emission trading system. The revenues of the emission trading system will grow, so we will not take anything away from the Member States. On the contrary, they’ll have more. But we can also allocate at European level the revenues from the emission trading system to serve the European Green Deal. The second topic is Brexit. Your Presidency comes at a crucial time for the Brexit negotiations because we have to make enormous progress. This is decisive until the summer, until the end of your Presidency, and here we have to decide on – or it’s the UK’s choice to decide on – how close or how distant they want to be from the European Union, but that also means from the single market. In other terms, you cannot have no free movement for people and then expect to have free movement for goods, capital and services. It’s either all four have free movement or none of this is possible. You cannot accept to have a level playing field if there’s a huge divergence in taxation or social standards or environmental standards. So it is the choice of the UK how far they want to align or diverge, but this is decisive for how good access to the single market will be or not. In short, it’s the old proverb: you cannot have your cake and eat it at the same time. And the very last point, the Western Balkans. Ich glaube, beim Thema des Westbalkans dürfen wir eines nicht unterschätzen: Es ist in unserem strategischen Interesse, dass der Westbalkan so nah wie möglich bei uns ist. Wir sollten nicht unterschätzen, wie stark China bereits präsent ist, wie stark Russland dort präsent ist, wie stark die Türkei dort präsent ist – alle mit der Intention, den Westbalkan und die Staaten des Westbalkans so stark wie irgendwie möglich auf ihre Seite zu ziehen. Es ist in unserem Interesse, sie so nah wie möglich an uns heranzuführen, und deshalb mit dem Blick auf Nordmazedonien und Albanien: Wir haben viel von ihnen verlangt. Nordmazedonien musste seinen Namen wechseln, um die Möglichkeit zu haben, die Beitrittsgespräche mit der Europäischen Union zu eröffnen. Und ich glaube, wir können es schaffen, einerseits den Beitrittsprozess zu modernisieren, aber andererseits auch treu im Wort zu bleiben zu dem, was wir Nordmazedonien und Albanien gesagt haben. Es ist in unserem Interesse, und in diesem Sinne wünsche ich Ihnen alles Gute für den Vorsitz.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, first of all thank you for the many reactions, many suggestions, many different points of view on the current priorities of the Croatian Presidency, but also on some ideas how you believe we should tackle the most important political and legislative dossiers which are on the agenda. Let me say a few points at the end in order to try to collectively touch on some of the matters that you have raised.  First of all, what is the philosophy of our first ever Presidency of the Council? We are a bit of a symbol and a signal, as I said at the beginning. Only 30 years of democracy, 28 years of international recognition, seventh year of membership. Still catching up with those who are more developed; those who were in the Union from the start, or those who joined, like our neighbours from Central and Eastern Europe, in 2004 and 2007. One of the MEPs, Mr Krach, I think, mentioned the first Croatian President Tuđman, and tried to interpret his doctrine. I dare to say that I might know a little bit better what is the legacy of the first Croatian President, and what he wanted for Croatia once we gained our sovereignty for the future and the perspective. It was actually he, 30 years ago on 30 May in the first democratically—composed Croatian Parliament, who said that European integration is the way to go, and everything we have done in the last three decades has been the implementation of this objective. We know what sovereignty means. We know what it means unlike any other country which is present in this hemicycle. What it means to have occupied territory. What it means to have a war on your territory. What it means to have more than 16 000 people killed in your own country, almost at the end of the 20th Century.  That experience remains vivid and we know that Europe is a project of peace and cooperation and reconciliation. That’s how we address our political responsibility today. This is very important to know.  Second, we have taken into account the strategic agenda, the trio programme, the programme of the new Commission and our own programme. Everything that we have put as priorities is very realistic. Therefore, on some of the items, we know that climate change and the climate neutral objective until 2015 will be the driver of our economic transformation. It will become for our economy what embedded human rights are for our foreign policy. This is what we agreed with the Commission in Zagreb last week. We should help to address this issue so as to take into account the different state of play of our industries, our financial capability, our budgetary capabilities, in order to go in the same direction but not to have negative economic consequences.  Secondly, on the dossier of migration, which many of you have mentioned, I will say once again – and repeat this with full understanding – that this is crucially what we must do in the months ahead of us.  We had the arrangement with Turkey that has managed to put down the numbers of illegal migration on the Eastern Mediterranean and Western Balkans route, compared to 2015-2016 data, by 98% – 98% down. These are the numbers we have now compared to 5 years ago, to only 2%. How should we tackle this? Jointly. We speak about a Frontex of ten thousand border police. My country proportionally perhaps has more border police than any other – 6 500. I hear some statements and allegations, which in the reports you read, or the rumours you hear, are almost to become effect. They are not. Whenever there was an allegation, there was an investigation. There were some disciplinary measures. There is strong surveillance within our police to prevent any violation of human rights, or any behaviour which would contravene our own law, European standards or international conventions. This is how we should behave.  But I repeat, once again, unlike many other Member States, we have said no barbed wire between two friendly, neighbouring countries such as Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina, and we will not erect fences between nations which are friendly, which will always be together as we were together in the past. Moreover we said clearly we will not erect fences between parts of the Bosnian Herzegovina border where Croats live as constituent people in Bosnia and Herzegovina and Croats on the other side of the border. This will simply not happen. This is our policy and we will stay behind it. But what we want to do is jointly address the problem either at the source, or at the first point of entry. The Croatian—Bosnian Herzegovina border is not the first point of entry of migratory waves. Let’s be very clear about it. This is important to note.  On the budget, the stakes are high. We understood the message ‘we can’t do more with less finance available’. That’s very clear. But we need to find a common consensus if we are to embark on the new own resources. By many analysis, by many reports by very able people in a number of years behind us, this might seem the only way to address, as Ursula says, the modernisation expectations of what we can finance jointly – this is key.  On demography, if there is one political element which I would like to leave as a legacy of Croatia in this six months – and also together with the Commission, given that Dubrovka has this portfolio for first time ever in the history of the European Union – it is this, which we feel to be an existential question for the European Union. For almost half of our Member States who have negative natural growth, such as my country, I think there is a need for a set of tools with the great sensitiveness of the President of the Commission who knows in her previous roles how important this issue is, how we can combine policy measures which have proved to be efficient in other countries, how we can offer them to those that have difficulty.  This is the idea – the population is moving from less developed countries to more developed, from rural areas to urban areas. These are our common problems and we should address them jointly. On the Western Balkans and the issue of enlargement, we are not naive. We are not unrealistic. I know more perhaps than anybody, since I’ve been dealing with this issue for almost 30 years, that the level of enthusiasm that the West with open hands offered to the Central and Eastern European countries in the 90s will never happen again, to those who would like to join.  But what we need to do, is intelligently to structure the process for the next ten years. To steer this process, to pilot it. To give an ambitious agenda for those who want to reform, transform and attain the standards that we have in the European Union. This is the idea behind the summit that we want to organise in Zagreb, and therefore I say for those who are afraid of saying ‘yes’ to the opening of the intergovernmental conference with Albania and North Macedonia, we know it’s a complex legal process with so many possibilities to either suspend or to reverse or to ask more or to build another requirement of this exercise. It is just a start of a marathon. It’s not a senseless fuite en avant.  We have to be clear about it. Enlargement doesn’t happen overnight, it happens after years of long reform process and careful scrutiny by the Commission and the input of the Member States.  In that respect I don’t want any of the countries in our neighbourhood to be forgotten, especially Bosnia-Herzegovina which is strategic for my country. I will also mention Ukraine, because you mentioned it Ursula now. I think in the context of the Eastern Partnership and everything we dealt with from 2013 and 2014 until now, we should adequately address their own ambitions for territorial integrity, but also for reforms in the European perspective which we should support. One word on Brexit. I see that Michel is here and this topic is just after our debate. I think the most important element in the last three and a half years, was the unity of the 27. We remain united with full solidarity extended especially to the most concerned countries such as Ireland. In the 11 months ahead of us, with an intelligently drafted and crafted negotiated framework, I think we can attain a good agreement as a starting point for future relations. We should not pretend that in an unprecedented situation we can solve with the first contractual relations everything we’d like to do in the future, after the divorce that is happening literally in three weeks’ time. Therefore we will help you, as the Council, on the proposal of the Commission, to find the right balance for completion in the months to come.  Finally, I just want to reiterate that all of our services, all of our ministers, government, MEPs who are here – and I thank them for their contributions – will be at your disposal to have a good dialogue together and to reach compromises.  This is one of the objectives of European democracy. This is the role of the European Parliament. This is the role of the Member States within the Council and also the facilitating and leadership role that the European Commission has. I thank you very much, Mr President, for this opportunity and for having been with you here today in Strasbourg. As many of you have said, my friends, this Parliament is a very dear institution to me.  (Loud applause)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thanks to Prime Minister Plenković. I wish your entire government team well in its work and good wishes for this very important period for the European Union. The debate is closed.  Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – I would like to congratulate Croatia on its first Presidency and wish that the coming semester would be successful and productive. It's going to be a stressful and quite difficult time. The forthcoming Brexit and, of course, the most important challenge ahead is the multiannual financial perspective. Croatia, like Lithuania in 2013 and my country, is taking on the presidency with the great challenge of finding an agreement on the next multiannual financial perspective. There are few times and the positions are very different, so it will be necessary to continue constructive negotiations with the Member States in order to agree on a socially responsible budget in the common European interest and solidarity, which is capable of responding to the ever-increasing challenges. Social Europe and people must become a budgetary priority. I would like to remind you that today, working people are increasingly at risk of poverty, not to mention over 20 million children living in poverty. Sufficient funding will be needed for new and very important initiatives, such as the European Guarantee for the Child, the Youth Guarantee, so that we can make a real contribution to poverty reduction and enable young people to work and earn. I very much hope that during the Croatian Presidency we will be able to agree on an ambitious and socially responsible budget.

name: Jarosław DUDA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I am very pleased that the Croatian Presidency has paid a great deal of attention to social issues. I would like the Presidency to take into account actions to improve the situation of persons with disabilities when addressing key issues such as poverty eradication, increasing access to the labour market and building high-quality, inclusive education systems. This more than 100 million citizens face barriers to access to education and employment, mobility and an independent, active life on a daily basis. Preparing teachers and trainers to support the full development of children and young people with disabilities is crucial for their future social and professional life, and I therefore hope that this issue will be taken into account in the Council conclusions on teachers and trainers for the future of Europe.  I also welcome the Presidency's declaration on demographic challenges. Europe's growing older population requires a multidimensional strategy that includes both promoting professional and social activity, mobility, good health, access to services and healthcare, and combating all forms of age discrimination. I am also convinced that the Croatian Presidency will be an advocate of a strong, ambitious cohesion policy for the years to come. I also hope that the Determination of the Presidency will send a positive signal on the future integration of the Western Balkan countries into the European Union.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. – I would like to wish Croatia success for the ambitious programme for the 6 months of the Presidency. Let me add a few points! I was surprised that you didn't talk about Schengen. Specifically, what will you do? Will you support Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia entering the Schengen area, given that they meet all the technical conditions? You talked about a development of the single market, but you didn't talk about the economic crime that is eating it up and making it poor. What will you do to eliminate crime networks? You are talking about a strong Europe, but this cannot be achieved if it is not all strong states. What will you do to eliminate the double treatment of the Member States? What will you do with the mobility package in the Council, which will exclude Eastern carriers and which will fragment the internal market and discriminate against European entrepreneurs?  And last but not least, I can't help but ask you what you are proposing for the Eastern Partnership? Just as the Western Balkans are important, so are the Member States and the Eastern Partnership. I wish you success and I also hope to support measures that bring cohesion, security and unity to the EU.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The ECR Group supports the croatian Presidency's orientations to further deepen the internal market. I appreciate the inclusion in the priorities of the Croatian Presidency of a reference to services and the digital economy and their role in enhancing the EU's global competitiveness. In my opinion, particularly in the road transport sector, there are trends in moving away from the idea of liberalising the internal market.  I absolutely agree with the Croatian Presidency's priority to protect the financial interests of the EU and the Member States. As an example of activity in this area, it is necessary to point to Poland, which fights VAT fraud extremely effectively. The Polish Government's initiative is to create a coalition at EU level to combat tax fraud.  I also support the Croatian Presidency's plans to speed up the enlargement process for the Western Balkan countries and to maintain the EU's credibility in the region. I look forward to a positive decision on the opening of accession negotiations with Albania and North Macedonia at the MARCH RE meeting.  At the same time, I welcome the fact that Croatia mentions the Eastern Partnership in its priorities. I will seek an ambitious agenda for the Eastern Partnership, both politically and financially.

name: Mihai TUDOSE
text: in writing. – I would like to draw the attention of the Croatian Presidency of the Council of the EU to the fact that Nord Stream 2 is not only an economic project, but also one with serious implications for European energy security. The us sanctions imposed on companies involved in the construction of the pipeline are a serious warning of the risks to the Union as a whole by increasing dependence on a single source of gas supply. Surely Nord Stream 2 will bring profit - if and when it is completed - to its investors. However, I believe that it will harm a European Union caught in the vise of the Nord Stream - Turk Stream gas pipelines, especially the countries on the eastern flank. We note, in Bucharest and in the other capitals liberated three decades ago by communism, that the appetite for business of some Member States takes precedence over the principle of solidarity, which is the foundation of European unity, as well as on the common energy security.  In these circumstances, I believe that an urgent analysis of Nord Stream 2's compatibility with EU rules and interests is required. We also need to diversify the Union's sources of energy supply and coordinated negotiations with third countries to respond more effectively to the geopolitical challenges of access to oil and gas resources.

name: Loránt VINCZE
text: Writing. – I welcome the programme of the Croatian Presidency, which started at the beginning of the year, and its priorities. It contains a number of ideas which, to me as MEP of the Hungarian community in Romania, sound encouraging. I mention here the necessary responses to demographic challenges, the catch-up of regions, the preservation of our European cultural heritage, the proper joint European framework for fundamental rights and the rule of law, and, last but not least, the launch of a discourse on the future of Europe.  I am pleased that the six-month programme formulated is objective and to the point. The situation of the Presidency is exceptional in that we are at the beginning of the new five-year European decision-making cycle. This gives us the opportunity to rethink, together with the citizens, the issues on which we are still indebted to Europeans at EU level.  Such a topic is a remedy for the situation of the roughly 10-15 percent of European citizens who belong to one of the indigenous, national communities and speak regional or minority languages. Here in Parliament, an intergroup on indigenous minorities has been re-established and its members are happy to cooperate with the Croatian Presidency. I trust that the Croatian Presidency's programme will provide a place for the Protection of Indigenous Minorities in Europe along the principles of guaranteeing equality, non-discrimination, protection of fundamental rights and the rule of law.

name: Bettina VOLLATH
text: Writing. Thank you for your insights into the objectives of the Croatian Presidency and I now wish you a lot of realism! But I also have a request: you specifically mentioned the need for the security of our external borders and, shortly afterwards, the indispensable need to guarantee the rule of law. So you too must be convinced that these two needs must be reconciled. Unfortunately, however, there have been a large number of very credible reports for more than two years now that illegal repatriations are taking place on the EU's external border in Croatia, even using violence and the deprivation of migrants. Now, of course, we can say: where is the proof – I know nothing. However, if there are so many identical reports, when there are people who are found with relevant injuries and robbed in the Bosnian border area, is this not reason enough for the Croatian Government to look closely at what practices are actually being applied to Croatian border guards? That is precisely what I am asking you to do: make these accusations a matter for the boss and take care of them so that this flaw does not stick to your Presidency from the outset and remain a dark shadow over it.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the implementation and monitoring of the provisions relating to citizens' rights in the Withdrawal Agreement (2020/2505(SDR)).

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – President, honourable Members, as we are about to see the Withdrawal Agreement enter into force, basically unchanged from its 2019 version, except for the provisions regarding Ireland, we should be pleased, in retrospect, with our decision not to accept a carve-out of the provisions on citizens’ rights, as many have requested.  Indeed, having done so would have led to a level of protection far weaker than we have at present, with part two of the agreement dealing with citizens’ rights fully embedded in the whole agreement and with various remedies foreseen should the UK not deliver adequately in implementing these provisions.  This does not mean that we should rest on our laurels and I’m grateful to the European Parliament for having scheduled this debate today. I also welcome the draft resolution tabled as it lists a number of concerns regarding the preservation of citizens’ rights, the administrative procedure in relation to residents’ rights, the limited assistance offered to citizens in this respect or the effectiveness of the UK independent authority due to oversee the implementation of these provisions.  This does not necessarily mean that everything is rosy on the EU side. It is important, as you note in your resolution, to encourage the Member States to adopt a generous attitude regarding the rights of UK citizens having decided to settle in the European Union.  We should also insist that both the Commission and a UK independent authority are rigorous in their monitoring of the implementation of part two of the agreement.  There is also more that can be done regarding the awareness of citizens on both sides of the channel, however protective the provisions of the Withdrawal Agreement. They would be of little use to citizens, especially vulnerable ones, if they are not aware of them, nor of the administrative steps needed to benefit from them. And certainly, Parliament can also play a role in reaching out to citizens and contributing to their information.  Of course all these provisions – even though their effect will last beyond the transition period – will not cover citizens who would consider settling at a later stage. Although we are well aware that the line of the UK Government is to put an end to the free movement of persons, we should make sure that the future relationship that will be negotiated shortly will be ambitious enough in terms of mobility.  This will have to be accompanied with the preservation of certain rights for the citizens concerned.  Let me conclude by noting the large degree of convergence that exists between your positions on citizens’ rights as developed in your various resolutions and the priorities of the Council. This is a clear illustration of the commonality of purposes of our two institutions as regards Brexit.  Our common efforts should help to ensure that the provision on citizens’ rights in the Withdrawal Agreement allows EU citizens and UK nationals, as well as their family members, to continue to live, work or study in their host countries, as they have chosen to do.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: President of the Commission. – Mr President, last week I was in London and I had the opportunity to speak to students about the future of the relationship between the United Kingdom and the European Union. After I had finished the speech, as always the floor was opened to the students and the audience and the very first question that came was not about trade, it was not about financial services, it was not about security, as important as these topics are. It was of course about citizens’ rights. And the same question came back time and again with different personal twists. One came from a young man who came from Benelux living in the UK who was of course worried about his future. Another came from a British lady who has an Italian husband and who was worried about his status, what’s going to happen with him. And while the questions may have been subtly different, the reason for asking them were always the same. People want certainty about their lives and their future and certainty about the future of their loved ones. And I am speaking here about 3.5 million citizens in the UK who come from a European Union Member State, and about the roundabout one million British people living elsewhere in the European Union. Now these are large numbers but behind each of these numbers are people with their very own personal stories. Some are citizens from another European Union country but they are born in the United Kingdom. Others have arrived later. Many have married, have children, have gone to university, have started their careers, and they work in the UK and respectively in the European Union. They teach children, they treat patients, they care for the elderly, they work in farms or factories, they have started their own businesses and provide a living to many more. So whatever their own personal story is, they all have one thing in common, and that is they want to have peace of mind. They want to have a plan for their futures and the future of their families. And all they want is to feel at home in the place they call home. Therefore, protecting these citizens’ rights has always been our top priority from the moment the referendum result became clear. Thanks to the excellent work of Michel Barnier and his negotiating team, the Withdrawal Agreement provides comprehensive guarantees for these citizens. It gives them the protection and the certainty they need. It allows them to stay where they live today, under the same conditions, for as long as they want and without any discrimination based on their nationality. This Withdrawal Agreement and with what we have agreed on, puts clear obligations on the United Kingdom and on the European Union to safeguard these rights. It is one thing is to put them on paper, another thing is to implement them. So once the House has ratified the Withdrawal Agreement our top priority will be to implement our shared obligations, both in letter and in spirit. And for me this is a legal issue with a moral imperative. The good news is that the United Kingdom has already begun implementing the European Union Settlement Scheme. To date, about 2.5 million European Union citizens living in the United Kingdom have already applied for residence status. Most of these people have now received proof of their right to remain. This is good news. But you also know that there are cases where some have not and many more are yet to apply, and there is a number of concerns that have also been raised. There are the famous cases of the French bakers and the Polish chefs that shine a light on some of the issues. But, seriously, there are many other cases where people are confused or unable to apply for whatever reasons. Or others have received requests for more proof, despite having lived in the country for 40 years or more. So, we are in close contact with the citizens and the UK authorities on these issues. We need to avoid any discrimination or added complexity during the application process. We need to ensure that all citizens – especially the most vulnerable – are fully supported throughout the process. And we need the guarantee that the Independent Monitoring Authority can act in full independence to deal with complaints. This is of utmost importance. From our side, the Commission will keep a close and vigilant eye on the implementation. We are ready to help European Union citizens living in the United Kingdom to ensure they are properly informed and supported. And of course we will do the same when it comes to British citizens living in the European Union. All these questions I have been speaking about I raised with Prime Minister Johnson last week when I visited London. We will closely cooperate with the United Kingdom to make sure that we can get this right and that we can solve any problems as swiftly as possible. Finally, the good news is that there will be continuity for the European Union citizens living in the United Kingdom and vice versa for the British citizens living in the European Union at the end of the transition period. But, after the end of the transition period, the United Kingdom will be a third country. And Brexit will mean changes to those who will want to make their future life on either side of the Channel. We will have to negotiate a new way forward, and we are getting ready to formulate the mandate for those negotiations ahead of 1 February. We have, as we have done in the past, also made in these negotiations citizens’ rights our main priority. And we will always negotiate in good faith to build a new comprehensive partnership with our British friends. As I said to those students in London, it is the good old story about old friends and new beginnings. (Applause)

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, in this House, throughout the Brexit process, we have had many meetings with EU citizens, including British nationals. We have listened to their stories and understood better the consequences of Brexit for their rights as European citizens. Their concerns have become ours. In all its resolutions, the European Parliament dealt with citizens’ rights, but still today we see risks to the sustainability of commitments agreed in the withdrawal agreement – hence this new resolution. The lack of proper and full implementation of legal solutions on citizens’ rights would have a massive impact on people’s lives and their life choices. The implementation of the withdrawal agreement matters because it provides a minimum of legal certainty that people need. We regret that in spite of the option presented in Article 18(4) of the withdrawal agreement, the UK has chosen to use the application approach for a settled status scheme. I regret, also, that only half the Member States seem to use the approach based on the declaration. We also deeply regret that the UK Government has announced its intention to end free movement of people under the future framework for cooperation. EU citizens, including British nationals, have greatly benefited from the free movement of people and I still hope that the British Government changes its mind on this issue. It will, further, be crucial that we find a way towards mutual recognition of qualifications, that it will be possible for citizens to participate in local elections, that there will be good cooperation in the field of family law on the basis of relevant provisions in international law and that potential regulatory divergence will not affect citizens’ rights. I appreciate the assurances given to us by the UK Government with regard to the functioning of the independent monitoring authority. The European Parliament will nevertheless keep a watchful eye on the implementation process. As we have pointed out in our resolution, the shortened transition period means that there is less time to operationalise governance of the withdrawal agreement regarding citizens’ rights and that an awareness-raising campaign will also be a matter of priority. Ultimately, the proper and full implementation of citizens’ rights would help to build the trust needed for successful negotiations on the future.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, our first duty as the European Parliament, elected directly by the European citizens, is to defend those we democratically represent. That explains why our top priority in terms of Brexit has always been citizens’ rights, not only the rights of EU citizens living in the UK, but also the rights of British citizens living all over the European Union. Listening to the serious concerns expressed by so many citizens and NGOs, we simply cannot ignore that people are extremely worried about the high degree of uncertainty and other damaging implications of Brexit in their lives and legitimate expectations. That is why we are here today to discuss and approve a political resolution tabled and supported by the leaders of many political groups in this Parliament and designed to convey a strong political message. The UK Government can do more and should do more to ensure full protection of citizens’ rights in the context of Brexit. We certainly acknowledge the efforts made on such a difficult issue, but the truth is that the EU settlement scheme currently in operation in the UK could easily be more user friendly and would largely benefit if additional assistance were provided to older and more vulnerable citizens.  On the other hand, as many applicants are only getting pre-settled status, it would be better to take this procedure as declaratory in nature and to ensure proper review by a truly independent authority. Moreover, a physical document would help to give additional legal certainty and a sense of certainty for the future, not only for citizens, but also for employers and landlords. We hope to get a positive response from the UK Government regarding citizens’ rights.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, the first thing that I want to do is to thank the President of the Commission, Ms von der Leyen, and also Michel Barnier, naturally, for their strong and continued support on citizens’ rights. I hope that this House, when we vote – I think it’s tomorrow we vote – on this resolution gives it a huge majority, a huge majority that gives us a mandate for the final discussions with the UK authorities, which will happen on Thursday. I have been invited by the Secretary of State, Mr Barclay, and by the new Minister for European Affairs, Mr Pincher. It’s important that this resolution has massive support so that it gives us strength on Thursday and Friday because there are still concerns that need to be addressed. If they are not addressed now, before the end of the month, they will be on the table before the end of the year. I cannot imagine that the European Parliament will agree, for example, on the free-trade agreement (FTA) without solving the problems and the concerns of the EU citizens and the UK citizens, including freedom of movement.  These concerns have already been mentioned by my two colleagues. First of all, the automatic recognition of citizens’ rights. There is a Tory Government and Tory governments always say that they want less bureaucracy. Well, OK, let’s make less bureaucracy and the best way to do it is automatic recognition so that you don’t need all this. The second is a physical document. Why is it necessary? The UK authorities are telling us that, ‘yes, but it’s not necessary – they have an email’. But can you imagine a case where a woman goes to see her parents on the continent, comes back and at the border they ask, ‘where is your email?’ – ‘I don’t have my email, there is no energy anymore in my battery’ – or maybe she deleted the mail, so she cannot enter the UK. We need a physical document. In a normal world, you have a document. That’s the second concern.  The third concern is the Independent Monitoring Authority. My proposal is simple: why not put a few representatives of the 3million organisation in the Independent Monitoring Authority? Then we are sure that both sides are there, so it solves the problem. These things need to be addressed and I hope that they will be on Thursday and Friday.  Maybe, to finish on a lighter note, I can ask Prime Minister Johnson for a little bit of flexibility. Maybe he can follow the Queen’s example – because yesterday the Queen gave Harry and Meghan a transition period to leave, so maybe some flexibility on Mr Johnson’s side could also be very useful. (Applause)

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, the European Union is often presented as a vast, mainly economic project, committed to promoting the interests of capital holders. That is somewhat true, but it is not that the European Union and the three million citizens of the European Union who live in the United Kingdom and the 2 million or so Britons who live in the European Union know this well. The freedom of movement, the freedom to establish themselves to study, to work, to retire, a freedom granted to all the citizens of the European Union, is probably one of the pearls, one of the most important achievements of the European Union. This is, of course, what all these citizens are likely to lose with the now inevitable withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union. Indeed, this Parliament and the European negotiators, including Michel Barnier, have done everything possible to minimise the damage - because there is damage - caused by the UK's withdrawal from the European Union. I think what was put in the separation agreement is satisfactory, but it is true that we have a problem of trust with the United Kingdom: it is true that we are concerned about the administrative difficulties that are being put in place or of this threat which is written in black and white in the transposition into British law of the separation agreement and which provides for the possibility for the British Government to abolish outright the independent authority which will ensure the application of the separation agreement in terms of respect for the rights of citizens. Even more worrying are the statements made by some close to the British Home Office that almost portray EU citizens residing in the UK as threats to state security. So my message to the Government of the United Kingdom is this: if you really consider the European Union to be a friendly power of the United Kingdom, make sure that by your attitude towards European citizens, you simply confirm that status as friends. Be sure to treat EU citizens in the UK as you want British citizens in the European Union to be treated.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: on behalf of the ID Group. – Mr President, dear colleagues, especially those who are here for the last time, the EU-UK Withdrawal Agreement is a salutary example of belated political realism. The resolution debated today accepts this verdict. Three points, however, deserve mention.  First, the agreement states that in future, the parties may decide no longer to accept national identity cards without a biometric identification chip. Such a rule is not unlawful, but there seems no obvious legal, economic or security reason for it. Data protection and privacy were once subjects of fierce political debates. Sadly in our rights-obsessed political climate today, such basic rights seem forgotten.  Second, the agreement freezes EU citizens’ rights as they are being interpreted on Brexit day, while assigning future interpretation to the Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU). The CJEU is, in effect, asked to develop two parallel bodies of case—law: one for citizens’ rights within the EU27 and another for the UK based on pre-Brexit EU law. How realistic, I ask, is this? Finally, clause 18 of the resolution bemoans the UK Government’s intention to end free movement of persons next year. The motion claims that all four freedoms are interlinked and that any comprehensive EU-UK trade deal should be conditional on the UK agreeing to generous free movement of persons rules. This demand is against the UK’s and the EU’s own interests. Free trade agreements – indeed, most EU trade agreements – generally say nothing about free movement of persons. The EU in 2018 had a very large trade surplus with the UK. It’s therefore in the EU’s interests, just as Britain’s, to negotiate a comprehensive trade deal.  If this House is serious about citizens’ rights, then EU and UK citizens have a right that their economic interests be taken seriously by this House.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I know that the new Commission President had a very good meeting with the British Prime Minister in London last week. They got on extremely well.
