But it is a revolution to emerge from a model that has become obsolete in the face of the climate challenge. What I want to tell you is that we have to set two priorities.  First, to cushion the social cost, then to accompany the regions in this just transition and as chairman of the Committee on Regional Development, I want to tell you that we are fully mobilised to carry out our legislative work.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a study on the conversion of my city, Taranto, home to Europe's largest and most polluting steel works, says that the cyclofossile is closing, leaving the slow and devious decay of an elsewhere normal life in the seas, aquifer, air and soils, accompanied by social disintegration and without any parachutes. It is industrial sites like this that the just transition fund must respond to, with the protection of citizens' health as a priority. It will not be a fair transition, but yet another mockery, if modernising the plants means using gas, a fossil and climate-changing source, especially without a health impact assessment. The strategic importance of the green new deal is to rethink the economy, transport, energy, turn Europe into a source of inspiration, a leader in the fight against global warming. Be ware, however: this Fund must not take resources away from cohesion policy but, if anything, be in synergy. Finally, the proposal: the ETS could have allocated as much as 48 billion over the last three years to climate actions, so revenues from the ETS are used to finance the just transition fund.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Madam President, I say to the First Vice-President and Executive Vice-President: I am not an automotive engineer but I know that our industry is probably the best engine ever built. So when it runs it needs fine tuning to keep running and deliver employment and well-being for millions of families and societies across Europe. So, if we try to overload that engine for a very short period of time, it will cut out, it will break down, that’s for sure. And knowing this we should debate on the Green Deal and the JTF. So, I believe that we should support the European Commission and its initiative to secure the future of our children and a good environment. I know the future belongs to policies, which deliver without harming the environment. I know the future belongs to policies, which are not harming the future of our kids. But I believe we could achieve that without killing whole sectors. I believe we can achieve that without leaving millions of people without jobs. So let’s work in a way to fine-tune this. My concerns are that if we have big and new initiatives, we need new and big funding, and the proper time to deliver those results. It’s a great idea, but we have to pay attention to the details and not make families, industries and whole sectors of our economy pay for this.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: - Dear Chairman, I welcome the European Sustainable Investment Plan as a key part of the New Green Deal. Its aim is to enable the financing of the Green Deal, but also to encourage other types of financing, not primarily private investment and public funding at national levels through fiscal policy reform. We must not forget that Member States must also participate in this project to create a more socially and environmentally conscious Europe. I welcome the reform of the European Semester through the SDGs. We must also ensure that the Commission's recommendations are implemented at national level in order to truly achieve the ambitious sustainable objectives we have set for ourselves. The Just Transition Fund needs to be used to reduce regional inequalities in the European Union and help the most vulnerable, and the European Investment Bank must significantly increase funding for climate projects. The rules we set out in the Taxonomy Directive should underpin all these changes. And in the end, we must not forget about the citizens. A just transition is not possible without dialogue with social actors and communities affected by the transition.

name: Sylvie BRUNET
text: Madam President, Commissioners, I am convinced that there can be no fair ecological and digital transition without anticipation and social support. Firstly, it is therefore imperative to help European workers acquire the skills they will need to move from declining to expanding sectors by strengthening their employability. Moreover, it will be useful to share our knowledge on these skills and jobs needs in Europe, of which we have no vision. Second, the transition must be socially fair and leave no one behind. Let us not forget measures to combat energy insecurity and the implementation of affordable solutions for those affected by carbon pricing measures. It is therefore imperative that we ensure the social acceptability of the transition to a more sustainable and climate-neutral economy. How? Strengthening social dialogue to anticipate and manage change and combating all forms of inequality and exclusion.

name: Katrin LANGENSIEPEN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Thinking together on environmental, economic and social policy is one of the greatest challenges. It will decide whether measures for ecological change are fair and socially accepted, or whether existing injustices in Europe are exacerbated. The Commission's proposal on the Fair Transition Fund is, in principle, correct. Poorer, most marginalised people in particular are confronted with the negative effects of climate change. Our task must be to protect these people and to protect them socially. The proposed financial support, for example for the retraining of jobseekers, is to be welcomed, but will be far from sufficient. In order to fully counteract social exclusion, we must also take into account people who are not active in the labour market. The aim of the Sustainable Development Agenda is to eradicate poverty in all its dimensions by 2030 and not to reinforce it further. The way to be climate-neutral must be a common inclusive process that largely excludes discrimination of any kind. It is therefore essential that Member States involve civil society and social partners in the preparation, implementation and evaluation of their regional plans. It is also essential that we create social safeguards. Only in this way can we prevent poverty and accompany people in transition. In this context, the European Commission urgently needs to propose a framework directive on a minimum income.

name: Laura HUHTASAARI
text: – Mr President, the EU is buying behind its green deal those Member States that are still dependent on fossil energy sources. If the size of the Fair Transition Fund is set at an estimated 100 billion, it will obviously be channelled to Eastern Europe.  A green deal will not only cost eu countries that use a lot of coal, such as Poland. Countries such as Finland, which are climate-conscious, are forced to drastically reduce their emissions radically further, at the risk of losing the competitiveness of their own industry. Finland, which has made and is making emission reductions at its own expense, is now paying emissions reductions for others. Finland has long distances, a cold winter and a small internal market, so there are plenty of challenges without the EU bringing additional burdens. The Green Deal is used to fool nation states into pursuing a planned economy. This has nothing to do with the market economy.

name: Elżbieta RAFALSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In the green transition, the employment problem, the problem of workers, the human costs, the social impact of these changes are very important. In the Commission's plan, very little space has been devoted to those workers who are at risk of losing their jobs. This problem will particularly affect employees with many years of service, i.e. workers in the 50 and 60+ age group, those who have 30 years or more of seniority. It will also affected entire regions in Poland. This will apply to Lower and Upper Silesia, Malopolska or Wielkopolska. What will the European Commission propose to them? To what extent does the Just Transition Fund take this situation into account? Won't these workers be victims of the Green Deal? Have these social impacts been taken into account? Free training, retraining and courses alone are not enough here. That's definitely not enough. We must talk about these risks, because if this is linked to an increase in unemployment, job losses, the collapse of entire industries, no one will say that this is a just transition, but a social transformation that impacts workers.

name: Silvia MODIG
text: – Mr President, the Just Transition Fund is a vital part of the Green Deal. We must ensure that the costs of the transition do not fall on the already vulnerable. The conditions under which we support the regions most affected by the transition must be very precise so that no euro ends up at the wrong address. Support must be strongly conditional on real and effective climate action, and the target must genuinely support the people of the region concerned so that the transition is truly socially just. These include improving energy efficiency, climate action, which at best reduces housing costs, retraining those employed from coal and the direct creation of genuinely climate-sustainable jobs.  And this brings us to the fact that all solutions must support and strengthen the good principles of the social pillar. Everyone must have equal access to education and participation in the labour market, because if we take social justice into account in all climate solutions, we will be able to reform our society not only to be carbon neutral, but also to make it better for all Europeans.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to return to the issue of the green deal at the level of the national budget, because both the European Commission and the ECB have repeatedly heard about the fiscal area that governments are allowed to do, and this means that there are governments, those that have a low public debt ratio, that can make investments, while those governments that have a higher debt-to-GDP ratio cannot make investments, let alone green ones. This is a great macroeconomic nonsense: firstly, because all countries must help to eliminate their emissions; secondly, because it is precisely those countries that have the greatest economic difficulties that need to invest in this and their investment multipliers are more effective. If we invest a point of GDP in these countries, we will have the effect of three points of GDP on their economies and therefore on their ability to reduce emissions.  Our solution is to break green investment away from budgetary constraints, in the expectation and hope of removing precisely the budgetary constraints and the entire austerity policy.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Madam President, Ladies and Gentlemen, Ladies and Gentlemen, Ladies and Gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioners for the work she has said. The European Union has set itself ambitious climate targets. However, these climate targets will not be achieved by themselves, but require a great deal of investment, and this money must come from somewhere. That is why it is right that the Commission has put forward a proposal today and is considering this issue. However, the sustainable investment plan is not the first investment plan that we are dealing with here in this House. It was only in the last parliamentary term that we dealt with the so-called Juncker Fund, and the Juncker Fund gives us valuable lessons on where to be careful. I would just like to mention three key words very briefly: firstly, we must ensure that there is a balanced distribution. With regard to the Juncker Fund, we have found that money has disproportionately gone where the most resourceful applicants sat. Secondly, we must pay attention to additionality. We do not need to redefine or redefine investment, but we need to trigger additional investment. There is no point in a large number of projects end up with the label 'sustainable investment', so that the Commission meets its target, but we have not made the bottom line any more. Thirdly, it is also very important to me that the private sector makes the difference. It is also about being so attractive that private investors are also willing to join in. And that is what we, as a Parliament, want to ensure now in legislation.

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Thank you to our Commissioners Timmermans and Mr Dombrovskis for very ambitious introductions.  Many of europe's citizens today feel a great fear of the future and the challenges we face, and I share that concern. Not least around the big and important climate challenge.  The Commission communication on a stronger social Europe is therefore very important. We Social Democrats have been driving the social pillar – work actually started in Sweden in Gothenburg in 2017 – and the pillar will be an important step on the way to a more social Europe. Because now we must raise our ambitions with jobs for both women and men, jobs with good working conditions, education and social protection. We must have wages throughout europe that people can actually live on. We must have decent wages, and although I, as a Swede, would prefer to see that we develop the Nordic model throughout the EU, we will follow this work.  We are looking forward to a fairer and more social Europe. It is the essence of making people's everyday lives better. So let's start that work right now.

name: Katalin CSEH
text: – Madam President, if there is one thing we have to make absolutely clear about a Just Transition Fund is that citizens need to be in the centre of it, not governments: not large and polluting companies, but ordinary people. We have to ensure that a just transition reaches the poorest and neediest regions of Europe. We need to concentrate funds where EU assistance means a difference between being warm and freezing to death during winter. Solidarity has to be in the heart of a just transition process. There is, however, one thing that I am not a fan of and that is corrupted and greedy governments. Some EU Member States will see this new fund as another opportunity to rob beneficiaries of EU money while enriching a small circle of loyal cronies. We cannot repeat the mistakes of managing the Cohesion Fund. A just transition fund has to operate in the most transparent way, equipped with the right tools to prevent mismanagement of money. Solidarity and transparency must guide the implementation process. Turning a climate emergency into climate neutrality won’t be easy, but with the right tools it can just be made possible.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: – Madam President, when the Commission presented the Green Deal in December it was very clear this is a change. This is really a new Commission with a new focus and new priorities, and that we fully support and we are really standing behind that, but then of course the big question is going to be: will there be investment? Because we all know this is not a minor change, this is a change, this is a transition in all the sectors, in all the regions, in all the countries of Europe. And that also desires investment, and there I have to say – and I can’t fully judge yet because I haven’t seen the final proposal, but of course we’ve seen earlier versions – but is now the real Green Deal, with a new policy, really matched by new policies on investments?  Until now, I don’t think so.  First of all, it seems like the same old discussion on the European budget that was started by the previous Commission, and secondly, when we are talking about a sustainable investment plan, I sincerely hope it’s not just another Juncker investment plan 2.1, 2.2, 2.3, where are we now? We really have to look at additionality  and changes of the EIB there. So this really desires fundamental change. That’s possible. It’s  possible when we are looking at green public procurement there we can really make a change. But also we need to address changes in fiscal policies, and if then in the draft we see that you are planning a debate, and the outcome of that debate will form the basis for any possible future just steps – including how to treat sustainable investment – that doesn’t read like the change that we need also in our fiscal policies. So I hope the final version will be better.

name: Ivan DAVID
text: – Madam President, treating a sick planet on parts of one continent at huge cost and poor efficiency with considerable side effects is a bizarre idea. Mrs von der Leyen is said to have studied medicine. The first commandment of the doctor is primum non nocere (above all, do no harm). I am afraid that the Green Deal project is far from being prepared to be implemented responsibly. We are to look at the proposal on how to deal fairly with financial injections for the damage done to society by the future implementation of chimeric ambitious projects. We're supposed to take everyone's money and treat the most damaged. We hear ourselves - it should be, it must be. But we know what's going on with ambitious plans with no preconditions and ignored consequences. Your projects are in the fog. A society governed by ideology always goes wrong.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, Commissioners, the commitments made by the EU in the field of energy are clearly set and set very high. But no region that has to change the foundations of its economy should be left out on the road to a more sustainable future.  I am very happy that the Commission has come up with a proposal for a fund to help these regions transform their economies into completely different areas. I am quite sceptical about the calculations from the table, but it is clear that this will be the need for billions of euros across the EU. It will therefore be important to process an impact study that demonstrates what this change will mean for each region. I see close links with cohesion funds as problematic for central and eastern Europe. I am concerned that there will be great tensions not only between Member States, but also between regions.

name: Nikolaj VILLUMSEN
text: Madam President! In recent years, we have seen how the European Court of Justice and the crisis policy of the EUROPEAN Union have weakened the trade union movement and the right to collective agreements. That is why, of course, it is good that the European Commission is finally recognising that there is a huge problem of growing inequality. But the proposal to impose a statutory minimum wage hits the side of it completely. I fear that a statutory minimum wage will be another blow to the trade union movement.  Instead, there is a need to strengthen collective agreements. Let us have a social protocol that puts workers' rights above the eu's internal market. Let us enable municipalities to opt out of tinkering companies when they make public tenders. And let us strengthen the trade union movement so that we can ensure a level playing field for equal work and stop the gross exploitation of our foreign colleagues.

name: Robert ROWLAND
text: – Madam President, we have now reached a tipping point where we see clear evidence of job destruction across Europe due to the insane green policies of the EU. The promised job creation is an illusion propagated by our masters in the Commission who roll out their seven year Soviet—era Gosplan in the misguided belief they know how to create economic wealth. Most of these career bureaucrats have never created a business in their life, and certainly don’t have any understanding of what they’re doing to the industrial base of Europe. This is not Schumpeter’s ‘creative destruction’ – this is a made-in-Europe version of destructive destruction. The German automotive industries already announced over 40 000 job losses due to forced conversion to electric vehicles. The promise of green new jobs reminds me of the American Major in the Vietnam War who said ‘to save a village, you first have to destroy it’.  The same economically illiterate logic is used by the EU Commission. They think they have the power to magically create new jobs once they have destroyed existing ones. The unJust Transition Fund budget of just over EUR 30 billion is meant to assist countries such as Poland and the Czech Republic. My prediction is that the number will triple as the Commission pays for the folly of the Green New Deal and is forced to rescue large swathes of Europe’s obsolete industrial base that has been intentionally destroyed.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Niklas NIENASS
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Thank you for your performance today. I can understand that you are not entirely satisfied because your own government is letting its own people down. But wouldn't you have to be in the UK? If you're chasing an exit here, why are you coming here? So I mean, stay where you are.

name: Robert ROWLAND
text: blue-card answer. – I’m not sure there was a question there, but it gives me a wonderful opportunity just to reiterate. I will give you an example in the UK. Ex-Chancellor Hammond said the cost of the net zero target for 2050 was GBP 1 trillion. We have not had an impact assessment in the UK. I would urge everyone in this Chamber, before they sign off on this Green New Deal, to ask the Commission, Mr Timmermans, what the impact assessment is on everyday jobs. For example, in the UK, we currently pay GBP 12 billion a year in renewable obligation certificates and other forms of green levies that go directly on household bills. It is a regressive tax and the poorest pay it.

name: Dennis RADTKE
text: Madam President, Vice-Presidents, I would like to thank the Commissioners for their excellent work and for the work she has done. Thank you for the insight, for the start you made here today. However, it has to be said that it is not much more. And that is why I say, in view of the challenges that we now have in front of our chests: we must now also get out of this heading mode, we must now also come out of this cloudy and flowery mode. Because the election campaign is over – even for you, Mr Timmermans! That is why it is simply so important that we now not only remain in the rough, but also make it very concrete where we should go, including in terms of social Europe. With regard to the Fair Transition Fund, which I very much welcome, I want to make it very clear what must not happen. What must not happen is that existing budget titles are simply being reallocated and that we are now suddenly starting to put ESF funds into the Fund for a Fair Transition. After all, we will have an effect of pitting people who work in industries that are threatened in their existence by the transformation of climate change, for example, against the long-term unemployed, who have very different problems. We must not play off those affected against the weak in our society, but if we are serious and say ' climate change and the fight against climate change must not lead to disruptive developments and structural breaks', then we must generate additional money and not simply shovel the money from the left pocket into the right pocket.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Madam President, from what we are hearing today, there is still scepticism from people on whether climate change and inequalities can be addressed together. I think the fact that we are discussing precisely this point today – a Just Transition and a sustainable investment plan – is proof that, yes, climate change and inequalities can be addressed together if there is the will to do so. With the European Green Deal, we want to make Europe a front—runner in climate—friendly industries but, at the same time, I am sure that climate action benefits the most vulnerable and does not leave low—income households behind. Yes, we recognise that workers in carbon—intensive activities need the required protection to be able to benefit from this transition because, ultimately, the jobs of tomorrow will require different skills and we need to make sure that our current workforce adapts, while the future workforce is prepared for these jobs. At the same time, green practices, goods and services should never be out of reach for the least well-off. I believe that we require an inclusive Just Transition based on three main pillars: participation, support and creation. Participation of affected workers and communities in planning and advancing climate action; support through targeted financial programmes and capacity building that prioritises the most vulnerable; and creation of high-quality and sustainable jobs and strong social measures, including reskilling and upskilling of workers. This is the opportunity that we have in front of us. Given the right financing and the right policies, this will be our opportunity to create new jobs in a new economic reality.

name: Clotilde ARMAND
text: – Madam President, I do not believe that there is a barrier to the East's attitude towards the European Green Pact. In many ways, societies in Eastern Europe are well placed to talk about ecology. These companies have maintained a stronger link with nature, maintained short supply chains, gone through the deindustrialisation phase in many regions. The fight against deforestation and polluting mining is, for example, highly mobilizing in Romania for civic society. Many Eastern countries have made efforts to achieve their targets for the share of renewable energy. Of the 14 Member States that exceed the Community average, 7 countries are from Eastern Europe. It is proof that we can have clear environmental objectives, but we need to find the right formula: funding, assistance in project implementation, recognition of the importance of the energy mix. We need to take the green turn intelligently and not feed eurosceptic positions.

name: Ville NIINISTÖ
text: – Madam President, the Green Deal is most ambitious plan that Europe has had for decades. It has to be that: the climate demands it, the youth on the streets demand it, but also business leadership demands it. This is a chance for Europe to modernise and take global leadership also when it comes to the economy and business and create a circular economy in Europe and export that knowledge abroad. But this is not happening if we don’t show that we can also deliver. The risk with the financing that you are proposing is that it’s still quite hazy. We have EUR 7.5 billion, which is on paper. Everything else is a bit unclear as to whether it is actually additional. Also, on those EUR 7.5 billion: we have to be very clear that it is additional action, not just something that legislation would demand anyway. When it comes to the EIB, we also have to be very, very clear that that’s something that creates additional movement towards low carbon economy, and not just financing something that the public sector does anyway. So this is something that the Commission now has to work on: deliver stringent conditions for getting rid of fossil fuels and actually finance solutions that are viable in the long term, not just interim solutions. Good luck with that.

name: Guido REIL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The Green Deal is the most anti-social project in the history of the European Union, and anyone who believes that he can prevent the decline of coal regions with money, with structural aid, has learned nothing from history and from the past. So I happen to have a bit of a clue that I have been working in mining in the Ruhr area for the last 33 years – until I entered the European Parliament. There is no mining left, and my homeland, the Ruhr area, is now the poorhouse of Germany. In my native gelsenkirchen there is the highest unemployment rate in Germany, there are the most poor children, and there are the most poor old people.  In the former coal regions in Belgium, France and England, the situation is the same, we don't have to delude ourselves, look at it! In Poland, things will be exactly the same. 100 000 jobs will be lost, there will be a disaster for Silesia. We are not just talking about mining. The engine of the German economy is the automotive industry, and advisers to the Federal Government now estimate that 410 000 jobs are being lost! That will break our backbone. Let's put an end to this madness!

name: Grzegorz TOBISZOWSKI
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Dear!  Climate care is a great and responsible task. In order for the Green Deal to function smoothly and meet its objectives, we need to know on what foundations it was based. I therefore ask the Commissioners whether the European Commission has consulted or intends to consult the Member States on the measures, the investment, the specific money they will need in order to carry out the energy transition effectively, without losing out on the energy security of each country and Europe. Does the European Commission know how long it will take to green national economies, knowing today's access to the technologies to support this process?  In Poland, we estimate that the additional costs of transformation in 2020-2050 will average between 2.6% and 4.3% of GDP. That's more than €500 billion. This is 1.7 to 2.3 times higher than the European Union average. Please note that in Poland we also have a Silesian region, which is connected with the mining sector, and in this sector and around it there are 200 000 people working. On the other hand, it costs EUR 250 000 to create a single job in this sector. This data comes from the academic centres of the region. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Petros KOKKALIS
text: blue-card question. – Does the honourable colleague have an understanding of the cost of the percentage of GDP that adaptation will cost in the case of temperatures rising over the Paris Agreement?

name: Grzegorz TOBISZOWSKI
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I did not question this in my speech, noting that climate care is a great and responsible task. In order to meet this task, it is necessary to stand up to the truth by doing the right analyses in order to respond rationally to climate challenges and care, bearing in mind people and workplaces. So I am not at odds with the programme, but I would like us, as a Europe that wants to be a world leader in climate concern, to be a real leader, not just to talk about the fact that we have a good plan, good assumptions.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: – Madam President, we agree with the Statements of the European Commission when it says that the fund for the energy transition must be fair and that the Green New Deal must be social. But this is not possible if social and environmental objectives have to compete for a financial package that has been cut and if we continue to work on this double financial trick that consists of moving the same money from one side to the other, announcing new priorities, new acronyms, new funds, new propaganda, but making the new money available only to the militaristic and security obsession. Nor with the trick of announcing 100 billion euros, money that will not be invested by the European Union and which the European Union does not know if others will invest. Nor can we say that the Green New Deal will be social if we are to exclude from the fund for the fair transition and from all these cohesion policies and regions that are at the front line of the consequences of climate change.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen commissioners, we are on the right track with this investment plan for sustainability, with this fund for a fair transition. In the European Parliament we have always said that new priorities need to be extra resources and it is very positive that the Fair Transition Fund has an additional EUR 7.5 billion. My question is: why 7.5 billion euros? Will that be enough? It is something that Parliament will have to study and verify. Furthermore, complementarity is also positive with cohesion policy, but cohesion policy must not be misdone: fair transition can never take place against territorial, economic and social cohesion. Furthermore, there is an appeal: Member States have to define their investment plans, they need to know what they want for their regions. Otherwise, once the amounts for each region have been defined, they will complain, they will say that it is Brussels' fault and they will say that after all the money is not enough, when they have not even said what they wanted. And it is urgent that each Member State, that each region also do its homework in this area.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a trillion investments for Europe's sustainable change over the next ten years: this is the important objective that the Commission is presenting today for a Europe that achieves climate neutrality in 2050 and is increasingly socially inclusive. There are certainly many resources, but if we are to successfully address the profound changes that these challenges require, we must commit ourselves to making more resources available in the coming years.  I come back to the Commission's proposals: I would like to highlight two of them, which contain significant innovations. Firstly, finally, a fund with resources dedicated to making the transition socially fair, because we must attack climate change but also avoid leaving someone behind, especially in sectors that will face important industrial conversions, because sustainability must be agreed with everyone in order to be achieved. Secondly, the explicit reference in the investment plan to the opening of a debate on the demeriming of sustainable investment in the Member States from the calculation of the deficit in the Stability Pact must be grasped. I am aware of the timidity with which the reference is included in the text, but I would like to reiterate, as some of my fellow Members have already done, that this issue must be tackled with determination in order to ensure that the Member States too are able to make their essential contribution to this challenge. This is the path that Europe must take: to keep up the level of ambition on essential issues such as environmental sustainability and, at the same time, to reach out a hand to those who risk falling behind in society. Focusing on environmental sustainability and social inclusiveness are the keys to making European citizens passionate again.

name: Jordi CAÑAS
text: – Madam President, Commissioners, during the crisis I had an economist friend and I said: "Behind the macroeconomic measures that are taken there are people". And he said, "Well, let them step aside."  Sustainability is a principle, it is an objective. But sustainability, like crises, is always paid for by the weakest; it cannot be that sustainability and the road to it, transition and change are again paid for by the weakest and most vulnerable, because we are here to make a Europe more sustainable, but also fairer. And there are some who, in front of sustainability, put some concepts and some ideas that forget that there are people behind them. Therefore, we need funds, yes, but we also need objectives, and values. And that value is to develop social policy, the European social pillar. Because this development is not only funds: they are concrete objectives to guarantee our citizens that never again nor crises, nor changes, nor transitions will be baited in the weakest, the most vulnerable.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Madam President. Thank you, Mr Vice-President, for presenting us today with the Sustainable Investment Plan and the Fair Transition Fund. I believe that these are two essential instruments for the European Green Pact. Two comments on this. With regard to the Fair Transition Fund, my colleagues have said, I think we must be sure that it will indeed lead to a transition. And, therefore, that criterion of conditionality, of getting out of coal and really committing to climate neutrality must be an essential component. So, first of all, I would like to ask you to have that incorporated into the Fair Transition Fund, which is a central element. We can't leave anyone behind in that. And so I think it's a good thing to put it as a real priority. And then, on the investment plan, what we know gives me the feeling that we lack a little ambition when it comes to getting resources for that investment. I think it's kind of a Juncker 3.0 plan, a little refried with national contributions. And I think that's where we need to go a little further. We need new sources of resources to be able to come up with a plan that is extremely ambitious. I doubt that with what has come to us, what we have on the table, we can reach that billion euros. Therefore, my second message would be: let's please put more ambition into obtaining resources to make that plan a real transformative tool.

name: Paolo BORCHIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, half a million workers affected, 160 000 jobs at risk throughout Europe, fifty regions involved: these are the likely numbers of what could be the next employment crisis. According to the gospel of the most important neoliberalism, it seems that the European Commission is proposing a strategy of decarbonisation in the knowledge that it will exacerbate the problem of unemployment, all in the name of fatalism, because it seems that you have resigned yourself to deindustrialising Europe, the continent where the industrial revolution was born. I ask what resources this fund will be given, given that you have talked about a thousand billion that do not exist to date, and above all do you intend to solve something by sending fifty-year-old unemployed people to do training courses? If the way is to snatch the cohesion funds or the European Regional Development Fund, then we are not there. I am now asking for the help of the interpreters, because in Italian, in these cases, it is said that the patch is worse than the hole!

name: Anna ZALEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioners, I do not know if you have noticed, but even your supporters say 'yes but'. They say "but" because the plan presented is very superficial. It is not enough to say "we want", "we promise". All the more so because trust in the Commission has already been strained, because all countries agreed in 2014 to seek to reduce emissions by 40%, and all these targets that have been presented to the Commission will be thrown in the bin in a moment.  But I obviously have very specific questions for these superficial numbers, because some of them defy logic, mathematics, and certainly economics. Where does 7.5 billion new money come from? New taxes would have to be introduced. If so, which ones? How do we get from the 7.5 billion to 100 billion promised by the Commission? If new investments, then which ones? I ask for precise information. If we are to raise almost EUR 300 billion from private investors, how does the Commission want to do this? Finally, the question is: when will we have a new climate law? There are less than sixty days left.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Madam President, Vice-Presidents, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I think it is a great vision for us in Europe to become climate neutral. The old Commission has already shown in 2018 how we can achieve this: with additional jobs and additional economic growth. But we need a good framework for this, and some regions simply need to change more than others. That is why it is good that we are taking these people with us through the Fund for a Fair Transition. I stress that this is what we must do in all the regions of Europe. We cannot apply the old criteria to this new objective. Even in richer regions, people face challenges that we would not have without coal phase-out. That is why we need to do something about this. Nor should we have the illusion that Europe can do this on its own. We also need national support, and the Commission must approve this under state aid law. We also need to talk about own resources from the ETS. That is another reason why my group is in favour of extending the ETS. I regret that we still have a great deal of resistance here, but I hope that we can agree on this. Finally, I would like to pay tribute to a colleague who sits behind me and who only talks after me about what is actually wrong, because he is the inventor of the Fund for a Fair Transition. Without him, we would not have this proposal today and would not have so much support for it. Thank you, Jerzy Buzek, for your commitment, and we are fighting to make it a reality in the end.

name: Dan NICA
text: – Madam President, Vice-President Timmermans, I would like to welcome your announcement of the allocation of EUR 7.5 billion for funds for a fair transition, and at the same time I would also like to welcome what you announced this morning, namely that the European Investment Bank will be involved in supporting the projects that are necessary for decarbonisation at European Union level.  In the case of Romania, the presence of the European Investment Bank is vital because the investment needs that I saw in a study presented in December is EUR 80 billion for the next ten years, i.e. 4% of GDP, which should be spent every year from this year onwards; it is an enormous amount and, without the support of the European Investment Bank, it will be very difficult for us, and I hope that this will happen because in the past the European Investment Bank has supported more the countries that are the richest in the European Union and little or no need for help. At the same time, Mr Vice-President, I would like to ask you to insist that the projects that are needed for the decarbonisation-affected regions start immediately, as well as the social projects for these regions, which are vital for many people: in the case of Romania alone, there are 170,000 people who are affected.

name: Pascal CANFIN
text: Madam President, I come from a country, France, where citizens wore yellow vests to tell us that the ecological transition had to be right and that is why it is essential that today, the first political act that is taken by the European Commission, after presenting its European Green Pact, is precisely the just transition fund , so that no European citizen or territory is left out, so that risks can be turned into opportunities. I would like to say to the far-right colleagues who follow one after the other to shout, saying 'it is unbearable, it will cost us far too much': go ask the people of Venice if they think it is very expensive to fight climate change, if we do too much or if on the contrary we do not do enough. Go and ask the Australians today if they think too much is being done globally against climate change or whether doing nothing or not doing enough is costing a lot of money and destroying their continent. That's the reality. Stop looking in the rear-view mirror, let's look to the future, let's do it together, don't back down to the European Commission, put the necessary money on the table, you have the support of Parliament and the citizens of Europe. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 171, paragraph 8 of the internal regulation)

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Mr President, you are a Member from France. I am amazed at your statement. Yellow vests against climate policy have been taking to the streets of France for months. Please note that your energy mix is only 2% coal-based. Polish the energy mix close to 80%, so what costs will this climate policy, so restrictive for the Polish people, generate? Is a just climate transition to be about governing the voice of the nation?

name: Pascal CANFIN
text: answer 'blue card'. "Precisely, it is very important that there be this fair transition fund and we support it. I particularly support it because in countries like Poland, the starting point is different, and I welcomed the fact that Poland did not block the carbon neutrality target in Europe in December. Your government could have done it, it did not, and so it is important today that we have European solidarity to accompany the just transition, in Poland and everywhere else in Europe, but especially at home. So do not lend me false intentions: I support this transition plan precisely because it allows no one to be left at the edge of the road throughout Europe and especially in the countries that need it most, notably Poland.

name: Rasmus ANDRESEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her (Start of speech when micro is switched off) ... must provide answers – for the 50-year-old Polish coal worker, for the 20-year-old Danish climate activist, but also for 26 million EU citizens suffering from asthma. We are pleased about the Fund for a Fair Transition for Coal Regions. But otherwise you haven't changed enough. It is not enough to recycle the old figures. They remain at 25% climate investment and the old draft of the financial framework of Mr Juncker and Mr Oettinger. Let us not deceive ourselves: they are relying primarily on private money, but with private investment alone we will not be able to finance the Green Deal. Corporations such as Siemens or RWE will not ensure that 55-year-old coal workers have a future, that our air will be cleaned again, or that trains will stop even in small towns. We need public investment and we need more revenue of our own for the EU budget. We want Google and Amazon to pay into the EU budget, and we want climate-damaging imports from other countries to be carbon-priced and taxed. Let us work together with the multiannual financial framework, only then will we be successful.

name: Izabela-Helena KLOC
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab For a number of Member States, coal and gas remain the only energy carriers on the road to climate neutrality. I would remind you that the Paris Agreement is based on the principle of using its own resources to achieve the objectives of the Agreement. More addition, it is not possible to maintain energy security without further use of fossil fuels. I would also remind you that the specificity Polish confirmed by the President of the European Commission. We therefore demand, above all, technological and temporary flexibility in the recovery of climate neutrality. For us, climate neutrality will in fact not be possible until 2070.  And now an important example. Experts point out that a rigid climate policy will lead to a massive blackout in Europe as early as 2050. In the immediate event of an imminent threat to the vital interests of states and citizens, is it not legitimate to continue to use coal as a stable fuel to ensure energy security and, consequently, to invest in the modernisation of coal blocks? Already today, Polish coal-fired power plants are saving German citizens in case of less electricity production by windmills.  Dear! In pursuit of climate neutrality, let us be responsible, just and, above all, honest with citizens.

name: Maria da Graça CARVALHO
text: – Madam President, Commissioners, the European Union has rightly taken an ambitious position on climate change and the environment. However, in order to achieve this, we must ensure two essential aspects from the outset. Firstly, that European policies are aligned with these priorities.  Secondly, investments must be equivalent to the ambition of the proposed targets and not be made at the expense of the existing budget cake. Particular attention should be paid to the completion of cross-border energy networks and the development of clean technologies. As regards the transitional fund, it will have to establish a simple and flexible system of State aid. It should adapt to the specific issues of each region and take particular account of those areas where the transition will be more difficult. No sector of the economy should be left behind, let alone those that directly concern people. People should always be at the heart of our strategies.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to welcome the Vice-Presidents of the Commission and thank Mr Timmermans for the reference to my region, Asturias, a region in northern Spain which has been suffering for decades; first, in the 1980s, we faced the necessary adjustment after the oil crisis of the 1970s, and at the moment we are facing a new challenge to respond to the fight against climate change.  In my region, as in all of Europe, we are aware of the need to fight climate change, but we too are, as socialists, that this process must be a balanced, balanced process that guarantees equality for all citizens in Europe. And that is why the Commission's proposal to start negotiating today is very welcome. I would like to thank this proposal for, as I say, to begin discussions, in which there are obviously many issues in the air that we have to define in the legislative process. And I would like to ask the Commission for the same speed to have a border adjustment for carbon as soon as possible.

name: Moritz KÖRNER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I would like to thank the Commission for this proposal for the Green Deal and the Fund for a Fair Transition. We must finally tackle the fight against climate change with courage, optimism, with new ideas, with entrepreneurship, with innovation and not with planned economy, prohibitions and renunciation. Because we will only be able to do this if we actually develop the economy in this direction. And to do this, we must also mobilise private capital, as is intended. We will not succeed if we do not turn it into a business model, if we do not actually mobilise private investment. In order to do this, the European Investment Bank should finally be better equipped. My country, Germany, must finally see this and ensure that it does. However, I would also like to say something that Mr Reil has just said here about the Ruhr area – unfortunately, he is no longer here. But as a Member of Parliament from North Rhine-Westphalia, this is also close to my heart: the Ruhr area is a completely different situation from the one we are currently discussing. In the Ruhr area, coal mining has not been economically possible for decades, and it has been dragged on for decades by subsidies. That is precisely where we should have taken a different approach. People should have been taken into new jobs, into the future much earlier. That is precisely what must happen here, because we can no longer get away with climate change. We really need to create the jobs of the future.

name: Petra DE SUTTER
text: – Madam President, the European Green Deal is the urgent and necessary response of the EU to climate change. It needs to be fair and just. And I want to thank the Commission for including the road map on social Europe in the present communication for that. But, most importantly, it needs to be financed. The Just Transition mechanism is meant to help regions which are having problems in transitioning because they are still very dependent on fossils. I just hope it will not serve to pay off regions which have simply been unwilling to take necessary measures so far, even if they perfectly well could have done so. Vice-Presidents, you are brokering a difficult deal with sometimes unwilling Member States, but do not give up. You will have our full support. Most importantly, and, in conclusion: make the funding conditional. Member States which receive money should deliver. We need phase-out plans and binding national energy and climate plans.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Today we have learned the european Commission's vague and unfortunately very general plans for a just transition fund. The proposed amount is absolutely not sufficient. So will the Just Transition Fund be just by name? Commissioner Timmermans, at a hearing in the Committee on the Environment, when asked about the future of Polish mining regions, said that as the grandson of two miners he knows that he will be hurt. How does this work for a just transition? It cannot, Commissioner, be done at the expense of the workers of the mining regions. It cannot be done at the expense of coal-based economies such as my homeland Poland. One MEP has just praised the European Emissions Trading System, and is it based on a just transition when we have a diverse energy mix? Commissioner, does the Commission have calculations of the costs of climate change? How much will it cost Poland, whose 80% energy mix is based on coal? What resources can we count on? We need time and money, as Poland, to achieve climate neutrality. Ursula von der Leyen said climate policy cannot leave anyone behind. Keep your word.

name: Isabel BENJUMEA BENJUMEA
text: – Madam President, when we talk about the European Green Pact, we must start from an unquestionable concept of the basis. Political agreements reached for environmental protection cannot cause irreparable harm to our economy or to citizens. If political agreements have been reached to achieve full decarbonisation in Europe, it is now up to the Member States to remain competitive and to continue to create opportunities for citizens and businesses. It is therefore logical that the European regions affected by decarbonisation and the inevitable relocation of companies and industries will require countervailing measures. Spain and its mining regions are among them. And I emphasize the case of Spain because it would not be logical for a Member State which has complied with European Union rules in this area to be now affected by the fact that it did its homework. The debate should focus on how and why. The purpose of the Fair Transition Fund is to help regions affected by the forced closure of an economic activity remain competitive. Help them recycle and become and offer their citizens other tools with which to build their future. It should never be a thoroughly lost aid that clears consciences. Let's not seek to buy social peace. In conclusion, these funds must be accompanied by a thorough assessment of their fate, productivity and results. Concrete plans and programmes that bet on training, employment, innovation and otherwise competitive energy search.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, making progress possible, including social progress, is our commitment, and that must now be achieved through the route plan for a more social Europe. Not everything about that route plan is crystal clear yet, but the intention is at least. No one should be left behind. We know that through globalisation, through technology, through energy transition, work is changing and we will therefore have to invest in new jobs with new funds. We need more resources for fair sustainability, for example from the agricultural budget. Employees must be able to earn a fair salary anywhere, anywhere, even if they work through a platform. I therefore expected the Commission, in addition to a proposal on minimum wage, to propose the fair working conditions of platform workers. I am pleased that the Commission has indicated its will to combat climate poverty. It is difficult to do green when you are red, and let us say from here: heads of government and ministers, there are so many plans. Come over the bridge with money, invest in people, also for a social Europe.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: Mr President, the fires in Australia are once again making it painfully clear that action is simply desperately needed against climate change. And the European Green Deal only works if it is also borne by people and companies and if we take their concerns seriously, because there is no point in people being unable to pay their bills or that every year the rules for entrepreneurs change or that innovations cannot become affordable climate solutions.  So I am very much in favour of making clear policy for the longer term and, where necessary, providing financial support. This can indeed be done in the form of loans, or through the European budget. But instead of going straight to the taxpayer and asking for more money, I think we should have the political audacity to see where we can cut back on old priorities and thus free up money in the existing European budget. The same applies to the European Member States. Countries must first ensure that they can make the most of their European funding before they ask for new money. The European Union is simply not an ATM.

name: Caroline ROOSE
text: Madam President, the presentation of the Fair Transition Fund is good news because the transition can only succeed if it is carried out in a fair and social manner. Not all European regions start from the same point. Those with industries that emit a lot of greenhouse gases, such as the coal industry, need a political response and strong support from the European Union. In these regions, polluting activities are often central to the economy, they are an important source of jobs and income. We must not abandon these workers, we must offer them sustainable and secure job opportunities. They need to be trained in new trades to enable them to work in the renewable energy sector or in the circular economy. We must therefore concentrate European support towards the large local communities in the regions which will have to undergo a major transformation in order to achieve the objectives of the Paris Agreements. I would also like to add that it is important to put in place strict conditionality in order to access the resources of the transition fund. For example, it would not be acceptable for the fund to be used to indirectly subsidize other fossil fuels such as gas. The release of this fund is crucial to the success of the European Green Pact, so we will be vigilant about its implementation.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Madam President, sustainable financing is the foundation of the European Green Pact. The initiative to set up the Fair Transition Fund was initially proposed by the ITRE committee, President Buzek and other colleagues, to reduce the socio-economic impact on communities adversely affected by the transition from coal dependence to decarbonisation. As current chairman of the ITRE committee, I stress the importance of adequately supporting the transition of the energy, industrial and digital sector, starting with the 41 regions dependent on coal production, including the Oltenia region and the Jiului Valley in Romania.  We really need adequate financial resources for the transition to the production and use of renewable energy, the development of new economic models, the creation of new jobs and the retraining of existing staff. It is essential that Pillar 1 money is new money, without affecting Cohesion Policy or other programmes.

name: Constanze KREHL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I very much welcome the proposal on the Green Deal and therefore also the proposal on the Fund for a Fair Transition. Yes, we need to give more and additional help to the affected regions. However, two points in the proposal come to me a little too short or too vague. The first point is the question of funding. Beyond the question of whether or not EUR 7.5 billion is enough for the Fair Transition Fund, this must not be old money at the expense of cohesion policy, but we need new, fresh money. We must not harm regions that need our support through the Fair Transition Fund by taking the money away from them. I wish all of us good negotiations on the new MFF, because what the Member States are proposing at the moment still undercuts the Commission's proposal. Secondly, we need a change and an adjustment of state aid rules, because larger companies also need to prepare for this transition and we do not want to support the unemployed first, but want to open up new prospects for employees beforehand.

name: Mauri PEKKARINEN
text: – Mr President, securing the resources of the TRANSITIONAL FUND is a challenging but potential task. In addition to limited new money, it really must be possible to use existing financial instruments, such as the EIB and Invest Europe, for this purpose.  One third of the EU budget is currently spent on regional or cohesion policy. This money, too, without breaking the objectives of cohesion policy, must be able to be used for this purpose, for a sustainable transition. The fund's resources must be allocated primarily to those areas where the abandonment of coal, why not peat, causes the most material and social problems.  The Fund should also finance the renewal of industrial processes into low-carbon and climate-resilient processes. This also requires preventing carbon leakage in European industry.

name: Michael BLOSS
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Timmermans, Mr Dombrovskis, I would like to thank Mr Timmermans for his excellent work and for his excellent work. Real climate protection cannot be done without justice. That is why it is good that you are thinking about this dimension. We must take everyone into the future, invest in new professions; we need a climate-friendly and just Europe as quickly as possible. But what you are presenting so far is not enough. Instead of taking new money into their hands, they want to re-declare old funds. They are promising investment without linking them to the condition of coal phase-out. That must not be allowed to happen! The phase-out of coal must become a condition for the receipt of European funds. But the German Federal Government must also take responsibility. It wants climate protection without providing additional money. That will not work. Climate protection is not free, with flowery words no new European express trains, wind turbines or the cars of tomorrow are being developed and built. We need climate protection and justice, but to do so you and the German Federal Government must be more consistent.

name: Adam JARUBAS
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. We are taking on a great, pioneering global commitment to climate neutrality in the 2050 perspective. This also raises the climate ambitions set for 2030. Such a change will entail a profound transformation of the economy as a whole, not only an energy transition and, consequently, far-reaching social and economic consequences. It is therefore necessary that this transformation be fair. This topic has already been discussed in the recent reform of the ECJ, and is materialising today. We therefore welcome the creation of a fund and a fair transition mechanism. This fund should be aimed primarily at the countries and regions facing the greatest energy transition challenges and which, in proportion to their GDP, will bear the greatest costs. It is pleased that the Fund in the Commission's proposal receives more funding than Parliament has proposed. We believe that the Just Transition Fund will succeed and this will only be the beginning, while in the future the funds will be increased in proportion to the needs. I therefore call for the fund to be given priority if new measures arise, such as the proceeds of carbon duties or charges for access to the common market.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: – Madam President, Mr Vice-Presidents, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating the European Commission for presenting these three documents in a comprehensive strategy at the same time. Climate change creates economic and social inequalities and the European Union must recognise it and act to combat these inequalities. We look forward to their legislative initiatives. The regions of the Union are in different states in terms of CO2 emissions. Member States and regions have been investing unequally in the energy transition. Portugal, for example, is now well positioned in renewable energy because it has prioritised this ambition and has invested here significantly. We must continue to support all regions in the energy transition by promoting the modernisation of their economies and the requalification of people.

name: Pär HOLMGREN
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Of course we need a fair transition. There is a great deal of good in this proposal. It is just a matter of not happening in 25 to 30 years, but actually here and now, in this decade.  There are also a couple of things in the proposal that need to be much, much clearer. Firstly, in the proposal for a fund for a fair transition, there is no real requirement that countries that receive subsidies actually set out the EU's climate targets. Financial support for coal-dependent regions, for example in Poland, must, of course, lead to the decarbonisation of fossil fuels and to a clear transition to renewable energy.  Secondly, and at least as importantly, people must be at the heart of the transition. A fair transition is about creating new jobs and ensuring sustainable development for those people who will eventually lose their current jobs when fossil fuel is phased out. If we do not put people at the heart of climate policy, we will never succeed in the climate change transition, either by 2030 or by 2050.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: –Madam President, i voted in favour of this report. Mr Vice-President of the Commission, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Schwa I would like to express my great satisfaction that we have the Commission's proposal for concrete solutions in terms of supporting those regions that need it most, that we have it on the table. We can discuss it. There were so many ideas that I wouldn't want to refer to any of them. To many, I can say, there will be a very positive attitude of the majority in the European Parliament. We will have time to report, to discuss, also in the trilogy. I wanted to say something general. Namely, the fund is so that our people, those from those regions most at risk, have the conviction that climate neutrality 2050 will be achieved with them, for them, and not somehow next to them or against them. It was originally created for mining regions, because the idea came in Katowice, the capital of COP24, but today with this extension of the fund that we have on the table, we should think about much larger, additional funds. I appeal to the Vice-Presidents to reflect on how these additional measures, not from other policies, could be included in this multiannual budget.

name: Mounir SATOURI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, when we are talking about transitional funds and social justice, I regret Commissioner Schmit's absence. Environmental health, safety at work, protection of public services, housing, the fight against energy insecurity, universal income, reduction in the number of homeless people, all these subjects are the conditions for a just and necessary transition. Across Europe, inequality is worsening. Global warming is accelerating these inequalities and they are helping to strengthen the arguments of the far right and to destabilize our Europe. We expect much more commitment on social justice, and I would like to reaffirm here that we environmentalists expect better and will do everything to make the construction of this social pillar a concrete reality for all our fellow citizens throughout Europe.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Honourable Chair. Europe has decided to respond to climate change, climate change, and this is our green agreement. The Green Deal has a price and we are seeing today and we have a fair development fund in front of us. I support that we are fair, correct to people and that we are helping them because they will come into adversity. We're saving the mining sector in particular. Even in Slovenia, from which I come, we still produce about a third of the electricity from coal or lignite, so it is right that we help these regions.  However, these regions will not be the only ones to pay the price of the Green Deal, so it is right that, in the light of the upcoming financial framework, we should very concretely anticipate the other needs and measures related to new energy infrastructure, the transformation of sectors such as the automotive sector, as well as the rest of the steel sector and the like. It is right that we also do not forget the other policies, so I expect, in the context of the 2016 MFF, that we have the full price of the Green Deal on the table and that we also find quality resources to cover this account.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, Vice-Presidents, I would like to thank the Commissioners for their excellent work and for the work she has We are setting ourselves the right and necessary objectives and we do not yet know whether they are ambitious enough. We also know that there is no single measure that will enable us to achieve these objectives. We need to turn the screws on many construction sites and get more money in our hands. It is therefore important that we know that we need EUR 260 billion a year in new investments. I therefore also welcome the fact that we want to mobilise EUR 1 000 billion over the next ten years. We know that we need to invest more in research in order to achieve technological leadership. It is therefore right that we should create a fund for a fair transition, because there are less-favoured areas. We also know that social problems can arise. If we want to achieve and stabilise social cohesion in this restructuring, we must enforce the social pillar in the European Union. We have a lot of work to do, but we have to face up to this challenge.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Vice-President, I believe that we all agree that we need an energy transition, that we need fewer finite raw materials, that we need more renewable raw materials and that we also need less CO2 emissions. However, I believe that the danger we are running – and many of my fellow Members have also told me this – is that, in the end, we, as the European Union, are the ones who closed the coal mines, which have depopulated rural areas and ultimately contributed to the loss of jobs. And we must not fall into this trap, because a worker who has worked in the coal mine for decades will not care that we create new opportunities. It's not that simple for him. That is why it is essential that we find a forward-looking approach. We must promote biotechnology, we must promote renewable raw materials, and we must ensure that this fund for a fair transition does not become a fund that stands for shutdown, which stands for abandonment and stands for depopulation, but a fund that stands for new technologies, for the future, for biotechnology and, ultimately, for rural landscapes.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The very name of the Fair Transition Fund suggests that resources should be shared effectively, but also fairly. Fair ly, that is, in proportion to the social burden on regions that are free of coal and coal power. And here the map of Europe is very diverse. For historical reasons, it is rarely the misconduct of society, more often the misconduct of the governing. And that's why we have to say wisely about the Green Scound words, "yes, but". Because Europe is not only to be green, but also to be competitive. Because if Europe is to lead the whole world, it must succeed, not fail. This requires a very robust financial shield for many European regions. And this cover is just emerging. For now, it's foggy. If there are convincing specifics, then we will all say "it's the weekend" with one voice.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: I would just like to inform you in good time that I have 35 spontaneous speeches at the moment and that this is not feasible under any circumstances, given the time lag. I will be able to accept a maximum of eight speeches in order to remain halfway on schedule.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: Mr President, Vice-President Timmermans, Vice-President Dombrovskis, thank you for being here today to present the Mechanism for Sustainable Investment and Fair Transition. It is particularly important to bear in mind that, for the Fair Transition Mechanism to succeed, we must immediately define the eligibility criteria in the light of the contribution of coal production to the region's Gross Domestic Product and the speed of removal from coal. In Greece, the government, through its energy and climate plan, has already announced that it is trying to close coal plants by 2023, and yet Greece's energy mix will not come from coal in 2028. Is or is the speed of carbonisation an element of eligibility in the Fair Transition Fund? Vice-President Timmermans, I have heard you refer to the citizens of Western Macedonia. They expect us here in Strasbourg and Brussels to give them a fair perspective. To replace their agony with a viable job. Jobs that suit them, jobs for the industry, jobs for energy. We're waiting for your answers.

name: Edina TÓTH
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European I welcome the Decision of the European Council in December to make the EU climate neutral by 2050. However, it is necessary to be prepared for the fact that this transition will result in significant economic and social change, with high costs and investment needs. Support should be provided for lower-income Member States, in particular the least developed regions and sectors where the transformation will lead to job losses. A fair transition fund should be established in such a way that energy and food prices do not rise as a result. No Member State or region should be left behind. The conditions for a socially just transition must be created. I would like to point out that the creation of a fair transition fund should not be taken away from support for traditional EU policies, such as the Cohesion Fund or the common agricultural policy. This should be done from fresh money from financial resources beyond the Union's multiannual budget. Finally, I would like to draw attention to the fact that the scope of aid cannot be limited to member states where coal deresiction is a major problem.

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: – Dear Mr. Vice President, climate change is a reality and we see this indeed every day and they threaten many parts of Europe, including, among others, my country the Republic of Croatia, and especially our coastal cities such as Zadar, Split, Dubrovnik, which are real gems of historical heritage that definitely need to be protected. However, on the other hand, it is also necessary to take into account those consequences that the transition and the Green Deal will have on our industry, on our society, and in this sense I would emphasize the four principles.  First, when it comes to environmental protection and the Green Agreement, there needs to be a strong and precise assessment of the effects of regulations that need to be based on science, not ideology.  Second, it must be clearly defined how the most deprived will be helped and there is a Just Transition Fund of utmost importance.  Third, the funds to finance the transition must not be at the expense of cohesion. Cohesion is one of the most successful European policies that embodies exactly the principle of solidarity on which the European Union is founded, and that is why it should be preserved in this context.  And fourthly, the rules from which the funds will be financed and to whom and under what criteria the funds will be allocated must be clear and precise, which is unfortunately not the case at the moment.

name: Lídia PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the objectives of the Green Deal are to have a more evolved and healthier Europe, halting the loss of biodiversity and pollution, and to reverse our management of goods and waste with a circular economy while promoting competitiveness and growth. Let us have no doubt that this transition is both an environmental need and an economic opportunity. The European sustainable investment plan is the pillar of investment to build on this ambition, putting around 25% of the entire Community budget at the service of this change. Public and private contributions, the definition of sustainable investments and the promotion of links between investors and new ideas and technologies are part of a strategy to place Europe as a global leader in a sustainable and growing economy. I consider it essential that a strong commitment to renewable energies, in particular solar energy, that this Commission should regard hydrogen as a serious possibility of decarbonisation and mobility and work to solve once and for all the problem of energy connections between the Iberian Peninsula and the rest of Europe.

name: Stelios KYMPOUROPOULOS
text: Mr President, there has been talk for months about the Fair Transition Mechanism and the expectations that exist for it. Today we have heard evidence and that is very optimistic. I would like to remind you that, in Greece, more than 5 000 workers will be affected by the closure of the units in the region of Western Greece and the municipality of Megalopolis. In Greece, we are not content with a simple Grecovery from the outgoing, as everything shows crisis, but we aim for a big Greek green surprise. It is not enough to tell an organisation or region to 'green'. We must show the way and provide the tools, without weakening successful actions aimed at social cohesion. In fact, the Mechanism should be not only a fair but also an effective transition. We must prove to the people who will change jobs that they will not lose their jobs and that there is a not only national or local but also a European project that will safeguard investment, business and human resources in every region.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, in my remote northern England region, in a proud community, generations of men and boys slaved underground, mining for coal, and worked in iron and steel foundries, forging component parts for railways, factory ships and a thousand other products that helped to build our national infrastructure and generate trade, so I know exactly what happens when, with one fell swoop, an industry disappears, with no thought as to what might replace it. In post-industrial Britain, under Thatcher’s government, the skilled ironmasters and steelworkers of County Durham were offered little more than precarious low-paid work on a factory production line, putting potato crisps into packets eight hours a day, five days a week, for example. These men – strong, decent, proud – became broken beings, emasculated, their loss of dignity obvious in their dull eyes and their spreading girth. What a difference it would have made to these men, to my community, if we had had a Just Transition Fund. Decent work confers a sense of dignity, of self-worth.

name: Othmar KARAS
