text: Now I have to say something: you know that we have exceeded the time. Thirty-five people have come forward and every second person I call is not there. We will note this, because otherwise the whole order, also the calls will be confused. We only waste time when I have to constantly ask who is there and who is not there.

name: Susana SOLÍS PÉREZ
text: – Mr President, thank you, Commissioner, for your presentation today. The Fair Transition Fund is essential for European regions to finance decarbonisation. We are talking about EUR 100 billion in ten years and we are very concerned about how these funds will be distributed. You, Mr. Timmermans, during your presentation, appointed the miners of Asturias, my region. But both Asturias and Castilla y León, like Aragon, are regions of Spain that have already closed all their mines, that have already done their homework and are now closing the last coal-dependent thermal power plants. And these regions are suffering a lot in terms of employment and this is greatly affecting the problem of depopulation. That is why what we want to ask of you today is to take into account these regions, the regions that have already done their homework, in this Fair Transitional Fund. Because, as you said, it is about leaving no one behind and it is essential that these regions do not lose more jobs and do not lose more population.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In the trilogy on the soonomy managed to leave an open door for gas and atom, this final regulation. Unfortunately, these activities will only be transition activities. That's how it's written. So I have a question for the Commissioners: how do you understand this transitional for gas and atom? I am a little reassant about what the Head of the EIB said yesterday, because he said that there would be no such axe over those investments that are ongoing, but I would also like to hear your views on this, because I believe that the matter is important. I know that gas is not climate neutral, but it is a certain source of energy and one would have to think positively about it.

name: Marc BOTENGA
text: Mr President, I have looked at the presentation with great interest, but there are a few points that appeal to me. First, if we want a fair transition, the issue of public services is fundamental. However, on public services, you say that you will support the local authorities, but I then wonder why not break with austerity right now: it would allow the public investment that we need to prevent the small stations from closing. Second, the issue of social dumping. If you come out of this chamber and talk to people, the first issue will be social dumping. I see that, in the communication, you are simply promising to apply the current European rules. Do you really think that for people that is enough? I don't think so. Finally, when it comes to employment, you are saying that you are going to support large companies, as I understand it. The problem is that we have been doing this for years. They are given subsidies, they are given aid in exchange for jobs, and what do they do? They pocket and they leave. Why would that change?

name: Antonius MANDERS
text: Mr President, Commissioners, the Green Deal is a huge challenge. Everyone is asking for more money, but I would like to propose that we make it a business model so that in the near future we can turn the Green Deal into a European export product that the European economy can make money from. Promoting a healthy lifestyle is of great importance. Half the population of Europe is 50+, and the other half want it to be very much. It would be good to promote a healthy lifestyle, for example by bringing VAT to 0 on fresh European fruit and vegetables – and not just organic ones – and that we should eat less meat, but european meat. It would then be good to reduce traffic flows, such as commuting, and I would ask the Commission to come up with technical means to make that possible. It would be a very good example if this Parliament were to allow members from Brussels to attend this meeting, so that we would have to drive up and down less and thus set a good example.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, Commissioners, of course, the transition to a neutral economy has been taken on by the Paris Agreement. I am glad, however, that the proposal has come from Parliament and the Commission has appropriated it in order to have a transitional fund. Use the word fair. Obviously we do not know much and I hope, Mr Timmermans, that you will come up with clarifications, because we had the experience of the Juncker Fund, where the criteria were not the best and the funds were concentrated in a few states that had the administrative capacity to write the projects. We really need to have investments, and we need to take into account that investment in low-carbon energy sources is not discriminated against, and then decarbonisation in the energy system helps decarbonise other areas, and i think that impact studies need to be done, as has been said. And I conclude by saying that in everything we decide, we must not forget and take into account the context of each state and that the energy mix is provided for in the Treaty as subsidiarity.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: In the course of the Green Deal, we expect more than 50 Commission initiatives in the near future, so that we will actually have a debate on this issue every plenary week, where the various aspects can still be included in the speeches. (End of spontaneous speeches)

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, very briefly, if we do not limit the increase in temperature to 1.5 degrees, we are no longer masters of our own destiny. Things will get out of control, we will reach tipping points and the effects for humanity will be disastrous. If we do not shape the fourth industrial revolution that is happening right now at breakneck speed, others will shape it for us and I believe that some will be big winners, but many will lose out. So that’s the writing that we see on the wall. If you see writing on the wall, you can react in three ways. You can just ignore it and continue as is – as some seem to advocate here – you can be afraid and hide under the bed – which I would not advocate – or you can start acting. This is what the Commission is doing with the Green Deal. This is what we are doing with the Just Transition Fund. To those who say it’s not enough, you’re right, it isn’t. More efforts will be necessary. But it is a first step in the right direction and any journey starts with a first step. We will start discussing the elements with you in the next months and years so that we get it right. I want to explicitly thank President Buzek for having made this proposal. It’s his idea and we worked on this, and I say this on the day – and he will allow me to say this – that I want just to recall that, exactly one year ago, a courageous mayor, Paweł Adamowicz, my friend, was murdered. He stood for something I believe in, which is freedom, openness and dialogue. I really would like just to mention his name here today because he deserves that and we should never forget him.  Let me end on one thing. Yes, as it was said, I am a grandson of coal miners. That’s right. But I also know the writing is on the wall for coal. There is no future in coal and, if you want to ignore that reality, you can continue subsidising mines for years and years to come, at great expense, but how are you then going to explain to people who suffer from bad air quality that more than 400 000 people in Europe die prematurely because of bad air quality and you do nothing?  Do you really believe that our children and grandchildren are looking forward to a job in a coal mine? I think they’re looking forward to other jobs and the Just Transition Fund should help bring about those other jobs in those regions that in the future will no longer be coal regions.  This is the very idea of what we’re doing and ignoring the writing on the wall – as you do – is not an option. Nor will the British Government do that and I’m absolutely sure that in the future the European Union and the British Government will be working hand in hand to make the Green Deal happen.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Executive Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all, I’d like to thank everyone for this lively and inspiring debate. I think it shows that we share the same goal, the same sense of urgency, and the same aspiration for the economic transformations we are facing to be just and inclusive.  Our target is set. Now we need to work together towards a green and socially sustainable European economy. But we cannot do this alone. We can steer the policy but we need to bring European citizens and businesses along with us. We have the funding to move forward and to make sure that everybody can stay on board. We have enabling rules to guide us through this transition and we have the technical assistance to ensure that there is a strong pipeline of sustainable projects.  Coming back to some of the questions which were raised in today’s debate, there were many questions raised on the overall impact of this green transition on the European economy and whether a sustainable European investment fund and the Just Transition Mechanism are enough to deal with this. First of all, I would like to emphasise that our studies are actually showing a moderately positive impact on the economy from transition to the carbon—neutral economy. Yes, there will be jobs which will disappear like the ones in the coal industry, but the green economy will be creating many new jobs. So our task is to take this opportunity, but, at the same time, support the people and regions most affected. That’s why we have the Just Transition Mechanism and the Just Transition Fund, and yes, that’s exactly what the Commission proposed. This was also a question which was raised a number of times. We proposed the Just Transition Fund as fresh money, so EUR 7.5 billion on top of the current MFF proposal. We believe we have everything we need to reach our goal, so let’s work together to make this a reality.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Marek BELKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I represent the Łódź Voivodeship, where the Bełchatów Power Plant is located. It is the world's largest coal-fired power plant producing electricity from lignite. Unfortunately, however, it is also the largest emitter of carbon dioxide in Poland. However, I do not want our partners to look at my country only through the lens of the 'chimney of Europe'. It is therefore with great outrage that I have received the news that my country's government does not intend to take all the measures provided for in the Green Scound roundabout proposed by the European Commission.  We have heard from many European leaders that only countries active in the Green Deal will have access to funds from the Just Transition Fund. Why does the PiS government want to raise money for the restructuring of plants such as Bełchatów or numerous mines in Silesia? Why does he not want to provide fresh air to Poles? However, if the PiS Government were to recoule and understand that an energy transition is essential for Poles and Europe, I ask the Commission to allocate the important resources from this fund to the regions that need them most, namely Belchatów and Silesia.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: in writing. Let us not forget that there are people behind the Ecological Pact. They're always the most important. I'm talking about a silent, invisible killer. Pollution! I am a doctor and I treat people affected by pollution every day. There is a need for a Green Revolution, new public and social health policies applied at European level provided by the Fund for a Just Transition.  We have proposed a mechanism today to allow this. Specifically: 1. ensuring adequate funding based on impact studies; 2. European assistance in the implementation of these projects; 3. priority financing of Romania by the European Investment Bank - the most vulnerable regions (Jiu Valley and Oltenia); 4. the introduction of the European minimum wage; 5. Supplementing the cohesion funds much needed for development. And last but not least, two less expensive but highly effective solutions: 1. the prohibition of deforestation at European level during this mandate. My bill providing for the same is on the agenda of the Chamber of Deputies in the Romanian Parliament and I do not see why it could not be adopted; 2. the introduction of green education at European level. Unity in diversity, the motto of the European Union, must also mean health and solidarity for all European citizens.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. – The green transition will affect all segments of our lives, including transport, one of the sectors facing the greatest challenges. Road, public transport and transport are an integral part of our daily lives, so it is not insignificant what changes these areas will undergo in the coming decades. One of the biggest sufferers of air pollution is the population living in cities and urban areas. The modernisation and decarbonisation of public transport can make a major contribution to solving the problem. The European Union must help the Member States, financially and by other means, to provide citizens with public transport that is clean, easy to access and affordable.  Another important issue is access to alternative fuels throughout the European Union. The development and deployment of alternative clean fuel infrastructure in the Member States is a prerequisite for a fair green transition in the field of road transport. Particular emphasis should be placed on lagging, less developed regions so that the green transition does not lead to new fault lines between less developed and developed regions. Finally, it is important to say that the green transition can only be fair if we do not allow this to be done only at the expense of European citizens and taxpayers. Most of the burden must be made up of the biggest polluters.

name: Cindy FRANSSEN
text: Written. – The proposal for European minimum wages, coupled with a new 'social action plan', is an important step forward. One in ten workers is teetering on the brink of poverty. That figure has been rising for 10 years. In order to regain the confidence of its citizens, Europe must be more than a market. Never before have more people started working in Europe: 241 million. Yet too many workers struggle to make ends meet every month. The low wages and the big difference between EU countries, from EUR 1.62 an hour in Bulgaria to EUR 11.97 an hour in Luxembourg, are pushing millions of working Europeans into poverty, but are also causing resentment about wage competition and social dumping within the European market. A European minimum wage framework should put the social partners first and take account of the situation in each Member State. This means that not every worker in the EU should be subject to the same minimum wage. However, there must be an annual process in the European semester, with the social partners, towards more dignified wages and less inequality within Europe. In this way, Europe is striking two birds with one stone: social dialogue is being strengthened, with respect for national wage-setting and traditions.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. – The Investment Plan for a Sustainable Europe is the financial arm to implement the Green Pact. It is also a response to citizens who demanded a roadmap to make the EU the first climate-neutral bloc. On the other hand, the Fair Transition Fund must stem the greatest impact that the paradigm shift that climate neutrality will require on highly carbon and fossil fuel-dependent regions and industries. The road to climate neutrality is complicated and the Fair Transition Fund is cushioning the difficulties of this change. The Socialists have argued that the transition is fair and does not create any more inequalities, and we will ensure this during the process of implementing all proposals and measures that fall within the Investment Plan for a Sustainable Europe and the Fair Transition Fund. We are aware of the need to mobilize resources to reduce emissions and renew the necessary infrastructure. But above all, we Socialists have a strong commitment to social justice and solidarity with those who face more difficulties, so we will closely monitor the implementation of the Plan and the Fund.

name: Nicolás GONZÁLEZ CASARES
text: in writing. – The ecological transition is a necessity that entails opportunities, but also challenges: regions like mine, with energy-intensive companies, need the European support to change their production model and do it fairly, leaving no one behind. Citizens need certainties that the cost of transition will not be paid by the usual. In Galicia and Spain we know well what we are talking about because we have closed coal mining with great costs: stoppage, loss of productive tissue, depopulation. European solidarity is needed for those who must close their mines now, of course. But also for those of us who face serious consequences for having done so much earlier. Our regions also need investment to relaunch their industry. And fair competition in both the internal market and with third countries. It cannot be that poorer regions end up funding the bill of the transition from coal to rich countries that have not done their homework. We believe in solidarity towards those who need it most. But we cannot afford for this process to open up new gaps. We need a Fair Transition Fund. And justice in his design.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. – The Fair Transition Fund targets nothing less than maintaining social justice in climate protection efforts. This is a big task, and the Commission statement is an important step on the road to res solving it. However, this proposal does not take into account the complexity of the challenge and needs to be improved. Financing a truly socially just transition requires more ambitious financial instruments. The Fair Transition Fund is not suitable for this in the proposal. The lack of adequate support can lead to a sharp increase in consumer energy prices, which is unacceptable to me. Transfering financial instruments from the Structural Funds to climate protection also goes against the principle of fairness. In this spirit, the source of the Fair Transition Fund allocation should be outside these.  It is also worth reviewing the level of mandatory national co-financing included in the proposal. Finally, in the current situation, we do not have the luxury of favouring certain technologies and stigmatising others. For a successful transition, we need all the low-carbon solutions without exception. Nuclear energy should therefore also be made available for financial support as a cheap, zero-emission and safe source of energy.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Union has set itself very ambitious climate targets, and I believe that today almost no one is questioning the need to take action to stop climate change. However, it should be borne in mind that the burden of achieving these objectives is radically different for individual regions and therefore some of them require additional support. I am therefore pleased that the European Commission has come up with a proposal to create a fair transition mechanism. However, it is fundamental that the creation of this mechanism should be based on the principle of 'new objectives – new money'. I would therefore like to know what the source of the EUR 7.5 billion proposed by the Commission for the Just Transition Fund is to be. I would stress, however, that cohesion policy, of which this fund is to be a part, is the most important investment policy of the European Union and its future must under no circumstances be jeopardised.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: Writing. – The EU sets ambitious targets for combating climate change and achieving climate neutrality by 2050. One trillion euros over the next ten years could be channelled to finance the transition to the green economy and mitigate the social consequences associated with it. Funding is expected to come not only from the EU budget, but also from private funds and loans guaranteed by the European Investment Bank (EIB). The Commission wants EU countries to provide €7.5 billion of fresh money to the next EU budget to finance the Fair Transition Fund. The MFF discussion is currently going very hard. But in order to receive this money, countries will have to balance each euro with €1.50 to €3 of cohesion funding, as well as provide money from national budgets. This is, of course, not at peace in the countries of Central Eastern Europe, which are the largest beneficiaries of EU cohesion funds. They also consider that they should be additional resources rather than reda breakdowns from existing funding. Net contributors, on the other hand, also do not perceive this initiative with great enthusiasm: they are generally in favour of spending more money on the EU budget to combat climate change, but are reluctant to pay more bill at the bloc's box office, while poorer countries want generous aid. It is an extremely difficult task for all of us to agree on a budget, to work together and to implement the climate targets that have been set.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. – I welcome the fact that, after more than two years, the European Parliament's proposal to set up a Fund for the Fair Transition of Mining Areas is being implemented by the European Commission.  It is a first step and it is good that we have work to start to protect the most vulnerable citizens from the changes brought about by the shift to climate neutrality.  However, the European Commission's proposal will need to be considerably improved by the European Parliament.  I believe that the most critical issue is the financial overlap between the Fair Transition Fund and Cohesion Policy. Although the EC has announced a budget of EUR 7.5 billion for this fund, in fact the EC is based on cohesion policy funds. The EC proposal to transfer between 1.5 and 3 times more funds from ERDF and ESF+ programmes than the allocation to the Fair Transition Fund disadvantages exactly the least developed regions in the EU and which will also suffer the most, as is the case with Oltenia.

name: Manuel PIZARRO
text: in writing. – The history of Europe and the world is marked by changes in the development model that have generated wealth and employment, but have also resulted in the disappearance of millions of jobs, social exclusion and marginalisation. Over the past few decades, the expansion and improvement of the European social model has been essential to mitigate the negative impacts of these structural transformations on people's lives. For the first time in history, the drama of climate change makes the next change in the development model - from a fossil fuel-based economy to a decarbonised and sustainable economy - an inevitable and scheduled change. That is why the European Union's duty is to create mechanisms that reduce to a minimum the negative impact that the environmental and climate transition will have on regions and sectors most dependent on high-carbon activities. The Fair Transition Fund, the Investment Plan for a Sustainable Europe and the European Pillar of Social Rights are an important triad of people to ensure that the European Union of the future is a social and sustainable Union capable of breaking the old cycle which, with every new leap in the development model, created winners and losers.

name: Rovana PLUMB
text: in writing. – Our citizens urge for immediate action on climate emergency. Having people at heard of transition is the responsible way forward to a net-zero greenhouse gas economy. For that, we need innovative solutions, good cooperation between the EU, the Member States and the local and regional authorities. This will have a transformative impact over all the European economy as well the lifestyle, including of the consumption habits – climate neutral in order that no one is left behind. A just and fair transition policy framework and a sustainable investment plan with a visible positive impact on employment will create the conditions to better align EU climate targets for 2030 and 2050. The Just Transition Fund, composed by private and public money, should approach the problems facing workers in regions that are economically dependent on the sectors in the frontline of decarbonisation. This means providing technical assistance and supporting all efforts to transform these economies and diversify their industries. Regional development based on a carefully planned restructuring process, to which renewable energy plays central role, will create also new employment opportunities. Just Transition is not just another transition, it is a new revolution!

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Writing. – The ambitious goals of the European Green Deal and the Funds for a Fair Transition are out of the question – climate neutrality by 2050, making the EU economy more sustainable and society fairer and more prosperous are ambitious goals and the pillars that underpin the Green Deal. However, these pillars need to be improved and further strengthened: the distribution of wealth in Europe is falling further and further apart. One in ten workers in the EU is at risk of poverty! And yet the Sustainable Development Goals are not being pursued ambitiously. And we know that the key to social peace and stability is social inclusion and justice! A magical polygon that combines ecological, social, and economic indicators must form the basis of the New Green Deal. The first pillar – the financing of the European Green Deal – must be strengthened so that additional financial resources, including a fair tax policy, as well as a higher contribution from the EU budget and a 'golden rule' for public investment, must be considered in order to manage the changeover fairly for all!

name: Andrey SLABAKOV
text: in writing. – I am impressed by the statements here today. Indeed, they are in tune with the Commission's Green Deal - they are only wishes, as in a bad Christmas card. "We promise everything without knowing how to achieve it." You put the donkey in front of the wagon. You propose measures that guess what the economic effect of the transition will be.  You promise more than €7 billion to take care of those whose jobs will be closed. Not because there's no job, but because a political decision has been made. And where will those billions come from? With taxes, of course. Taken from those who have just been out of work. Let's not be fooled, this is about the whole of Europe, which relies on fossil fuels and heavy industries. The level of green energy and economy technologies cannot compensate for this volume at all. The Green deal and its supporters behave like young Bolsheviks who believe unreservedly that from miners they can make computer specialists in six months. We are here to solve the problems of European citizens, not to create new ones! Thank you!

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Iran and Iraq following the recent escalation (2020/2506 (RSP)."

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, first of all, let me thank this Parliament for its ongoing concern about the situation in the two countries that feature in this debate, as well as in the wider region. It’s not an understatement to say that the recent tensions in Iraq and in the surrounding region have the potential to erase the hard-won progress of recent years, thereby affecting the lives of millions of people.  Allow me to begin this debate by stating one thing very clearly. I am committed, as High Representative, and, as the European Union, we are all committed to working to stop the current cycle of violence in Iraq, which must cease before it spirals out of control once again.  This is also why I convened an extraordinary Foreign Affairs Ministers Council on Friday – coming back from Croatia sooner than expected – from which I received a strong mandate to carry out all necessary diplomatic efforts to contribute to de—escalation in the region, support political dialogue and promote a political regional solution. These are the precise words of the conclusions of the Council. The President of the European Council and the President of the European Commission have also been fully engaged in these de—escalation efforts and this is how it should be. During the past six weeks – in fact already since last year – we have seen an increasing escalation of tension in Iraq, which culminated in the killing of Iranian General Soleimani by a US drone attack, followed by attacks by Iran against bases in Iraq housing troops fighting Daesh, which thankfully did not harm anyone. While it may appear as if, for the moment, the current situation will not escalate further, we, and I personally, have since the very beginning of this crisis been active in urging calm, restraint and de—escalation to all of the relevant parties inside and outside the region, from Iran to Iraq, the UAE, the United States, Turkey, Russia, China and others. We want to ensure that everyone with influence uses this influence to good effect and that we reach a temporary calm. Why are we so concerned about the current crisis and how it can affect the region? Well, the current situation in Iraq and the risk of further military escalation could jeopardise the substantial achievement in stability and, in particular, the fight against Daesh in recent years. The current situation could generate a number of dangerous consequences. The resumption of Daesh would have a catastrophic humanitarian impact, possibly leading to a dramatic increase in the number of displaced persons. We must avoid that at all costs. For this to occur, preserving the achievements the global coalition has won collectively in the fight against Daesh is imperative. Such a situation would also risk diverting attention from the necessary political reforms that Iraq must undertake, starting with government formation – there is still a caretaker government – and the need to tackle essential social challenges, including fighting corruption.  We have already invested significantly in Iraqi stability, reconstruction and development with the financial support of more than EUR 1.2 billion since 2014. This has focused on humanitarian aid, support for internally displaced persons, stabilisation in the liberated areas, civilian security sector reform through the CSDP EU assistance mission and supporting good governance and job creation.  We need to make sure, with our continued support, that the reforms legitimately demanded by the Iraqi citizens are delivered promptly, also bearing in mind the global commitments taken in Kuwait in February 2018 at the reconstruction conference held there. On this the EU is fully delivering on the pledges we made, with over EUR 400 million mobilised in the last two years to support governance reforms and promote sustainable job creation. The situation in Iran is also something that we continue to follow closely. We have had a number of tragic incidents, such as the Ukraine International Airlines plane crash on 8 January with 176 people on board, including a high number of EU citizens. Iran has now taken responsibility for this crash. As I said in my statement on 11 January, this was a deplorable tragedy and, once again, I want to send my condolences to the victims’ families. We expect that Iran will continue to cooperate fully and undertake a comprehensive and transparent investigation. In the same week, 59 people died in a stampede during the funeral ceremonies for General Soleimani on 6 January, and 20 individuals lost their lives on 9 January in a bus accident close to Tehran. In this case also, I convey my deepest condolences to all of them.  In the current tense situation, it is more important than ever to keep hold of the instruments that are serving to promote security and, in this context, the JCPOA remains crucial for non—proliferation purposes. A failure to preserve the deal will only add to tensions in the region. Imagine for a second what the situation would be today if Iran had nuclear weapons – and without the JCPOA they would have been able to obtain those.  On 5 January, Iran announced its fifth and, according to its own announcement, final step in the reduction of its nuclear commitments under the deal. This is a worrisome announcement, but it is important to see what the International Atomic Energy Agency reports on how Iran implements this step. As coordinator of the JCPOA, I have been in touch with all the participants on the diplomatic way forward, seeking to preserve unity in the group.  You will have heard that, earlier today, the Foreign Ministers of France, Germany and the United Kingdom invoked paragraph 36, the so-called dispute resolution mechanism, and informed me, in my capacity as coordinator, because they believe that Iran is not meeting its nuclear commitments, referring to the five steps that Iran has taken so far. As coordinator, I will guarantee that the dispute resolution mechanism provides an opportunity to address the issues indicated by France, Germany and the UK and I will oversee this process. I will be in touch with all the participants on the next steps.  I want to underline here that the dispute resolution mechanism is, first and foremost, a process to resolve issues related to the deal’s implementation. The objective of the dispute resolution mechanism will therefore be to find solutions and return to full compliance within the framework of this deal. It is not a matter of imposing sanctions, as some newspapers have been claiming since this morning.  All the remaining participants in the agreement have been clear about their determination to preserve the JCPOA. This unity is crucial and I intend to work hard to preserve it. The European Union position is clear: without this deal, we would lose a crucial element of the international non—proliferation architecture and an important contribution to regional security. A failure to preserve the deal can only add further tensions to the regions.  The time is running out. To reach de—escalation we have to witness this as a broader regional dimension. Tensions in Iraq reflect several of the region’s fractures and have the potential to affect difficult situations elsewhere in the region, from Syria to Lebanon, to Yemen and beyond. In short, the stakes are extremely high for Iraq, for the region as a whole, for the world and, of course, for us. In this context, there have already been calls for months for the European Union to play a bigger role, given that we speak to all – all means all – and we are not, as a group, perceived as having a hidden agenda. Our partners see us as standing for dialogue and peaceful and negotiated resolutions of disputes. As I mentioned at the beginning, last Friday I convened an extraordinary meeting of the Foreign Affairs Council. During the meeting, we once again reaffirmed our call for urgent de-escalation and maximum restraint. We also reaffirmed our steadfast support for Iraq’s unity, independence and territorial integrity, and underlined our commitment to our partnerships with Iraq and to our continued support for the stability and reconstruction of this country. We also underlined our joint determination to preserve the JCPOA, which we strongly believe to be in all our shared interests and the interest of the region for peace and security.  We were also very clear that a durable solution to the ongoing crisis can only be regional and that we would continue to explore the role that the European Union can play in that. So, with the strong backing of the Council and the Commission, I will personally continue to remain engaged in all of these issues, as I said, talking with everybody and travelling everywhere. I am looking forward to working with you to promote safety, security and prosperity in the region, which is strongly and dangerously jeopardised by the latest events.  (Applause)

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr Vice-President, thank you very much for your comments. I share them in essence. We Europeans must play our role as honest brokers in the region even more actively. After the events in Baghdad and Tehran have changed without our intervention in the last few days, we have been able to contribute to de-escalation through a large number of contacts. On the ordered killing of the head of the Qods Brigades, the US Secretary of Defense Mark Esper has issued his technical opinion on the assessment of the specific danger satisfactorion to American persons and facilities. I have nothing to add. In Iraq, the fight against ISIS is not over. For this, too, we need a functioning Iraqi state whose government is not a puppet of Tehran. I would like EU Member States to be able to continue their support for the Iraqi forces within the NATO framework or bilaterally. In this sense, you should also make use of your contacts in Iraq and, above all, thereby help secure our extensive civil reconstruction aid in the long term. In Iran, people are also outraged by the downing of the Ukrainian plane, especially the fact that the regime has taken three days to tell the truth. After all, Iran has now accepted the truth. Russia should take this as an example with regard to the downing of MH17 in eastern Ukraine. But Iran has every reason to make a plea. The best way to express remorse would be to officially re-accept the obligations under the nuclear agreement. This would enable us to finally implement the possibilities of the Instex payment mechanism and to avoid additional sanctions. I hope that we will find a solution to this within the framework of the activated dispute clarification mechanism.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, once again we Europeans are put before a fait accompli. The American administration and Iran are playing with global security and, as the EU, we are faced with the possible security risks. The assassination of Iranian General Soleimani is the latest in a long series of provocations by the United States since the withdrawal from the Iranian nuclear agreement. This has created a very dangerous spiral of instability in the region. It is crucial to support the efforts of the High Representative, to de-escalate tensions and to save the nuclear deal with Iran. This is even more important since the triggering of the dispute resolution mechanism earlier today, but we must also acknowledge the diverging interest with the current US administration and the American withdrawal from the region. This for us can only mean one thing: that the time has come for a realistic debate on Europe’s strategic autonomy to safeguard our own security and interests. We offer, of course, our condolences to the families of the victims of the Ukraine International Airlines flight and urge the Iranian authorities to allow international observers to undertake a full and transparent investigation. Iran must also refrain from the use of force, as happened during the last weeks, against peaceful demonstrators who took to the streets protesting against the mismanagement and authoritarianism of the regime. Finally, the EU must continue its engagement for unity and democracy in Iraq and, if necessary, step up our support.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Mr High Representative, this debate is, of course, about much more than the elimination of Soleimani. This debate should be about how Europe – and I am talking about the leaders in the Council – is completely absent in the Middle East. The withdrawal of the Americans from Syria, the Russians taking over, the elimination of Soleimani: Europe stood by and looked at it. We keep hearing through the press what our most important ally America is eating. We just have to guess at an exact justification and timing. And when scheduled flights are shot indiscriminately from the air, every European citizen rightly holds their heart.  Mr Borrell, you rightly vehemently support the Iran nuclear deal. Iran must never become a nuclear power and I would like to thank you very much for your rapid position-taking. But this is not enough. Iraq is in danger of falling into new chaos, and IS is in danger of being freed again in that chaos. Mr. Borrell, you are someone with the right gut instinct.  So use that, and make sure that Europe has one voice, a role in the Middle East. If we do not want the Von der Leyen Commission to be the victim of a major migration crisis again, then we must go for it. And you say, "I've been given a mandate." Well, I would very much like to see you on a plane heading for Tehran, towards Washington, to take the European position with one voice, to mediate. Because, you know, European interests do not go hand in hand with the American or the Russian. If there is one person who has to defend European interests, it is you, it is us. Go for it. You have our support.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Mr High Representative. The truth is that American action killing General Soleimani has been about to break throughout the region. Now, right now, it seems clear, that the US administration wants to end what has been a European creation, which is the nuclear agreement with Iran, which is the only one that allows us to keep the region at peace, that there is no nuclear escalation and that, I want to remember, it is the framework that allows us to talk to Iran about human rights. That we all agree that we must do so, but also THE JCPOA is essential to this. We have read today that it has been decided to activate the resolution mechanism. That may have a double reading. Some have probably activated it because they want to take it to the Security Council and kill the deal. But I think we should try to use it as an opportunity to discuss everything. For Iran to fulfill its commitments, but also to talk about reprinted sanctions, which are currently damaging the Iranian population in a very important way and putting the political agreement in check. Therefore, I press you ⸻as I know you are doing⸻ to have the agreement defended with nails and teeth, because it is our neighborhood that is at stake.

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr. President, the international community is legitimately concerned about the recent rise in tensions in Iraq and the region following the attack on the US embassy in Baghdad, the US strike that killed General Soleimani and the tragic deaths of 176 foreign passengers in the conflict killed by an Iranian missile. In this period of tension, which reminds us how Islamist fundamentalism, whether Sunni or Shia, threatens the stability of the world, the European Union has shown its futility in terms of diplomacy, as indeed in defence, and this is normal. Indeed, it is up to the nations to conduct a foreign policy in the service of the interests of their citizens. While I am also pleased that the voice of the European Parliament has not been heard - especially when we read the message of the President of the Subcommittee on Security and Defence, absewards Iran from responsibility for the death of the passengers on the flight to Ukraine - I regret that France's has not been heard. The voice of France should have recalled the three fundamental axes of our diplomacy as a power of balance and mediation: respect for the territorial integrity of States, the fight against Islamist fundamentalism, whether Shia or Sunni - and this fight is broader than fighting terrorism - and finally support for Christian minorities and their protection in this region. , these communities serving as true civilizational bridges with us.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, in addressing the High Representative / Vice-President, let me start from another point. The freezing of funds, a result of the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA), did not improve the lives of ordinary people. Kleptocracy and military build-up prevailed; thus mass demonstrations and a brutal crack-down on protesting Iranians. There were also matters of concern: meddling in the region, financing of terrorism and support of terrorist organisations, and the development of the ballistic missiles programme, not to mention the recent testing of this in terms of middle-range missiles shot on an anti-Daesh basis and the downing of the Ukrainian airplane.  Despite all of this, I also, like yourself, High Representative, hope for de-escalation and I think that triggering the mechanism is the least you can do, and we can do, the least of all things. I hope that we have our other tools as well.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr. President! Basically, I would just like to say one thing today: the people of both countries are not only dissatisfied with their governments, because the economic and social situation is so difficult, brutal violence is being used against demonstrators and they are also afraid of new wars. No, people are also, to a certain extent, fed up with the dirigisme of the West, and if you have been counting this up for about a century, it will prevent the stability and self-determination of the peoples of these countries – first for colonial reasons, later for strategic influence, and what is to come today, we all know for ourselves. America First, I don't think it's just an invention of Donald Trump, we've known that for a long time. And I think it's time to listen to the people who live there in these two countries, to respect them and not to commit political murders and send false solidarity tweets in Persian. Honest compassion is really different. If, for example, the Iraqi Parliament demands that foreign troops be withdrawn, it is a call for independence and a call for finally taking matters into its own hands. We should support this.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, we condemn the United States' attack on Iraq, with victims, among others, iranian and Iraqi military. We denounce the plan by the United States to declare the Middle East NATO territory. The European Union's dangerous involvement, in the context of escalating competition for energy control, is intended to benefit itself. It invokes the same provocative pretexts for justifying wars, such as in Yugoslavia, Syria, Iraq, Libya and Afghanistan, which condemn peoples to refugees and misery. We express our solidarity with the families of the victims of the Air Tragedy with the Ukrainian plane, for which the Iranian Government has a huge responsibility. We stress that the overt support of the Greek government in the policy of the United States and the long-term enormous responsibility of all the Greek governments that have turned Greece into an American-NATO camp put the Greek people at great risk. So the popular struggle to cancel the forthcoming Greece-United States agreement should be intensified, so that the Souda base and all bases can now be closed.

name: Sara SKYTTEDAL
text: – Mr President, Qasem Soleimani was, in every sense of the word, a terrorist and I believe no one at this plenary is mourning. However, it is hard to fully comprehend the potential consequences of the strike. The responses during the upcoming weeks and months will determine which direction this already fragile region will take in the near future. Prior to the strikes, protesters from Beirut to Baghdad filled the streets due to their frustration with the Iranian Islamist regime meddling in their internal affairs, wishing that they could determine their own nation’s destiny. Iraq remains the country most affected by Iranian meddling and it needs our support. Mostly, it needs stability through sovereignty, and as the Chair of the Delegation to Iraq, I would ask you, Mr Borrell, to provide us with details on future EU initiatives regarding Iraq and on how the External Action Service intends to proceed with our current commitments in the region.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: – Mr President, thank you, Mr High Representative, for your words, which I and my group fully share. It is clear that tension must be reduced in the region, that the murder of General Soleimani has been able to have far worse consequences than we have seen. We must try to maintain - as the European Union is trying – the nuclear agreement, which is fundamental to our security. Perhaps, in this perspective, the Instex mechanism would have to be operational in order to trade with Iran beyond the extraterritorial sanctions of the United States. The activation of the dispute resolution mechanism is logical in the context of non-compliance and announcements of future non-compliances, but we cannot forget either that Iran is an authoritarian regime, which has killed protesters and that it funds and sponsors militias in countries such as Iraq, Lebanon, Syria and Yemen. They must (inaudible words) also to Iran to cease these behaviors.

name: Martin HORWOOD
text: – Mr President, I thank Mr Borrell for his statement and echo his words on all the recent lives lost, including those on Flight 752. The E3 initiation of the JCPOA dispute process deserves cautious welcome. Rules-based diplomacy is always better than random insults and threats on Twitter. But was the EU consulted beforehand on this important initiative by three of its own Member States? Can I check that the British Government, in particular, did not play Brexit with Middle East peace by blocking higher level EU involvement? You cannot trust the current British Government to stand up to Trump’s dangerously unpredictable approach to this region, so desperate are they for a US trade deal. Indeed our clueless Prime Minister has just called for the replacement of the current Iran peace deal with a Trump deal, contradicting his own Foreign Secretary, who says the UK is still committed to the JCPOA.  I hope we all are, and that the EU will now play a more active role in de-escalating tensions and particularly encouraging understanding on all sides of the need for parliamentarians and protesters in both Iran and Iraq to have their say, without fear of disproportionate reprisals and response.

name: Hannah NEUMANN
text: – Mr President, the EU should use the dispute resolution mechanism to save the Iran deal, and we urgently need to step up our efforts: mediate between the USA and Iran, include other regional actors and help to further de—escalate the situation. This has been addressed already, so let me add another important aspect. The killing of Soleimani threatened to overshadow the voices of those protesters who had been calling for political reforms in both Iran and Iraq for months. But since Friday, they are back in the streets, despite mounting threats, again and they are even louder. And I also want to see EU action on this – to protect them from violence and killing, to fill the void that a withdrawal of US forces would leave in Iraq and to use all diplomatic ways to send a clear message to the Iranian regime. Yes, we need to deal with the big power politics, but there will never be peace in the region if the voices of those in the streets are silenced once more.

name: Jaak MADISON
text: – Mr President, first of all I want to thank the previous speaker because she told us very serious things, but they are true. We have to understand that the Islamic regime has been very totalitarian and hardly Islamic for the last 40 years, so we have tried to negotiate with Iran for several years to protect human rights, rule of law, all our values that we are promoting all the time, but as we have seen it is not very successful. And now, if the Americans have eliminated one of the leading guys from Iran who was responsible for paying for terrorist organisations, for murders, for attacks in Israel, in Yemen and Lebanon, I’m hearing a lot of Europeans saying, ‘Oh, it is unacceptable, we have to punish the Americans for that’.  We have to remember that the Americans in this case are our allies, so in this case there is a very simple question: do we show up to support the Americans, to hold stability? And in the first week we see it has been successful because Iran has been afraid of America. We should support them more. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: blue-card question. – So I would like to ask you, when there is no state of war, killing somebody – an official of one country in another country – is against international law. Are you in favour of respecting international law or not?

name: Jaak MADISON
text: blue-card answer. – (Start of speech off mic) […] Is it against foreign international law if you eliminate one of the leading terrorists? Is it really breaking international law? I don’t think so. In Baghdad there were attacks against the US embassy. That is an attack against a country and Iran has never said that they were not responsible for these attacks. So if I speak now about international law, I would say that they were exactly following international law, protecting their own country in Baghdad where they were allowed to be.

name: Assita KANKO
text: – Mr President, the Iran crisis is the first test of the new geopolitical Commission. The jury is out on whether it has passed. We all agree that General Soleimani will be missed as much as toothache. His death came after years of brutal action and weeks of Iranian escalation. However, since his death, the United States has probably avoided a war through chance rather than through strategy. The EU was right to seek de—escalation and to push the Iranian response to be limited. Unfortunately, 176 innocent people became victims of this situation. The EU’s role right now is critical. While Europe’s actions must never be driven by Iranian intimidation, we should continue to de—escalate, we should get Iran back to the table and prevent its nuclear ambitions and work with Iraq to maintain the anti—ISIS coalition. We have stepped back from the brink of war but getting everyone around the table will require solid European leadership, and I’m not seeing it right now.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Mr President, the crazy decision of the US to carry out the illegal assassination of Qasem Soleimani and Abu Mahdi al-Muhandis, and others, is just the most recent testament to the fact that the US is the most reckless, destabilising and dangerous political and military force on the planet at the moment. The US and their allies claim to be fighting a war on terror whenever they drop bombs and kill people. Here they have taken out some of the people who have done more to fight ISIS than anyone else that we know. They have been asked to get out of Iraq, are they going to get out of it? Are they going to recognise the democratic decision? They claim to have brought democracy to Iraq; are they going to respect it now? Commissioner, do you not agree that this region will be a safer place when the Americans are not in it? You talk about Iran not respecting the nuclear agreements; do you ever ask any questions of Israel? What in God’s name, why won’t Europe show a bit of courage and stand up to the terrorism of America?

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the New Year has opened with a crisis with potentially dramatic implications. The targeted killing by the Pentagon of General Soleimani, a senior Iranian official and likely heir to Ayatollah Khomeini, was unilateral, irresponsible and illegal from the point of view of international law, which was, moreover, carried out within the territory of a third state, Iraq. Nevertheless, to think that behind Trump's action there is no well-defined strategy is as erroneous as it is naïve: it is a muscular, unscrupulous strategy, based on balance of power and therefore aimed at meeting American strategic objectives. What can be our European role in the face of an agenda that intends to bend the Iranian Government through targeted force actions and a massive use of economic sanctions, which are bringing the Iranian people to their knees? Given Tehran's considered military response, we have an important window of opportunity for negotiation. I believe that, as a Union, we must respond positively to Mr Zarif's openness, by increasingly defending the role of mediators in a clear, transparent and balanced way, champions of multilateralism, starting from the nuclear agreement in order to extend it and, if necessary, strongly defend its essence.

name: Radosław SIKORSKI
text: – Mr President, I rather side with those who think that the United States was within its rights to eliminate General Soleimani, who was an unashamed organiser of terror all over the region for many years. In fact, General Soleimani is the embodiment of the problem that we have with Iran, namely that it is both a country and a cause; a cause of spreading the 20th century’s third utopia, which is to say theocracy. This is the problem that we have with Iran: while we sometimes have to deal with the regime, its nature prevents Iran from becoming like a normal responsible stakeholder. The Iranian people are protesting again, they would like to live in a normal country. Yes, we should do whatever we can to help, but we should not exaggerate what we can do for them. Because there is very little we can do, particularly when we act on a national basis. This is a high-stakes game. In the short term at least, it looks like President Trump has prevailed, but it needs a united approach from all of Europe and a loyal support for you, High Representative, of the Member States.

name: Sven MIKSER
text: – Mr President, over the past two years we have seen Iran and the US climb up a very dangerous ladder of escalation that has led to the killing of Soleimani and the downing by Iran of the Ukrainian airliner. I want to make two points here. First, no one can deny that Soleimani played a hugely destructive role in the region and, indeed, had the blood of innocent people on his hands. And second, I do believe that Europe needs a US that is fully engaged in international affairs and is ready to take on tyrants and bullies on the global scene. However, I believe it is also absolutely critical that the US play that global role in a responsible manner fully consistent with international law and international norms. Moreover, when it takes action that is bound to have such monumental consequences, these actions had better be part of a comprehensive and realistic strategy. Another violent conflict spiralling out of control in a region that is already turbulent and unstable is the very last thing we need. We as the EU need to fully use what few levers we have at our disposal to de-escalate this extremely explosive situation. And we should put our confidence in the efforts of the High Representative to work towards that end, including by trying to keep the JCPOA alive.

name: Nathalie LOISEAU
text: Madam President, for decades Iran has been at the heart of the crises in the Middle East, but in recent months the tension has increased considerably and it is difficult to see the way out of the crisis. Faced with an Iranian regime that seems most concerned about its survival, whatever the cost, the US policy of maximum pressure has not made the region safer. The Vienna agreement is broken down, the war in Yemen continues, the discontent of the peoples in Iraq as in Iran is facing brutal repression, Lebanon is in turmoil. It's time to get back to diplomacy. It is time for Europe to make its voice heard, the voice of reason, and to recall what its priorities are: nuclear non-proliferation and the fight against Daesh, which are left behind by the current crisis.  These priorities, we all share, so let us act and cease to watch helplessly a powder keg on our doorstep. We are counting on you, High Representative.

name: Catherine ROWETT
text: – Madam President, as Aristotle recognised, we can be blamed only for what is up to us. But what exactly is up to us? The unfolding situation in Iran invites us to reflect on this puzzle. Once again, Ukraine finds itself the tragic recipient of collateral damage that was hardly foreseeable, but how enthusiastically should we side with the citizens of Iran challenging their regime and its military and holding them responsible for targeting a passenger plane? For sure, human error might seem like a partial excuse, but equally, human error could, and should, have been foreseen and precautions taken. On the other hand, some actions are neither accidental nor excusable, and where aggression precedes self-defence we should not hesitate to apportion blame, especially if the perpetrator was once our ally. The obligation for de-escalating a crisis must fall to the aggressor and not just to those tempted to retaliate.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: Madam President, I have no particular sympathy for the Iraqi regime overthrown in 2003, nor for the Iranian regime today, but it is clear that the West today bears a terrible responsibility in the chaos that the United States, with the support of the majority of European countries, triggered by overthrowing the Iraqi regime in 2003, citing what was not yet known as the news. , so-called weapons of mass destruction. It is clear that today, by denouncing the nuclear agreement with Iran, when there was no proof that the agreement was not being respected, the United States has opened a new period of uncertainty. In this new period of uncertainty, Europe is once again proving incapable of pursuing an independent policy. How can we ask Iran to comply with its obligations under the Vienna agreement, when sanctions are still hanging over Iran and severely on its people? If you want de-escalation, then let us put in place a real system that allows Europe to trade with that country and divert sanctions. If you want de-escalation, then the United States respects the vote of the Iraqi Parliament and withdraws from that territory. There is worse than dictatorship, there is anarchy: this is what we have installed in this region. We are paying the price today by collecting Islamist terrorism.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, we see Iranians protesting against a theocratic dictatorship that murders their own people, just as we have seen previous generations of Iranians protest against the dictatorship of the former Shah. We must hear this call for freedom. And we are also seeing an ayatollah regime that seeks regional hegemony, to reverse the balance of power throughout the region, to create a corridor from Tehran to the Mediterranean sea by taking over Iraq, Syria, and Lebanon. General Suleimani was the military face of this strategy. And these ambitions threaten Iran's very security. It is time to put an end to this, it is time to abandon the policy of appeasement, it is time to abandon Mrs Mogherini's policy, it is time to toughen up on Iran and refer it to the appropriate limits.

name: Pernando BARRENA ARZA
text: – Madam President, the political assassination of General Soleimani by the United States has led to a spiral of violence, not only in Iran and Iraq but throughout the region, and has us given rise to what we might call a new kind of cold war, including those proxy wars that some world powers are willing to play in the area as well. We would urge the Commission and this Parliament to support and facilitate with resources the dialogue and economic recovery of the area through an assistance programme and we would like to stress that we must escape calls to the embargo, which historically have only served to punish the most unprotected social sectors, and we also believe that economic activity with Iraq and the countries of the area must be promoted. We must urge the United States and European countries that also have troops in Iraq to withdraw, as required by the Iraqi Parliament, and to ask for respect for international legality, flagrantly violated by the assassination of General Soleimani. This process of economic and democratic take-off of the area it appointed must be done without external interference and respecting human rights and this ⸻ththing⸻ requires ending all kinds of interventionism, American but also European. (He agreed to answer a question posed in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Isabel BENJUMEA BENJUMEA
text: "blue card" question. – Madam President, Mr Barrena, sitting here, is a gentleman who was convicted by the National Hearing in 2016 for belonging to the terrorist gang ETA, a gang that killed more than eight hundred people in Spain, and which has three hundred crimes still unsolved. I ask Mr Barrena whether or not he condemns ETA's terrorism, whether he condemns the violence of ETA, violence of which he was the protagonist as well. I ask you before this Parliament whether or not you condemn it.

name: Pernando BARRENA ARZA
text: "blue card" response. – Mrs Benjumea, I hear you speak and it would seem that nothing has changed in the Basque Country in the last ten years. ETA no longer exists, there is no political violence ⸻less on the Basque side⸻ and society is committed to closing that cycle with the recognition of all victims and the end of incarceration for political reasons. Let me tell you that your position is a long way from understanding and reconciliation. You and your party are still in positions of vengeance, and I invite you to contribute positively to the process of peace and political normalization so that this is a consolidated reality, as Basque society as a whole wishes.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman. The latest developments in Iran and Iraq show all the arrogance, all the arrogance of U.S. foreign policy.  It's arrogant to attack a general in a country you're not at war with. It is arrogant to attack him in a third country, which is why the Iraqi parliament gave a resolution on the departure of foreign soldiers, though non-binding. It's arrogant if civilians had died, America wouldn't be a match. When was America and what was it responsible for? It's arrogant to lie about going on the attack because of the imminent danger of Mike Pompeo to deny that lie herself within days. And why was it done? So to avoid debate in Congress, to avoid debate in Congress.  Also, credibility is not the strong suit of American foreign policy, let's remember WMD (weapons of mass destruction) and George Bush. It's arrogance to condemn Europe for not wanting to help with this attack.  And finally, the pinnacle of arrogance is to say that cultural goods in Iran are legitimate military targets. America has a $650 billion military budget a year and unfortunately they have to use it somewhere and be constantly at war.

name: Andrius KUBILIUS
text: – Madam President, we need to see that Iran and Iraq are part of a broader picture, which is developing in the regions surrounding the EU. We see more totalitarian regimes which are becoming more aggressive or we see more meddling and destabilisation. We see it in the south in Libya and Syria, in the Middle East in Iran and Iraq, and in the north east next to Russia. Some of those regimes imagine that their power is increasing and that the power of the West in the region is diminishing. That feeling is a temptation for them to become more aggressive. We also need to see that the US is diminishing its presence in the region and invites NATO and the EU to be more present. Until now, we in the EU are better at speaking about our strategic autonomy than we are able to show the strength of our real strategic autonomy in the neighbourhood of the EU. This is the way to have more instability and chaos in our neighbourhood. Mr Vice—President, during the hearing procedures in the Committee on Foreign Affairs, you spoke very convincingly, saying that, if the EU wants to be globally significant, it needs to be powerful enough to bring stability to its neighbourhood. It’s time to implement your vision.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: – Madam President, the beginning of this year in the Middle East was marked by the unilateral and irresponsible action of the United States which resulted in the extrajudicial execution of General Soleimani. A monumental mistake in line with the denunciation of the nuclear agreement with Iran. We could ask why and why, but that's not the most urgent.  Iran's seemingly accidental shooting of the Ukrainian plane and the incidents in Iraq have led to growing tensions in the region.  It is now up to the European Union to promote dialogue to ease tensions and defend human rights, and Iran is being called for reforms. The delicacy and geopolitical relevance of the moment do not allow hesitation. I therefore welcome last Friday's decision to strengthen the high representative's mandate and to try to save the nuclear agreement with Iran. This was an agreement that took too long to implement and which is fundamental for the region and for the world. The European Union demands the unity and determination necessary to defend it.

name: Malik AZMANI
text: – Madam President, yes, recent events in Iraq and Iran show us how fragile the stability in the world is, and an escalation is never far away. Moreover, we have to realise that the EU must combine its strengths to protect our global interest. We need to speak more with one voice, backed up with serious military capacities. It’s good that the EU wants to keep the nuclear deal alive, but we also have to warn Iran: the Iranian demonstrators are not to be harmed. As the EU we have to be firm to protect the universal rights of demonstration by Iranian people. And I call upon the High Representative to redouble her efforts in initiating a dialogue between the US and Iran. That’s the only way forward out of this hazardous situation.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: – Madam President, I say to the High Representative: let me start with a note of realism: our European hand is weak in this conflict, our role is small. But if we want to take our responsibility seriously we have to stick together, and we have to coordinate well. And the coordination should be in the hands of the Vice—President / High Representative as it is his responsibility. We want to defend the JCPOA but at the same time, we also must push back very clearly against Iranian aggression in other dimensions of its foreign policy. How can we keep the JCPOA alive? Not if we don’t insist on building the Instrument in Support of Trade Exchanges (INSTEX) and making it functional. And the Commission should join INSTEX and put capital into INSTEX and become a partner. And the last note that I want to strike here is this: there are many dark clouds, there is one signal of hope and that’s the engagement of Iranian citizens, and just recently also Iraqi citizens. And I think it is our duty as the EU to show effective solidarity with them.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her What we are witnessing here, I think, is an ego-acting of both sides, and a dangerous ego spectacle – admittedly. Both sides are essentially pursuing domestic political reasons for behaving, how they behave. In the US, not even the Democrats criticize the killing of this alleged terrorist. In Iran, on the other hand, the regime must ensure that people remain calm on the streets, and on the other hand, of course, it has succeeded in doing so with the attack by the Americans. The bad luck that the Iranians have had in the meantime is that they allegedly unknowingly and unintentionally shot down this passenger plane. But what do we see? In the US, for example, Trump faces an election in November, and Americans love this kind of strong hand and love this kind of actionism when it comes to terrorists. We should do the same, because terrorists must be prosecuted with a hard hand. The Iranian regime, on the other hand, needs the solidarity of its people, otherwise this undemocratic regime will not be able to be sustained for long. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Mayer, I would like to thank Mr Mayer for his You have just spoken of 'bad luck' in connection with the downing of the Ukrainian aircraft. Are you prepared to apologise to the civilian victims and to this House for this use of words? You cannot call such an act bad luck, it is extremely cynical.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Bütikofer, I would like to thank Mr Bütikofer for his excellent You might want to learn to listen in a meaningful way. Because the bad luck or, let's say, the misfortune, iran has claimed that it was a random firing. So the bad luck. So please do not instrumentalise the sacrifices for your cheap little one.

name: Beata KEMPA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The situation is serious, but it is not that we have to shout here in Parliament about arrogance, about ignorance, as we have done so far. This level of debate is not encouraging. The European Union has a lot of instruments, it has a lot of opportunities, not only diplomatic, but also opportunities for not only humanitarian aid, but also development. This situation shows that it is, to put it mildly, very irresponsible to focus primarily on Iraq and to call for military missions, particularly NATO and allies, to leave the country. This country needs help and stability. After the war with the Islamic State, this situation is still very difficult. We have talked a lot here in Parliament, you have talked about the situation of the Jezyds in the previous parliamentary term and you have adopted resolutions on this subject. The situation of Christians is also difficult. In this situation, if there are troops that are demining the Sinjar Mountains, where the Jezydzi are to return, talking about withdrawing these troops, supporting such resolutions, resolutions, is simply out of place. I also think that this is a great task for the European Union, because Russia has a very large influence in the Middle East.

name: Marc BOTENGA
text: Madam President, Donald Trump, the President of the United States, is scary and first and foremost of our fellow citizens in Europe. Do you realize that on Twitter, the hashtag #troisième World War was a trend for four days? And you can't condemn the illegal actions of this American president? Frankly, I don't understand. In addition, I hear calls for Europe to do more. You are aware that European states have intervened in Iraq, Afghanistan, Syria and Libya. Have you seen the success that it is, or rather the disaster that it is? Want more of that, more disaster? Let's be a little serious, you lived on which planet? If you really want to reassure our fellow citizens, let us take it from NATO, which leads us into this warlike logic of Trump. If you want to help the Iraqis, let us respect the decision of their parliament to demand that foreign troops leave the country. And finally, if you want to help the Iranians, stop the sanctions against this country that destroy the health, the economy and the social rights of these people.

name: Matthew PATTEN
text: – Madam President, before Christmas I told this Parliament that the nuclear agreement with Iran, the JCPOA, was dead and we urgently needed a plan B. Mr Borrell, High Representative, it gives me no pleasure to say this but it is true, and the EU needs to wake up. The JCPOA is not sustaining peace and security. it is now starting to do the opposite. America has left the agreement, Iran has restarted its uranium centrifuges, Germany, France and the UK have triggered the dispute mechanism, Iran has threatened reprisals against EU Members. The only way to keep nuclear weapons out of Iran, restore trade, free political prisoners and support human rights is to restore friendships in Washington, not Tehran. As well as turning the centrifuges off and thinking again about human rights, plan B has to include Iran’s agreement to stop supporting its proxy attacks against the US. Then, in return, the EU can do what it does best, namely trade. The EU needs to recognise that only the US has the resource, the relationships and the firepower to underpin the successful alternative to the JCPOA and peace in the region.

name: Tomas TOBÉ
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for High Representative! Last Wednesday, Iran shot down a Ukrainian passenger plane. All 176 people on board perished. Our thoughts go out to the victims and their families at this difficult time. Seventeen of those killed were residents of my country, Sweden.  I assume that the EU will more strongly condemn the attack and demand that the shooting be thoroughly investigated in full international transparency – particularly from the countries affected – and that those responsible be brought to justice. The relatives have the right to know what happened, and they are entitled to compensation.  And let me also be clear: now that the protests against the regime in Iran are spreading in the country, the EUROPEAN Union needs to support its democratic forces and reforms more resolutely.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for High Representative! The security situation in Iran and Iraq is changing from day to day, and it is now weighing between serious conflict and full-scale war.  The relationship between the US and Iran is extremely serious, and the European Union must play a clear role in détente and develop its own policy towards Iran, where we mark that what we want to see is a different future, a peaceful future, a future in which we stand up for democracy and human rights and where we respect the nuclear agreement.  Last week, a plane was accidentally shot down, and 176 people died. There is no denying that it is fundamentally the escalating conflict and the heightened tensions between the US and Iran that are the cause of this tragedy. Seventeen of the people who died were connected to my country and were Swedes, including young people and children.  I agree with the demands that we must demand full transparency in the investigation. The Member States concerned must be given this transparency. The relatives must know exactly what has happened, be entitled to compensation and know that we are on their side in the terrible grief that has befallen them.

name: Luisa PORRITT
text: – Madam President, I say to Commissioner Borrell: amid ongoing tensions between Iran, the US and the UK, the EU must step up as a mediator. Any discussions you have with your Iranian counterpart should prioritise the protection of EU citizens.
