A number of EU nationals are being held illegally in Iran, including my constituent, Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe, who has spent almost four years in prison. Her treatment is part of a pattern of hostage diplomacy by Iran and must be taken seriously. Nazanin’s husband, Richard, is here at Parliament today and tomorrow, and I am urging you to accept my invitation to meet with the two of us. He and the other families of unlawfully detained EU citizens want to see you put their loved ones first. Human rights cannot simply be a ‘nice to have’, they are non-negotiable. It must be safe to travel, and this has to form part of any current or future agreement worked out with Iran.

name: Markéta GREGOROVÁ
text: – Madam President, the Iranian regime has killed peaceful protesters and is supporting violent terrorist groups in its neighbourhood. That is undisputed. Oppressing one’s citizens and funding terror groups cannot come without international consequences. If history is a guide, the US strategy of regime change – we currently see it unfold – will not, however, change that. Libya, Iraq, Afghanistan: the list of failed interventions goes on. Regime change via military action is the worst possible choice. We Europeans must make this clear to our American counterparts. Hellfire missiles do not stabilise regions, diplomatic dialogue and enforceable economic and security agreements do. Mr Borrell, make this clear to the United States: Europeans will not support military intervention in Iran. We support peaceful protesters and we support economic and security cooperation with Iran, based on human rights and freedoms.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, europe has shown itself to be disunited over the crisis between the United States and Iran and the violence in Iraq. Sometimes he even expressed positions close to Iran, just to spite Trump. We have arrived at the paradox: for days General Soleimani has been sanctified as a hero in Europe too, and instead we have seen total silence in the face of the shooting down of a civilian aircraft that killed 176 people. Let us remember that the crisis stems from iran's assault on the US Embassy in Baghdad. Here we forget the protests against the Iranian regime in recent months: we are talking about 1 500 dead and more than 10 000 injured, thousands of arrests, torture, 100 women hanged, internet access censored, protests obscured in the media. Faced with a violent regime that finances terrorism, we do not need a 'Mogherini model' European Union, which two years ago showed up in Iran wearing a submissive veil without denouncing the dictatorship and hell there. We need clear positions, courage and the return of democracy!

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to Mr Borrell: I was a little bit surprised by your speech because you forgot some things: who first withdrew from the nuclear agreement? Mr Trump. Who assassinated Mr Soleimani? Mr Trump. Who is reinforcing, with the assassinations and these actions, the hardliners in Tehran? Mr Trump.  I have the pleasant privilege to come from a country with the only prime minister in the European Union who supported openly the assassination, besides Mr Johnson and of course Mr Netanyahu. So what I want to say to you is: of course we have to pressure Iran to respect the deal and to give democratic freedoms? But also we have to pressure and criticise the United States, otherwise Mr Trump is taking us for granted, Mr Borrell.

name: Lukas MANDL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Four short thoughts at this minute. The first is: What distinguishes the US from Iran? What is Iran? What is the significance of the nuclear deal for us today? And what can the European Union do? The US is an ancient democracy that works. Iran is a totalitarian regime that is guilty of human rights violations over and over again. I am therefore surprised that this is also equated in this House by the left and right populists. But Iran is also a subject of international law with which we have a treaty, the nuclear deal. The nuclear deal is important in order to prevent Iran from developing nuclear weapons, and right now it offers a dispute settlement mechanism that we must use. We must ensure that the European Union does what the Austrian Foreign Minister, Alexander Schallenberg, has proposed, namely to allow for shuttle diplomacy between the United States and Iran, because speaking is better than shooting. And Vienna is a place for negotiation, and Commissioner Borrell, take this into account and strengthen the effectiveness of the European Union in this matter for our security!

name: Dietmar KÖSTER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Ayatollah dictatorship is primarily responsible for the current situation in the Middle East. The Qods commander Soleimani has planned and carried out many terrorist attacks. He was responsible for violently crushing the protests of courageous Iranians who took to the streets last year for freedom and democracy, as well as for better social and economic policies. The Iranian regime is homophobic and anti-Semitic. The destruction of the State of Israel is his explicit aim. As Europeans, we must resolutely oppose this. The killing of Soleimani is questionable under international law and has increased the risk of war. Peace can only be secured by respect for international law. Now is the time for diplomacy. The nuclear agreement must be saved. The Trump administration must resolve conflicts multilaterally. We stand alongside the demonstrators who risk their lives for a secular Iran and for democracy and human rights.

name: Bernard GUETTA
text: Madam President, before we ask 'what to do?', let us see the new Reality in the Near East. The Iranian regime is now as contested on its soil as in Lebanon and Iraq, and the tragedy of the Ukrainian Boeing has at the same time increased its discredit even within its borders. The decline of this theocracy in turn weakens the Syrian regime and Russia finds itself alone in the Middle East, at a time when it is dispersing in Libya. So what can Europe do? It will not convince Russia, Iran or the United States to change course. Without defence or common diplomacy, it cannot solve this crisis, but it must instead make everyone say that the nuclear compromise must not be allowed to die, to Bashar al-Assad, whom he is running to his death if he does not seek a political compromise, to Russia that if it fails to work towards a regional compromise, it will eventually become bogged down in the Mediterranean.

name: Henrike HAHN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Targeting people is simply barbarism. Destroycultural sites or the threat of them. The killing of General Soleimani is contrary to international law, and this must be made very clear once again. We Europeans have been made peace experts by war experts, especially thanks to the United States. And we know from experience in Europe that politics fails when it leaves out values. International law gives a positive, constructive response to make this better, gives international organisations, agreements and treaties, especially in the Middle East conflict, especially now with the JCPOA, the nuclear agreement with Iran. What counts is not America First and not Europe First, what counts is: we all together – together and now. We do not have time to forget what we have long learned, we need peace rooms instead of rooms, we need a common transatlantic, European policy, one that combines strength and resources and reflects on common values, at least on common goals. On geostrategic issues, the environment and the climate, because the clock is ticking on everything, and only together we are strong. This applies to Europe, to the EU and to transatlantic relations. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mrs Hahn, you said that the murder of Soleimani was a barbaric act. Do you think it's too little to liquidate a terrorist? Is he a terrorist, after you, Soleimani or not?

name: Henrike HAHN
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you for your question. I believe that this act is contrary to international law. And I believe that we should not take on the role of a judiciary here in plenary; we are not entitled to do that here. That is something I have always wondered in this discussion today. It is contrary to international law, and this is clearly to be spelled out.

name: Teuvo HAKKARAINEN
text: – Mr President, Iran, led by bigoted lamists, is the biggest threat in the region. Over the years, Iran has spread its soldiers, practically its sister armies, across the Middle East, causing chaos and destruction. Iran has two major objectives: the development of a nuclear weapon, which the country has never abandoned, and the ultimate destruction of Israel. For this reason, the threshold for using a nuclear weapon is lowest in the Middle East.  Israel, the only democracy in the Middle East, will certainly not be left with its arms crossed waiting for its destruction. The wisest thing to do would probably be for Europe to be able to do nothing about the current situation. I just don't think that's possible. When the oil sometimes runs out of those areas, we are facing a transition to the camel season.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Madam President, during the first week of the new year we all experienced an unexpected chain of events that strongly increased tensions in the Middle East and far beyond with around 3 000 soldiers from 19 European Member States deployed in Iraq. The events also affect the security of the European Union directly. The situation in Iraq and in Iran is highly worrisome and all peaceful de—escalation efforts should be welcomed. Therefore, I call upon all parties involved to show restraint and make space for dialogue. Next to encouraging and assisting our partners to open diplomatic channels, it is important for the European Union to protect the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action and to convince Iran that it is also in their benefit to adhere to this agreement. Also in our relations with Iraq we should remain stable and productive. After having heavily suffered under the destructive passage of ISIS, the country is being reconstructed. Last year I was there with the Committee on Foreign Affairs in Baghdad and it’s really making me feel sad to see how all the fragile peace is gone. We should help through diplomatic channels and I call upon you, High Representative, to make the utmost effort and to show the European Union as a mediator in this really worrisome situation.

name: Jackie JONES
text: – Madam President, yet again, Donald Trump’s lack of forethought and sketchy understanding of geopolitics has kick—started a dangerous chain of events, following the US air strike which killed General Qasem Soleimani in Iran. Hopes of tensions calming have been dashed by the shooting-down of the Ukrainian passenger plane. And my heart goes out to the families and friends of those who have been killed. These incidents have ignited a tinderbox, and we’ve now seen days of protests and strong language on all sides, including from the UK’s Prime Minister today. The US should not have withdrawn from the Iran nuclear deal. I certainly disagree with Johnson, who wants to replace it with a Trump deal. This situation is highly dangerous. For the sake of the protection of everyone’s human rights across the globe, but especially those who are the most vulnerable – that always includes women and children – we must try to defuse the situation, and I call on you to do so.

name: Klemen GROŠELJ
text: – Honourable Chair. The escalation between Iran and the US could threaten not only regional but also global stability. Whatever the likely or less likely scenarios of the crisis, the European Union's invisibility is going into the eye.  The European Union urgently needs to strengthen its role in resolving the crisis and efforts to maintain the nuclear agreement. Whatever happens, it's going to affect us. With an otherwise unlikely further launch, it will be an important part of the European Union within the reach of Iran's missile systems. At the same time, we will face increased refugee or migration flow at the external borders.  However, even in the event of a tensions easing, especially when talks between the US and Iran are going to take place, the European Union must play an appropriate role in this. Any deal will have an impact on the European Union's energy security, why both the US and Iran want to become important natural gas suppliers.  It will play an important role in achieving our strategic goal – becoming a carbon-free society by 2050. Therefore, the European Union must become an actor who will decisively co-ord solutions in this crisis.

name: Elena LIZZI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Vice-President, the wave of instability triggered by the death of General Soleimani has once again highlighted the inadequacy of the European Union's foreign policies, reducing it to a consortium of goodwill, which is often ineffective and ineffective in the situations that matter. Mr Borrell, it is not about your person or your professionalism, it is about the context in which the European Union must move and therefore the legal framework: the collapsing Iranian economy, the late admission of the downing of the Ukrainian Boeing in which 176 people died, the diplomatic case of the arrest of the British Ambassador. There is a risk of an escalation of further clashes and street demonstrations, with the consequent violent reaction of the regime. Where is the Geopolitical Commission promised by President von der Leyen? How have we tried to limit escalation during these periods? We talked in November about Iraq and Iran. We continue to call for a lower tone, and I do so myself, to use dialogue and diplomacy, to seek a political solution, and I do so too. But then nothing happens and everything results in a joint declaration. President von der Leyen's first note on Soleimani's death came only days later. The European Union is once again in danger of... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The nuclear deal with Iran was a victory for patient diplomacy, the art of what is possible. War, sacrifice, destruction is always a failure of diplomacy. This agreement may have been a pillar of a global non-proliferation strategy built on the simple principle that it is easier to stop someone's armament than to disarm the holder of an atomic bomb. But President Trump, undeterred by his experience with North Korea, has chosen a different path. So the less predictable the Presidency of the United States is, the greater our responsibility for our own security and for the entire region.  I often hear that Iran is a terrorist country. This is a country of 80 million people. A very young society, which I met during the five years when I chaired the European Parliament delegation on Iran. These people want to live their own lives, not necessarily according to the indications of ayatollah. And this is a great reservoir of peaceful cooperation, which should be the strategic goal of our diplomacy.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the de-escalation between Iran and the United States after the very high level of tension over the murder of General Soleimani is good news, but there are still many issues to be resolved. The nuclear agreement has been the greatest achievement of European foreign policy in recent years, bringing the country back into the back of the West's political and commercial partners after years of strained relations. Mr Trump considers him dead, but for us it remains the basis of our improved relations and must be respected, as you rightly said, Mr Solana, on the sidelines of friday's extraordinary Foreign Affairs Council. At the same time, let us not forget the Iranian people, who have been taking to the streets in the first instance for months because of the difficult economic conditions, including american sanctions, and which have so far been severely suppressed. The events of the past few days, including the terrible story of the downed plane, have further aggravated the situation. Tehran will therefore cease the violence and listen to the demands of its people for a path of democratisation and the protection of human rights, which we hope for and which is part of our dialogue with the Iranian authorities.

name: Anna BONFRISCO
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Dear High Representative, a wish is stirred up in the hearts of the Iranians and Iraqis, regardless of ethnic and religious differences and their deplorable authoritarian governments: it takes the name of security, prosperity and peace, and it is the voices of protests such as those in Iran that, since November, often in the indifference of so many of us and the international community, are shouting at it. , have resulted in hundreds and hundreds of deaths. Is this the highest level of confrontation since 1979, and is this the rule of law that we intend to defend? What about the billion and more euros, directly from Europe, which have tried to support these people humanitarianally, where have they ended up, if not in the hands of governments that are puppets of Tehran? Because perhaps soon we will understand that the elimination of Soleimani, the greatest leader of Islamic fundamentalism, will serve to free those who fight for freedom, and we should thank, Mr Solana, those who freed us from the greatest terrorist in the world, against Israel and against us, ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Pierfrancesco MAJORINO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what has happened in Iraq and Iran is serious, worrying and dangerous. As the European Union we must be united and determined, and that is why some things must be said very clearly. The murder of General Soleimani by the United States was an insane act, to be condemned, an unscrupulous act, which strengthens the enemies of democracy.  What we do not have to do today, the mistake we must not make, is to throw out the nuclear agreement. Even more than before, it is important, as the High Representative has pointed out: it is a real test for us. Finally, both in Iraq and in Iran, there is a civil society that demands transparency and democratic development. We must start again from supporting these women and men in order to support the diplomatic and political path and to avoid an escalation that has not yet been averted.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Dear Chairman, first of all I would like to express my condolences to the families of the victims of the victims of the downing of the Ukrainian passenger plane in Iran. It's a tragic reminder of how isolated incidents can compromise general safety.  I support full access to the investigation to investigators of all countries whose nationals are victims of this tragedy. The basic message should be a call for de-escalation of conflicts and refrain from unilateral actions because they have a multiplier impact on regional and global security. The murder of General Soleimani, regardless of his actions related to crimes against numerous victims, opened Pandora's box with unprecedented consequences. The upcoming elections in Iran and the US unfortunately pose an additional challenge. I hope the latest controversy over the withdrawal of U.S. troops from Iraq will not cause more conflict and casualties. Likewise, full support for the Iran nuclear deal implies the realisation of commitments, including INSTEX, especially in the context of humanitarian trade. The European Union needs a proactive policy, proposing diplomatic solutions aimed at iran's compliance with the nuclear deal. This really contributes to peacekeeping and promoting security. Iran certainly needs to stop the violence against protesters that we have been witnessing in recent days.  In conclusion, I believe it is time to discuss transatlantic cooperation in the coming sessions in significantly changed circumstances. It is an indispensable part of the formula for global security and peace.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – Honourable Chair. I have been following the efforts of the Iranian opposition for years, its fight for democracy and its freedom. We have paid some attention to them in the European Parliament, too, but the European Union's high security and foreign policy service has a slightly different attitude towards them. I am convinced that the European Union should be more clear on the side of the Euro-Atlantic alliance, rather than trying to somehow medial between the US and Iran, between the country of democracy and freedom and on the other side of the country, which killed 1,500 people in protests last year, 12,000 of them, and in recent days it has also been very violent against protesters, while attacking American strongholds. , downed a Ukrainian plane and so on. We have nothing here to choose or be an intermediary between the two actors, but I call on Mr Borrell to redefine the European Union's relationship with Iran.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: – Madam President, our aim now really must be to calm the situation and contribute to reducing the tensions that have escalated unilaterally; We must also be able to say critical words to the United States, they are our ally within NATO, but we must act as partners, as credibility, in order to maintain our credibility towards other countries. It is really about making every effort, our capabilities and our good relations, both with the Americans, but also, to a certain extent, good relations with Iran to preserve the nuclear treaty, because putting us at risk, and some further escalation of tensions in this area, or military conflict, would certainly cause further influx of migrants and people. resettled and human rights violations.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, the Iranian regime deserves a full range of sanctions for its bloody actions against its own people who went into the streets to protest, as well as for a war crime which led towards the shooting down of the Ukrainian civil aircraft. The EU should apply effectively a full range of sanctions against the Iranian regime and provide support to the country’s civil society and opposition. Staying silent and inactive, we will promote the Iranian regime to commit further crimes and bring more instability to the region. Let’s admit some mistakes the EU made towards Iran in once having too optimistic expectations and exercise a more comprehensive policy line.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: – Madam President, we must realise here in the European Parliament that international politics is not about cheering in a football match. We don't have to have our favorite to tolerate all fouls and whistle contemptuitfully at his opponent. If we respect the rules and international law in the first place, we must measure everyone by the same meter. We must not be afraid to criticise anyone who violates the rules. The US has clearly violated international law with its recent actions in Iraq. That's non-negotiable. Iran's shooting down of the plane is also a huge foul to be condemned.  We here in the European Parliament are not tasked with loving the US or defending Iran; we are tasked with clearly defining ourselves against violations of international law. 2020 has not started well, and unless confidence in the functioning and validity of international law is restored, it may not even end well. Yes, colleagues, we are at a crossroads, but not between the US and Iran, but between international law and chaos. Let's choose.

name: Milan UHRÍK
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to complain to Parliament's leadership that we have been banned from having flags in plenary, with the bizarre explanation that these are banners. This is really outrageous.  As far as Iran is concerned, it must be acknowledged objectively that the nuclear agreement that Iran has agreed to is a good result of European diplomacy, but it must certainly also be said that, for all the evil that is happening in the Middle East, the aggressive policy of the United States of America, which is already completely openly ignoring international law, is perpetuate terrorist attacks on selected actors of other foreign states.  I call for the European Union to condemn this American terrorist attack, as well as condemn all other terrorist attacks by other countries, and to stay away from these dangerous bloody adventures of the United States.

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, with regard to the Iranian-American dispute, we must leave the truth. The truth is that General Soleimani was one of the organizers of the attack against the embassy in Tehran and was executed on Iraqi territory, where he produced the terrorist act. As far as we are concerned, it is a general current that we must do everything to maintain the Nuclear Agreement. I want to express my view: Iran will not respect the nuclear agreement, and we will remain in solidarity with a terrorist power in Tehran.  We're counting on our solidarity. I do not know whether we will be able to stand in solidarity until the end, as a terrorist government is our partner in this Nuclear Agreement.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, High Representative Borrell, the 176 fatalities of the aircraft shot down by an Iranian surface-to-air missile last week are the tragic corollary of an action-reaction spiral. Tragedy only worsens when we know that the Iranian authorities recognize the truth after the Canadian prime minister has made it public, according to his own intelligence services. But it can get even worse. Eighteen fatalities were European, dozens were Canadian, but most were Iranian, so we are faced with the certain likelihood that there will be harshly repressed Iranian demonstrations with hundreds of dead, as we have seen in recent months, and exclusion from the internet. What's more, the threat to definitively cancel the 2015 nuclear deal. We cannot afford it at the risk of imminent war in the region. That is why what we can do from the European Parliament is to support the diplomatic efforts, which you lead, of European diplomacy, so that the European Union can do everything it can — and not a second later do so — to prevent it.

name: Alexander ALEXANDROV YORDANOV
text: – Madam President, Mr Borrell, if a sensible approach fails, if de-escalating fails, do we have a vision for action? It is time, apparently, to prepare plan B. It is not enough to express condolences for those who died after the criminal attack on the Ukrainian plane. We must declare to this authoritarian and terrorist regime that if it continues its aggressive policy in the region, there will be another response, there will be a new Desert Storm. Isn't it a paradox that Iranians themselves react more harshly against the ayatollah regime than we do? It is time to support those who are protesting against this regime. And one more thing, colleagues: anti-Americanism, which in this room also sounded in a sense, is not only a threat to the United States, it is also a threat to us, to Europe. And in this situation, we must be with the United States.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: vice-président de la Commission et haut représentant de l’Union pour les affaires étrangères et la politique de sécurité. – Madame la Présidente, cela a été tout un ensemble de points de vue, tous très intéressants mais très différents. S’il fallait que je décrive à quelqu’un la position du Parlement après vous avoir écoutés, je ne saurais pas l’exprimer parce que ça va du blanc-blanc au noir-noir, et les points de vue sont très différents à propos d’une crise qui est très dangereuse pour nous tous, vous en avez tous convenu. D’abord, je voulais vous dire que personne n’a abandonné l’accord sur le nucléaire iranien. Nobody has abandoned it. It’s not me who believes that the JCPOA is essential for our security and has to be kept; it’s the Foreign Affairs Council and it is also the three Ministers of the E3 who share this point of view.  I know that there is a certain contradiction between the letter that I received signed by the Foreign Affairs Minister of the United Kingdom, and the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom saying something which looks quite different from the letter I have read, but what counts for me is the letter, which is an official document which has to follow my action. The British Minister says that the action they are proposing is not to abandon the deal and substitute the Obama deal with the Trump deal. It says that they want to keep the deal alive and what they want is to use this mechanism, this process, in order to have leverage in regard to Iran.  No, nobody has abandoned the deal. The International Atomic Energy Agency continues to monitor and inspect Iran’s nuclear activities, and let’s not forget that the JCPOA is embodied in a United Nations Security Council resolution. It’s not something that we Europeans wrote one night here together. It took 10 years to reach this deal and it was approved by a United Nations resolution, which nobody has cancelled. It is still alive. So don’t blame me and say, ‘Mr Borrell, you have to change your mind’. I’m coming here to explain not my mind – that too – but mainly what the Foreign Affairs Council, after a long debate, has decided and what the letter from the three Ministers says. We are certainly strongly committed to defending Iraq’s sovereignty, its territorial integrity and the importance of Iraqi ownership of the country’s internal political reform process. When my colleagues in the Foreign Affairs Council give me a mandate to do whatever I can, to use all the tools of diplomacy and to talk with everybody – everybody means, I say it again, everybody – in order to look for a regional political solution, I understand that it is an invitation to keep in touch with the Iraqi Government. Well, for the time being, the Iraqi Government is a caretaker government, but immediately afterwards – this meeting was on Friday – I kept in touch with the Iraqi Government, even if it is a caretaker government, and on Monday, the Vice—Minister for Foreign Affairs of Iraq was here having political consultations with the Secretary—General of the European External Action Service, and we agreed that we have to do more.  Someone asked me who can do more and how. Well, just by developing the Association Agreement that we signed, which was ratified and entered into force in 2018, just doing that is a lot of things. It is a lot of work and a lot of possibilities. We have a mission there and we can reinforce this mission. This Association Agreement opens the door to a lot of relationships on trade, economics and security, and certainly we have to decide what we are going to do from the point of view of the foreign, defence and security policy with the mission that we have there.  The soundest thing would be to reinforce it in order to help the Iraqi Government to avoid the country falling apart in any way because, after listening to all of you, I understand that all of you are completely aware of the very dramatic consequences that could come for our security if we have a crisis in Iraq similar to the one we have been witnessing in Syria.  That is why in the next days and weeks I will be engaged in a diplomatic consultation with the Iraqis and will offer our support and our help in order to continue the reform process in this country and avoid losing all the process and progress that has been made in the last years.  We can have a lot of discussions about what the future will be, but for the time being one thing is clear: Iran is not a nuclear power today thanks to the JCPOA and I don’t see how we can build an alternative agreement. I really don’t see it. Everybody talks about this deal. Some of you have been curious enough to have a look at it. It is a book like this, thick like this, full of technicalities, which it took 10 years to agree on.  I really don’t believe that it’s going to be easy to build another agreement with the same complexity, dealing, in a much more complex and conflictual environment, with the current situation. So that is why I have to insist that for us Europeans – and I am talking on behalf of the Foreign Affairs Council – we have to do whatever we can in order to make this deal survive, and for that we clearly have to push and influence the Iranians in order to fulfil all their commitments.  But let me tell you one thing that I think I already told you at the beginning. The Americans withdrew unilaterally from this deal and the Iranians have respected their obligation for 14 months without any kind of contretemps. Now they have certainly said that they don’t feel bound by the constraints of this agreement, but it is one thing not to feel bound and another to go over to the other side. There only the International Atomic Energy Agency can tell us how much and when it has happened. That’s why you have to rely on the reports from this Agency that, until now, has been a wise testimony of what is happening there. More engagement with Iraq and try to deal with all parts of the nuclear deal in order to keep it alive. I can certainly also talk about the Ukrainian plane. I can talk and try to answer all the many interesting issues that you have raised during your interventions, but unhappily it would take too long. Let me just say thank you for your contributions. I am sure we will continue to have to deal with this issue in this Parliament.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 171)

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – The situation in Iran has deteriorated severely and there have been more and more casualties among civilians. The shooting down of a Ukrainian passenger jet is appalling and clearly shows that everything that is happening in the Middle East also has a direct impact on Europe. The EU must clearly be more active in deft ing and finding solutions in the Middle East. It is important to find a solution to the nuclear agreement with Iran, and it is important that the EU has a clearer vision for middle east policy. This should certainly be one of the most important tasks of the Special Representative for Foreign Affairs.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: in writing. – What has happened recently in Iran and Iraq is another step in escalating tension, provocation and aggression led by the US and Israel in the Middle East, with the aim of imposing the hegemony of American imperialism throughout the region. The action taken by the US that led to the death of General Soleimani and representatives of political movements in Iraq and Lebanon is an unequivocal act of war, the consequences of which could lead to a conflict of unpredictable proportions. Strangely, or perhaps not, this act of war did not merit condemnation by the Member States or by the EU itself. We reject the destabilization strategy of the region promoted by the United States and its allies. It is essential to comply with international law and respect for the sovereignty of peoples, condemning this aggression and the escalation of provocation in the Middle East. It is essential to end the military occupation of Iraq. It is essential to defend peace and reject war.

name: Sergei STANISHEV
text: in writing. – Three years after Trump’s stepping into office, US foreign policy is starting to look less bound to a coherent strategy and more like a victim of erratic impulses. His latest reckless actions in the Middle East are the pinnacle of a long series of provocations starting with US withdrawal from the Nuclear Deal in 2018. Without a doubt, no tears should be shed for General Soleimani, whose imprints remain all over conflict zones in the Middle East. Yet the dangerous escalation, brought by Soleimani’s assassination in violation of international law, pushed the region in a spiral of tragic events and led to hundredths of innocent victims. Instead of giving hope to moderation and normalisation, Trump’s ‘fire and fury’ strategy plays into the hands of emboldened military leaders and extreme hardliners. It’s no wonder they are now even more convinced in the need of a nuclear deterrent. We must now stand united in support of EU High Representative Borrell’s efforts to revert all parties to dialogue, calm and restraint and to harness the Nuclear Deal. For the EU, the time for reflection for bigger strategic autonomy has come. Dialogue and diplomacy will always be Europe’s ways, and not tweets and bombs.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The next item is the report by Isabel Wiseler-Lima, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on human rights and democracy in the world and the European Union’s policy on the matter – annual report 2018 (2019/2125(INI)) (A9—0051/2019).

name: Isabel WISELER-LIMA
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, the European Parliament has a responsibility to speak with a strong, clear and above all united voice when it comes to human rights. Therefore, throughout the negotiations, I have tried to find the consensus that would allow us today to put to a vote a report which would be an expression of all our battles, of all our convictions and which would be carried by a very large majority. This united voice is not an end in itself but allows, in a context where we aspire to universality, to affirm our deep common respect for democracy and human rights. Human dignity, the affirmation of it, again and again must in our European Parliament go beyond the borders of political groups, be a shared value that allows us to be credible when we demand over and over again in our international relations respect for human rights. Especially since this European voice, together with other democratic voices around the world, is more than necessary in view of the content of the report on the state of democracy and human rights in the world. The report expresses its deep concern at the attacks on democracy and the rule of law. One point of particular concern to me is the rise of authoritarianism as a political project. It is also not a question of falling into the forced pessimism and the report also welcomes the fact that in a number of countries peace and democratisation processes are being implemented, as well as constitutional and judicial reforms. I would also like to stress that civil society and its commitment to democracy and human rights are now, much more than yesterday, in an encouraging sight. We support those who raise their voices to defend democratic values. However, one point remains particularly dark for humanity: the scourge of conflict and military attacks, including ethnic cleansing, continues to cause civilian deaths and mass displacement. Often, these places of extreme violence and non-law give way to the expression of the inhumanity in which men can fall. These places then become a space where cruelty and horror are lived on a daily basis. We are in the unspeakable. Each of us, all of us, has a human obligation to denounce this loud and clear, and as Members of this Parliament we have a political obligation to provoke action against this human misery. The report also highlights the issue of the rights of indigenous peoples, who are often violated, even though national and international laws protect them. It stresses the importance of advancing gender equality and the rights of women and girls around the world. Women and children are in fragile environments and are most likely to be victims of violence, most vulnerable to abuse and shameless exploitation. The report pays particular attention to freedom of speech and expression, as well as media pluralism, which are at the heart of truly democratic societies. It deplores the injustice of human rights defenders, including academics, journalists and politicians. It denounces the murders committed as well as the application of the death penalty, persecution and arbitrary imprisonment. The report stresses that trade and human rights can and must strengthen each other and stresses corporate responsibility. It fully supports human rights dialogues with third countries in the promotion and protection of human rights. Last but not least, he stresses that the right to freedom of thought, conscience, religion and belief must be guaranteed throughout the world and preserved unconditionally. At the end of my presentation, I would like to sincerely thank all the shadow rapporteurs and teams for the spirit in which all have worked.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, once again I have to thank the European Parliament for its continued monitoring of the human rights and democracy situation around the world and today I have to welcome your comprehensive Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World, which provides many useful recommendations. Thank you to the rapporteur, Ms Isabel Wiseler—Lima, for her work. I have to start by saying that human rights and democracy are and must remain at the heart of our work. It’s part of our DNA. At the very first Foreign Affairs Council meeting I chaired in December, we discussed with all EU foreign ministers our collective efforts to protect and promote human rights and democracy, taking into account the worrying trends, including shrinking space for civil society and increasing attacks on human rights defenders. The ministers agreed on the political appropriateness of establishing an EU global human rights sanction regime, and work on this is being taken forward in the Council and we hope to move forward as quickly as possible. This global human rights sanction regime is one of the targets, one of the purposes, objectives that we, all together, have to try to achieve as soon as possible. On my second day in office, I engaged with grassroots environmental human rights defenders from around the world at the Human Rights Forum, focusing on how to build a fair environment for the future. Many of the issues that you address in your Annual Report on Human Rights and Democracy, which was adopted in May last year, were already addressed in this report. And we delivered and streamlined a report using concrete country—specific examples. We are fully aware of the strong interlinkages between the two reports and for the next EU annual report, covering 2019, we are aiming for a timely adoption this spring. Your report calls for a more effective EU human rights foreign policy. It’s a welcome contribution to the ongoing work on the new Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy. This will be a roadmap setting the EU level of ambition and priorities for the next five years and it will reflect the transition to a digital world and the changing geopolitical dynamics. Human rights and democracy are and should continue to be at the centre of our relations with third countries. The European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights (EIDHR) is the largest financial instrument in the world dedicated specifically to human rights and democracy and payments for EUR 135 million were made under this flagship in 2018. Let me give some examples: the 2018 global call for proposal led to the selection of five projects on LGBTI rights and there was EUR 70 million to spend on that. They cover such difficult countries on this subject like Russia, Malawi, Zimbabwe, Guatemala, Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, Colombia and Peru. This project supported capacity—building of specialised NGOs and offered legal aid to victims of LGBTI—related human rights violations and to human rights defenders. Beyond development cooperation, your report correctly points out that trade and economic policies should be linked to political dialogue and that human rights violations should be fully taken into consideration in any action that the European Union is undertaking. You are very well aware of our human rights guidelines, the regular dialogues and a strong public diplomacy. We have a special representative for human rights that has reached out to governments and civil society globally and his leadership has already raised considerably the profile of the European Union human rights policy. In particular, the European Union has contributed to moving forward on rights of the child and, together with a group of Latin American and Caribbean countries, we have been tabling three resolutions on the right of the child. Two were presented during the March session of the Human Rights Council. One concerned the 30th anniversary of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child and the second focused on empowering children with disabilities so that they can enjoy their human rights, including the right to inclusive education. Your report also correctly draws attention to the rising backlash against women’s rights worldwide. The EU remains strongly committed to the full enjoyment of human rights by all. Our broad commitment to gender equality and women’s empowerment is demonstrated, in particular, by our Spotlight Initiative on ending violence against women and girls, signed in September 2017 in New York. This initiative is backed by a substantive EUR 500 million investment over the period 2018—2024. Two pillars were implemented: the Latin American pillar against the gender—motivated killing of women and the sub—Saharan pillar to prevent and eliminate sexual and gender—based violence and harmful practices. These need to remain at the forefront of our efforts, particularly in view of the 25th anniversary of the World Conference on Women and the Beijing Declaration. Also, your report welcomes the Council conclusions on democracy of last October and highlights the significance of transparent, inclusive and credible elections. This requires me to thank the Member States – and also the Members of this Parliament – who have joined our election observation missions. This election observation mission structure is a good example of how our institutions are working efficiently together. I don’t want to read the whole list of those missions, but I just want to point out some of them: Salvador, Kosovo, Malawi, Mozambique, Nigeria, Senegal, Sri Lanka and Tunisia. I am sorry that we were not in the last elections in Bolivia. We are going to mend that and will continue to do such important work in order to defend the basis of the human rights, which is an efficient democracy.  Let me say that this exchange of views was very useful. In the end, I will say I am sure that when I heard you, Ms Rapporteur, I found in your works the same aim that motivates the service I have responsibility for in order to work together on this issue. Thank you very much for your work. I am sure that now I can have more information about what you ask the External Action Service to do to defend human rights all over the world because you, European Parliamentarians, and us, people working on our missions all over the world, are trying to fight for the same purpose.

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President of the meeting, Vice-President Borrell, I too want to congratulate our fellow rapporteur. This is a very good report and makes it very clear that the European Union is working hard to defend human rights and democracy around the world. I would like to confine myself to a fundamental right that our societies strongly respect and that makes us unique and extremely influential in the world, namely the right to free speech.  Vice-President Borrell, I call on the External Action Service to do more to defend freedom of expression in the states in our immediate vicinity. It is inadmissible that, in a new neighbouring state of Turkey, hundreds of media institutions should be closed, thousands of journalists, dismissed, some of them wrongly detained and wrongly arrested. It is important to act because the right to free speech is a fundamental right in a democracy.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today's meeting with Parliament's report on human rights is neither ritual nor bureaucratic. If anything, as has already been said, the vote and approval take place too late: more than a year and a half late. The united work we have done has enabled us above all to draw attention to so many issues, and my colleagues in the Socialist Group who will be speak will point out the new features of the report. I would particularly like to highlight one issue: the fact that we have placed a great deal of emphasis on how we make European policy for the defence and protection of human rights in the world more effective. And here the issue of impunity is a crucial, decisive issue, which we have tried to put at the centre, in order to address a more fundamental issue: in the face of the challenge of safeguarding human rights and defending human rights, how to combat impunity also through new instruments, new powers, capable of reducing the spread of impunity. This is our commitment and our responsibility, and it will be the task of future relations to go into more substance, to make this a crucial issue of our identity, without ifs and buts, in order to really win the challenge in the world on human rights, also making strong choices – I imagine at the next G20 in Riyadh – to condition our participation in that meeting to put the issue of human rights also in a large country like Saudi Arabia.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Madam President, the annual discussion we have on the human rights report contains a risk: that of the routine settling into our debates when they deal with respect for human rights in the world. There is a risk of making the same observations, of resorting to formulas that are similar from one year to the next and of always renewing the same hopes. Today, it is different. This concern is quickly brushed aside. We have before us a well-thought-out, well-structured report, as precise as possible. The report presented to us by Mrs Wiseler-Lima is an essential reference for the weeks, months and perhaps years to come in terms of discussion of human rights. It covers almost all subjects without getting too lost in the details. It also addresses the heavy trends that condition respect for human rights in the world and among these heavy trends, it regrets, of course, the decline of multilateralism. The retreat of multilateralism means a betrayal of a proven method and abandonment of a human rights achievement. We can see that some countries of the European Union, the Council of Europe and within the Atlantic Alliance have allowed themselves to be led in this drift. It is particularly unfortunate to find among them the very members of the European Union. Finally, as I have little time, I would like to ask the Commission what consequences it intends to set aside for our proposals. Last year I presented a report on the ban on forced marriages and underage marriages and we, as the European Parliament, voted overwhelmingly to make the ban on underage marriage and forced marriages an element of conditionality in our approach to external relations. I hope that the last word on this matter has not yet been said.

name: Hannah NEUMANN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the human rights situation is worsening globally. That is why it is important that we hold all those accountable who violate human rights. But it is even more important that we start using the leverage that we as the European Union, with all its Member States and its economic strengths, have. That we use it to protect all those fighting for democracy and human rights.  Why is it that trade deals can protect business but not humans? Why do European companies still make a fortune selling weapons to warmongers? Why can’t so many human rights defenders still not come to the EU if they need protection? And why is it that European companies still destroy the livelihoods of so many indigenous people, only to mine coal? Mr Borrell, with this report, we want to change those things. It is a strong report, carried by a very large majority in this House. I hope it will guide your work for the next five years. Thank you, Isabel Wiseler-Lima for your great work on this.

name: Simona BALDASSARRE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am here today to ask you and ask you not to be complicit in a shameful business of almost six billion dollars, surrogacy, an alarmingly expanding phenomenon throughout the world, where wealthy Western buyers exploit women from poor countries, such as an insidious form of colonisation or, worse, new slavery. Let us work together against this shameful practice which violates human rights, the dignity of women and mercifies their bodies. Innocent children, torn from their mothers, become a mere contractual object, trampling on Article 7 of the Convention on Children itself. This Parliament has already spoken out in 2011 and 2015 against the de-development of the female body and the exploitation of vulnerable girls. Today I ask that the much-vaunted protection of women should not remain an empty word. It is essential that the European Union, which claims to be the first defender of human rights, should take every measure against surrogacy, because women are not incubators and children are not a bargaining chip. Women and men of this Parliament, today I ask for your help!

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. For two thirds of your speech on our monitors, you have been told that you are speaking in the debate on Iran and Iraq. I am glad that at the moment there is already current information, although I have already received signals on my cell phone. This is a rather bizarre situation. I will say this: I am very pleased that we in the European Parliament feel that we are the institution that shows what democratic standards are all over the world. We want to keep an eye on these standards. And good! I have been an observer of elections in more than twenty different countries, and I know that our missions make sense. In truth, it is the case that we ourselves must take care of certain democratic standards. I do not understand the situation. I just had the information that I only have eight seconds. Madam President, I have pointed out the error that has occurred. I would not like to see this taken as revenge on your part, Madam President, so I conclude. It is incomprehensible to me that yesterday the European Parliament refused to debate what was happening in Paris.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, 2018 was a year marked by the rise of intolerance, hatred and discrimination. It was the year of the increase in political violence against rights and environmental defenders, who, like Marielle Franco, were killed. We still demand justice today. But it was also the year when women, faced with the advance of the far right, took to the streets massively to remind us that the revolution will be feminist or not. And, one more year, this report on human rights refuses to look at Europe, where we too, ladies and gentlemen, must remember that human rights are violated. And if not, let's look at our borders, refugee camps like Moria, the ⸻ European Guantanamoauthenics⸻ detention centres, or the rampant inequality that is on our streets. Let us stop hypocritically demanding from other countries to guarantee human rights while we, or our multinationals, continue to violate them. We have to change this policy. We must stop violating human rights. Also in Europe, and also by European countries, governments and multinationals.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow we will vote on the 2018 annual report on human rights and democracy. In this first report of this parliamentary term, it is extremely important, once again and even more allegedly, to confirm the importance of those fundamental values on which the very existence of the Union is based: multilateralism, the centrality of human rights, the defence of minorities. Only by reminding ourselves who we are can we ensure that our action is consistent with these principles and not lose its course. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Isabel Wiseler-Lima, for the exceptional work she has done in concerting the different visions within the various committees involved. This strategy paper shows the deep shared concern about the contraction of democracy, human rights and the rule of law. 2019 was a year in which increasingly alarming authoritarian tendencies emerged and less and less recourse to multilateral international forums for the resolution of disputes between states. At this time, it is more urgent than ever for the Eu ropean Union to take the example of the international community. I therefore consider it a priority to focus, during this parliamentary term, on putting progress on human rights at the heart of any action by the European Union, dear High Representative, and to demand that all our allies fully respect the shared rules.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, I am waiting because I see that Mr Borrell is very busy with his phone and it is perhaps good that he is putting his headphones on. Unfortunately, the report we have on the table calls attention to freedom of religion and belief in the world. After all, for billions on this earth, their faith is the most important thing. They want to be able to freely confess and pronounce it. Unfortunately, because of their faith, many are oppressed, systematically bullied or even killed, not only by other people but also by governments. Think of repressions and murders of people in countries such as Iran, India, Nepal, Nigeria, Saudi Arabia and Somalia, and I hope that Mr Borrell will put that on his phone by now.  European policy is duplicitous. On the one hand, the High Representative almost weekly condemns all such attacks, and rightly so. On the other hand, the European Union continues to trade with these countries in full, and then concrete action is lacking. Beautiful words without concrete actions sound like hollow vessels. Please take action against countries like that.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: – Madam President, the presentation of this report is not merely the fulfilment of any bureaucratic ritual, it is the result of deep reflection and hard work of concertation and dialogue that requires a practical translation into the lives of thousands of people. I therefore extend a special greeting to the Rapporteur Isabel Wiseler-Lima and also to the shadow rapporteur of our political group, Mr Andrea Cozzolino. There would be much to say, but for a matter of time I would be reduced to highlighting the following points in the report that we will vote on tomorrow. the relevance given to civil society in a period of increasing compression of its area of intervention; stress the importance of promoting freedom of expression and democracy at a time of great challenges; the reference to the need to strengthen the fight against impunity; the mention of the need for protection of indigenous peoples increasingly exposed to all kinds of threats; the emphasis given to those forused in a year in which they exceeded 70 million; relevance given to gender equality. When it is human rights, it is much more what unites us than what divides us. Let us make this the driving force behind the work we have to do in the European Parliament.

name: Irina VON WIESE
text: – Madam President, colleagues, do you know where your Christmas cards were made? In December, a young girl in the UK found a message in one of her charity Christmas cards pleading for help. It was not from the sender, it was from the person who was forced to make the card in a Chinese prison cell in inhumane conditions.  Consumers in the richest countries of the world enjoy cheap throw—away products and turn a blind eye to the real cost. Manufacturers and retailers, including many European household brands, do not know and do not want to know what happens at the bottom of their supply chains. We must act urgently to have EU—wide legislation that makes supply chain due diligence mandatory. Companies must ensure that the low price of their products is not at the expense of human rights or the environment.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Madam President, I want to highlight the strong call by this Parliament for a legislation on human rights due diligence for European enterprises, because of course enterprises must take their share of addressing global challenges. It’s wonderful to see that more and more responsible companies call for mandatory due diligence legislation, especially at the European level, because they want a level playing field and they don’t want to be competed out from the market by irresponsible companies. So we have to make sure that we encourage responsibility and not irresponsibility. It is very important to guarantee access to remedy for victims of cooperate misconduct, and may I just remind you that this is the so-called third pillar of the United Nations guiding principles on business and human rights. And the EU has done very, very little, if anything, on this one. So 2020 must be the year of action, and when the EU acts the impact reaches far beyond the EU’s borders.

name: Bert-Jan RUISSEN
text: Mr President, the report before us shows that human rights are still being violated in many countries. Commitment to human rights must therefore remain an important spearhead of our foreign policy. I am thinking of protecting the rights of the child and of people with disabilities. I am thinking of countering the persecution and violence against people for whatever reason: whether it is because of faith, because of ethnicity or because of sexual orientation.  Meanwhile, Christians worldwide are the most persecuted religious group. Therefore, what about the EU Special Envoy for Religious Freedom in this regard? It needs to be reset and strengthened. I would therefore like to hear, and this is a specific question for the High Representative, what the status of the mandate of this EU envoy for religious freedom is.

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam rapporteur, I believe that the european Union's power on the international stage must be based on the defence of human rights. But how can the Union have the moral authority to demand respect for human rights in the states of the world if there are states in the Union that are not able to respect those same rights on its territory? Human rights are economic and social rights, of course, but also civil and political rights. Oriol Junqueras is not sitting here today because Spain does not respect its political rights, and I myself am now exiled to Belgium because Spain does not respect the human rights of Catalan separatist leaders. Turkey, Russia and China have said recently that they are following Spanish standards. When the European Union looks elsewhere when a Member State clearly violates human rights, it loses all capacity to ask others to respect what its states are not able to respect. (The speaker refuses a question "blue card" from Dolors Montserrat)

name: Arba KOKALARI
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for We are concerned that democracy is in decline globally, that repression against free media and dissidents has increased and that violence against women is the most common violation in the world. At the same time, China and Russia are advancing their positions. This needs europe and Europe more than ever.  I would like the European Commission to give priority to three important points: to urgently impose sanctions on individuals who commit serious violations of human rights and freedoms; that the demands for democracy in europe should be high for those who want to join the EU, but at the same time we give them hope that their future is in Europe and not elsewhere; that the EU takes greater responsibility for strengthening the rights of women and girls around the world.  The EU was once built on ideas to protect human rights and democracy. Then let us always act and show that we will always take it seriously, because that is not something we can take for granted.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Madam President, 70 years after the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, we live in a world where respect for these rights is more at risk than ever. The many reports of human rights defenders are alarming: conflicts around the world are depriving millions of people of their fundamental rights. The savage globalization that places business above human rights sacrifices entire populations on the altar of the profits of a few companies and a few shareholders, not to mention the rise of authoritarian regimes that carry their share of repression, discrimination and withdrawal in the name of a so-called national identity. Europe is not spared, yet it remains the territory representing this value of human rights, but for how much longer? It is our duty, it is our responsibility, our credibility, to be the global engine of the defence of human rights, in a coherent way, of course, that is, in all our policies: whether they are commercial, diplomatic, whether they are in our association agreements, we must put the issue of human rights first. Human rights must remain the european political marker. Mr. Borrell, you can count on us to support you in this difficult but noble task that is given to you today.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: – Madam President, Mr Comín, in democracies, as in my country, in Spain, human rights are worth what their guarantees are worth, and law enforcement and respect for the courts, which respect the rights of citizens, is the best guarantee. When his fellow seat violated the legal system, he tried against the Constitution and against the rule of law in Spain, he tried and violated the rights of Catalan citizens, whose obligation as president of that community had an obligation to respect and protect. Today, escaped from the Spanish Court not to respond to his actions, he sits in that seat, protecting himself in the legal order and the rule of law that he dis met, seeking impunity, not immunity. That is the defence that democracies within the European Union make of human rights.

name: Saskia BRICMONT
text: Madam President, thank you to the colleagues in the Committee on Human Rights for the excellent report they are presenting to us today, which I hope will also be voted on by a large majority in this House. It enshrines freedom of speech and expression and media pluralism as the heart of our democratic societies, which cannot be limited in the name of arguments such as the fight against terrorism, state security or the maintenance of order. It is also characterized by opposition to arbitrary detentions and indicates that we must promote and continue to promote human rights and democracy in the world through our foreign policy, of course, and not inadvertently strengthen authoritarian regimes. The credibility that you are calling this House for today is likely to be put to the test as early as next month, as we will have to ratify the trade agreement with Vietnam. Vietnam, which is now experiencing a large setback in human rights, too many political prisoners and a strengthening of this problematic situation in 2019. The European External Action Service has called for a response to the arrests of journalists and bloggers. How can we act in a united way? By being consistent between our human rights policies and our trade policies.

name: Frances FITZGERALD
text: – Madam President, first of all I want to congratulate the rapporteur, Isabel Wiseler-Lima, on this report. Because as colleagues have said, this is a most comprehensive report, it’s gold standard in terms of human rights. The question is: how will it be responded to how, will it be implemented? It has been sent to a whole variety of important organisations and individuals. Let’s make sure that governments and ourselves implement the very best practice when it comes to human rights. Many human rights are under threat with the rise of authoritarianism. And we must also call out the macho leadership that we’re seeing around the world. Women’s rights are in danger. Let’s look to home, make sure that the Istanbul Convention on preventing and combating violence against women that seven countries have not ratified is actually ratified. And let’s take a lead role in eliminating FGM around the world. Let’s hear all our political leaders speak out around this. And let’s make sure that we talk about what is happening to human rights defenders and take action in Europe to protect them.

name: Dietmar KÖSTER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Article 2 of the EU Treaties states that 'the values on which the Union is founded are respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights'. These human rights do not only apply to EU citizens, but also to all without exception. But what use are they of a refugee who is stranded in Bosnia and Herzegovina and who has already been illegally pushed back to Bosnia by the Croatian border guards for the umpteenth time, being beaten, mistreated and robbed in the process? His human right is literally being trampled underfoot. In the European Union, human and refugee rights are increasingly being challenged and foreign and development policy is subject to the primacy of the refugee defence. This undermines the EU's foundation of values and its credibility in the global commitment to human rights and democracy. That is why we must take a stand: for the inalienable right to asylum and respect for the human rights of refugees in the European Union and in the world.

name: Nacho SÁNCHEZ AMOR
text: – Madam President, as Mr Comín has not had the gallantry to accept the blue card proposed to him, I would like to remind you that this document we are discussing concerns human rights issues in the world. That is not to say that there are no issues to deal with about human rights in Europe. For example, what happened in the Catalan Parliament on 6 and 7 December 2017, when the rights of minorities or the opposition were trampled on. The same rule of law that has Mr. Comín sitting here today. The same rule of law that has Mr Comín sitting here and that everyone in this room respects when he agrees with us and when he doesn't agree with us. I regret only being able to refer to Mr Wiseler-Lima's great work by telling colleagues: dear colleagues, you are not a global player giving Sakharov Awards. You're not a global actor just giving Sakharov Awards. Either we have the political capacity to protect the people we target, and we have the capacity to influence the political life of those regimes, or we are simply making a huge toast to the sun. Therefore, our security and defence capacity must be strengthened so that our policy of promoting values is accompanied by an effective policy of defending these human value defenders in the regimes in which they are attacked.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, High Representative, I would like to make one comment on this debate. The doctrine of human rights is very often debated here in Parliament. We debate very often how human rights are trampled and violated in individual countries of the world. I have one request. This report, which will be adopted tomorrow, may it be a guide for you on what practical steps we should take in EU foreign policy. We are still calling for those regimes where human rights and citizens' freedoms are being violated to be more tough, not to provide them with such economic assistance and to treat them differently from their partners, to states where human rights are respected and respected. I very much ask that this material, this document, be reflected in your real activity, be reflected in EU foreign policy and that we give money and economic support only to those who are willing to respect human rights.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, this report reiterates and supports the European Parliament’s resolution passed on 3 May 2018 with regard to the protection of migrant children. Last week in the UK, the House of Commons rejected proposals to maintain protections for child refugees in the redrafted EU Withdrawal Agreement Bill. It is a betrayal of Britain’s long-standing commitment to humanitarian support, especially to the most vulnerable. I’d like to pay tribute to Labour Lord Alf Dubs, himself a Jewish refugee, who led the campaign on this issue, and I hope the House of Lords rectifies what has been a huge mistake made by the government.  If this is what Global Britain looks like post-Brexit, it sends out all the wrong messages as to who we are and who we want to be as a nation. Whether in or out of the EU, we must not abandon our commitment to human rights and internationalism, and as a child rights campaigner I ask all those in positions of power to remember Alan Kurdi and all the other child refugees who died whilst we turned our backs.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, despite many efforts, the human rights situation in the world is not improving. The scale of crimes and atrocities committed against children, women, ethnic minorities and religious groups, among others, are difficult to grasp even for those with extensive years of work in the field of human rights promotion and protection. The question of whether our assessments, reaction and response to the violations that have occurred are the best possible remains open. For example, we’re too slow to react to the worsening situation in Cambodia, where attacks on the political opposition, civil society groups and independent media have intensified. Human rights violations also take place by our borders: in Belarus, we see no improvement in political processes, including freedom of assembly and association, free speech, and independent media. The political opposition remains suppressed, and civil society is sidelined from ongoing negotiations towards losing the countries’ sovereignty to Russia.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, people say that  human rights are under threat. Yes, there is an element of truth to that, but sadly we have lost our moral authority to be talking about human rights the way we used to. The very fact that we ignore the rule of law so often around the world today does not do anything for our credibility to talk about human rights; the very fact that we don’t oppose US sanctions in places like Iran, Syria and Venezuela – because those sanctions hurt the poorest people in those countries the most and Europe should stand up against it.  We talk about trade and human rights being mutually enhancing; well in Saudi Arabia they cut off heads on a regular basis but I don’t see Europe having any problem trading with them. I don’t see us having much of a problem dealing with Israel despite the breach of human rights and international law in Palestine on a regular basis. We are not being consistent in how we behave.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, human rights is an endless issue. So many questions. Let me start by answering a very concrete question about our Special Envoy for Freedom of Belief: yes, we have a special envoy – Ján Figeľ. President Juncker created the function and appointed Ján Figeľ in May 2016. He supports implementation of the European Union Guidelines on promoting and protection of freedom of belief, as the name of his mandate says. He is engaged in visiting countries where the freedom of belief is at risk, engaging with national authorities and institutions, human rights organisations and religious leaders and communities. He participates in dialogue with them and promotes respect for diversity. It is a little bit of a reiteration – I’m saying the same thing in different ways – but that is what he’s doing, and he also serves as Special Adviser to the Commissioner for Development Cooperation. I cannot remember who asked the question – they are no longer here – but this is the answer I can provide to him: I will review the job, the mandate, of this special envoy and see how we can improve it, and what is the justification of this job. The subject requires for sure for someone to take care of it, but I will learn more about it; to tell the truth, I was not aware of the existence of this Special Envoy for the Protection of Freedom and Belief. Maybe next time I will be able to give more information. The other big issue that has been raised is business and human rights. It is a big issue for sure, and someone has been saying that Western consumers are very happy to consume cheaper goods without paying a lot of attention to the way these lower costs have been obtained. Why is it cheaper? Is the production procedure more efficient, or is it because the human rights of the workers are not respected as we require them to be respected in our economic system? The European Union is maybe the most engaged organisation in the world on this issue – to address human rights abuses connected to the activities of business entities. We have binding schemes in areas such as trade in diamonds and other conflict minerals, export controls on torture goods, and schemes against trade in lethal injections and the work of the child. I can give you examples of what we have been doing: we have some agreements with Asia-Pacific for close cooperation on business and human rights in Asia, where we have been investing more than EUR 5 million on this programme, and we have a similar project ongoing in Latin America. But we need to do more. We need to build up the necessary consensus. I don’t have a mandate to work more on that, so I count on the right of initiative of Parliament – you have it, use it – to help me in this task, in which I am very interested. You have capacities: use these capacities, because, as you know, I am only the representative of a set of people who very often don’t agree on every issue. In order to have a mandate, it would be very useful if Parliament used its right of initiative in order to build a European Union binding treaty. I think this is a very important issue – maybe the most important one worldwide. What other issues have been pointed out by you? Many of them. Due diligence legislation: yes, we have called for further EU due diligence legislation during the previous mandate, and some Member States such as France and Netherlands have adopted their own national legislation, but others have not done this. Once again, when you deal with a subject which is highly divisive, and when you don’t have an agreement among Member States, it is difficult to advance in something even if you are strongly convinced that this is needed. Here again, we can build an alliance between Parliament and the High Representative in order to push things that I, myself, do not have enough capacity to develop.
