I think this part-session could be a good start to our work together in order to advance human rights defence all over the world.

name: Isabel WISELER-LIMA
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would once again like to be the voice of those who have spoken today, as I have tried to do in this report as well. I would just like to point out some of the difficulties that have been raised this evening, including multilateralism, human rights defenders in difficulty - very important because they are the pillars for this to move forward - LGBTI people, who have enormous difficulties in some countries, violence against women and girls, production chains that have been named and which are problematic , companies that have their share of responsibility, forced marriages. Mr. Borrell, you have named the tools: we have the observation missions, we have your action, that of a representative for human rights and for freedom of religion. You said, 'What are you asking us?'. There are certain things that have come up every time during all these negotiations while we are working on this report: we must not let people who are guilty in the field of human rights go unpunished, they must be prosecuted, there must be a follow-up. We have to do everything we can in that direction. We must also insist on multilateralism, insist that trade be done in a way that we can be proud of. In that sense, I would like to talk about the follow-up mechanism that should be when we talk about trade because asking for certain things to be done is one thing, monitoring is another. I remain to hope that real progress will be made in the future on the state of democracy and human rights in the world and that we will know by our positions, you by yours or by your action and by us by our positions here in the European Parliament, to help accelerate this progress.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 15 January 2020. Written declarations (Article 171 OF the CRP)

name: Markus BUCHHEIT
text: Writing. – The report on the EU's Common Foreign and Security Policy states that the EU's external action would have a direct impact on the well-being of EU citizens and would also ensure security and stability. However, if we look at the situation on the Mediterranean, we get a different impression of it. So-called "sea rescuers" – who act there as helpers of criminal smuggling gangs – are not stopped. The EU Commission often even puts pressure on Member States to allow boats to land. However, this does not lead to greater security and stability in Europe. On the contrary, it is causing more and more people to make the perilous journey across the Mediterranean. And it is leading to more and more illegal mass migration, which poses intractable challenges for our nation states and, above all, for our communities. The same applies, incidentally, to the Safe Harbour initiative, which is intended to oblige municipalities to take in illegal immigrants. But such initiatives are exactly the wrong incentive. They are sending out the wrong signal and ensuring that not less, but more people are in need.

name: Janina OCHOJSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The 2018 Report on Human Rights and Democracy in the World and the European Union's policy in this area raises key issues relating to the rule of law, equality, freedom of the media and expression and freedom of thought, religion and faith, which must be strictly respected worldwide. We do not remember, or still do not remember enough, that human rights are not only a theme that was incorporated into all EU policies in 2012, but also a guarantee and basis for the proper functioning of states, societies and humanity as a whole. I therefore thank the rapporteur for taking into account my amendments, which highlighted the problem of access to water, climate change, poverty, the situation of people with disabilities and also of irregular migrants. These are very important issues for me, the importance of which should have been emphasised.  At the same time, I encourage further hard work not only by the European Parliament, but also by organisations defending democracy and human rights and monitoring the situation in this area around the world. There are still many problems, such as the rise of authoritarianism and the multitude of armed conflicts and military attacks that are consuming many lives and forcing a significant number of people to resettle. Moreover, it is worth noting that climate change and its consequences also force people to move, which in turn can lead to human rights violations.

name: Nicola BEER
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on – the report by David McAllister on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs on the annual report on the implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy (2019/2136(INI)) (A9-0054/2 019) and – the report by Arnaud Danjean on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs on the annual report on the implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy (2019/2135(INI)) (A9-0052/2019).

name: David McALLISTER
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, with this year’s annual report on the common foreign and security policy, I believe that we have once again identified the major issues our European Union is facing, and we also outline a possible way forward. The first two weeks of this new year have reminded us that the European Union’s security environment is today more volatile, more unpredictable, more complex and more ambiguous than at any time since the end of the Cold War. Let me underline the three main findings of my annual CFSP report.  Firstly, multilateralism is at stake. In such challenging times, where multilateralism is increasingly called into question, we – as a European Union – must take a firm stand against this trend, putting multilateralism at the core of our efforts to prevent and resolve conflicts. In the current setting, the CFSP must effectively promote our interests and values in our neighbourhood and around the whole world. We should take advantage of the new political cycle of our institutions to build a stronger, more proactive and strategic European Union.  Secondly, reinforcing the European Parliament as a pillar of the CFSP: during the past legislature, this European Parliament has played a prominent role in mediation in the peaceful resolution of protracted conflicts. Our efforts were successful, for instance, in Ukraine and in North Macedonia. These efforts, especially in the framework of the Jean Monnet Dialogue, should remain a priority in the upcoming years. We should also strengthen our role and oversight and scrutiny of the CFSP – but also, of course, of the EU external instruments. In this context, we must aim for a more strategic approach and greater coherence, consistency and complementarity between the external financial instruments and the common foreign and security policy.  Thirdly, strengthening the CFSP to counter global threats: I am, for example, convinced that qualified majority voting would make the EU’s foreign and security policy more effective and speed up the decision—making process. The need for unanimity is keeping us from being able to act credibly on the global stage. On the EU’s common security and defence policy, we need to strengthen capacity on EU— and Member State—level to act autonomously, as well as to foster partnerships with regional organisations. The announcement by the Commission President to build a genuine and operational European defence union within the next five years is welcome.  Finally, no single EU Member State can respond effectively to today’s global challenges on its own. We must continue to promote our European values whilst staying committed to a rules-based international order and economic cooperation. The European Union is a major player when it comes to diplomacy, trade, development cooperation, humanitarian aid and – step by step – also in the field of security and defence. Our European Union should act strategically by using its wide array of policies and instruments to respond to the challenges in our direct neighbourhood and beyond. The time has come, as the EU, to take our destiny into our own hands and embrace our role as a fully-fledged sovereign political and economic power in international relations, and I can only commend what the High Representative/Vice President has announced in the first weeks in office. I think he has a huge support here in the European Parliament. Finally, I would like to thank all our colleagues for their good contributions – especially, of course, the shadow rapporteurs – for a very good and fruitful cooperation.

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Mr High Representative, let me first of all sincerely thank all the shadow rapporteurs who, whatever their political groups and sometimes strong differences, have all sought to make substantial contributions to this annual report. This has given rise to some rather passionate exchanges, but I take this as a mark of interest for a subject that has not always aroused so much in this Chamber. In my opinion, there is room for a realistic picture of the defence situation and for pragmatic proposals for improvement. It is in any case in this spirit that I have drawn up this report, which has nevertheless been much amended. The realism of the observation is to insist on the profound degradation of our security environment. Our entire neighbourhood is in crisis; I will not go into detail on the conflicts in Syria, Libya, or Ukraine, on jihadist attacks in Europe itself, in the Horn of Africa, in the Sahel and on the boiling Middle East. The crises are simultaneous, more and more interconnected and all unfortunately reflect the desolate image of a Europe relatively powerless to contain them. The extreme volatility of the situation at our doorstep should upset our certainties and comfort, because even our alliances and partnerships are less reliable. Recent examples in the Middle East illustrate this dramatically. Many hope that this confusion is only a bad time to pass, only an unfortunate parenthesis. Maybe, but maybe not, and to tell the truth, I'd even be tempted to say, probably not. It seems to me irresponsible today when we are Europeans to think that our security will continue to be ensured eternally by others, without a substantial effort to assume our own responsibilities. The realism of the observation is therefore also that of a relative European failure to influence events, we should find ourselves around pragmatic recommendations so that Europeans can finally act and not just be outraged, condemned, deplored and commented on. Pragmatism is to be ambitious without having vain chimeras. Member States are and will remain the key players in defence. But pragmatism is also about recognising that none of them, even the most active and ambitious - and it is a Frenchman who tells you - can face the magnitude of the task alone, and you illustrated this again yesterday in Pau, Mr High Representative, about the Sahel. European collective instruments are therefore needed and support for recent initiatives must be affirmed, but we will have to be clear:01 these arrangements (European Defence Fund, permanent structured cooperation) will not in themselves make a major strategic difference in the short or even the medium term. The real question of this debate is finally relatively simple to ask: are we Europeans satisfied to be merely spectators, substitutes, even beggars of international security in the face of global and regional powers without complexes or do we finally want to be actors and give ourselves the means. I know how much debate is being debated about the concept of strategic autonomy. I just want to highlight two non-exhaustive points about this concept. First of all, it is obviously an ambition to be built and not an absolute reality today. Secondly, being autonomous does not mean putting an end to alliances or partnerships, quite the contrary, but being able to assess for themselves situations of crisis and to be able, if necessary, to respond to them alone by providing an answer in line with our interests and priorities. To see that security priorities for us Europeans are sometimes not exactly the same as those of our non-European allies is not a shameful disease, it is not a rupture, we must be able to assume it. At the beginning of the mandate, there is much talk in the Chamber of climate emergency, environmental emergency and social emergency, it seems to me that it is also urgent to consider our strategic posture and to work on it in a credible way.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: vice-président de la Commission et haut représentant de l’Union pour les affaires étrangères et la politique de sécurité. – Madame la Présidente, merci beaucoup Monsieur McAllister et Monsieur Danjean, pour le travail que vous avez fait. Nous préparons ces rapports sur la PESC (Politique étrangère et de sécurité commune) et la PSDC (Politique de sécurité et de défense commune). Permettez-moi de commencer avec le rapport PESC. Tout d’abord, je suis heureux de voir que nous continuons à porter ces valeurs au centre de notre action. Nous sommes et nous devons continuer à être une puissance basée sur des principes, et le multilatéralisme est un ordre international basé sur des règles, c’est la base de notre politique étrangère. I am also pleased that you recognise that we need to be more assertive. We now have to prove that we need to be more assertive with respect to Libya, with respect to almost everywhere, in terms of the problems we are facing. We need to be more assertive in protecting our vital interests. We live in a world of power politics and we need a truly integrated foreign policy that combines the power of Member States with the coordinated mobilisation of our instruments, and as your report states, we need to strengthen the links between internal and external policies. This has been said many times. It is good to repeat it; it would be much better to implement it. I welcome the emphasis you put on the importance of securing adequate financial resources. For external action under the next Multiannual Financial Framework, we are going to see soon if it is possible or not. In particular, we need to preserve the envelopes for the neighbourhood and sub-Saharan Africa in the new proposed instrument. Yesterday I was with the President of the French Republic and with the Presidents of the five Saharan countries, and the issue of the resources that we need in order to help them to face their security problems – which are our security problems – was on the table. I wonder if the answer we are going to be able to give to them the next day is good enough. Partnership: you rightly point out that for everything we want to do, we need partners. We want to be multilateral, but one cannot be multilateral alone. To dance the tango you need two; to be multilateral you need several. We need to link up with like-minded allies, with the regional blocs like the African Union or ASEAN, and above all, the United Nations. Take, for instance, climate change. The Council asked me at the last meeting of the European Council to develop a strong climate diplomacy in order to ensure that our climate ambitions can be shared in partnership with other states in the world, because if not, our efforts will be completely useless. We must engage with others in order to ensure that they are on board in our climate action in order for it to be really successful. Credibility: it’s clear that we will lose credibility as a geopolitical power if we cannot deliver stability and security in our immediate vicinity. If we are not able to solve or help to solve the problems of Libya or the Western Balkans, it’s going to be quite difficult to convince anyone that we are a geopolitical power. It’s clear that we must step up our support to Kenyan sovereignty and resilience. On Kosovo, we haven’t been able to travel to Kosovo because Kosovars don’t have a government, but even if they do not have a government by the end of the next month, we will have to travel to Kosovo and Serbia in order to reiterate our commitment to the European perspective for the entire region. We have some complicated relations with some of our other neighbours. Recent activities by Turkey affected the security and the interests of our Member States in the wider region and are of real concern. The central Mediterranean is suffering an extraordinary change from a geopolitical point of view, and some actors like Russia and Turkey, which were not showing up there six months ago, are now taking the lead in trying to solve this problem. You have to pay special attention, you are right, to the southern neighbourhood – Libya, Iran, Iraq – which are protagonising the debate today. We have been at the forefront of efforts aimed at de-escalation, but in the end, who is sitting at the table with Sarraj and Haftar in order to try to reach an agreement on the ceasefire is not the European Union, it’s Russia and Turkey. Africa: let’s talk a lot about Africa, a continent of both promises and challenges. The Council mandated the High Representative and the Commission to present, by the June meeting, a comprehensive action plan for Africa, and believe me, from now till June there’s not too much time to build this comprehensive action plan with Africa, because we cannot do it alone. We cannot have a plan for Africa without the Africans. It started in the Sahel, and President Macron yesterday called a very interesting meeting, asking the G5 countries of the Sahel to come and to talk about what we can do together, much as we will do the same thing in our college meeting with the African Union in Addis Ababa next February. Latin America: Latin America is burning, from Chile to Mexico. There are a lot of great difficulties there, and we should work to strengthen our cooperation. To pursue our interest in Asia, which remains stable and prosperous, maybe the most stable and prosperous region in the world today. Tomorrow we will be travelling to New Delhi to attend the Raisina Dialogue and strengthen our strategic partnership with India, and also we will do that soon with China, to prepare the summit. CSDP: the CSDP report, which addresses the impressive development of the Union’s common security and defence policy on the challenges that lie ahead. Here the urgency is clear. In a geopolitical world, the EU has no choice but to strengthen its capacities to protect itself and become a more credible security provider. The beating heart of the CSDP are today the 17 missions and operations deployed in different regions beyond our borders. And I have to salute the enthusiasm and devotion of the thousand men and women who are serving the European Union Flag in sometimes dangerous circumstances. In your report you point out, rightly, that we need to address persistent structural issues that are affecting our missions. We need to make sure that the CSDP missions become more robust, both in terms of human resources and of their mandate. I welcome the political support for the creation of the proposed off-budget European Peace Facility, designated to help our partners to take care of their own security by building their own capabilities. This is important when it’s again, for example, in the Sahel countries. Taking a greater role in the world requires developing what is called a ‘strategic autonomy’: some words that are sometimes conflictual, and not everybody understands them in the same way. This is a sensitive term, but in this context it essentially means that we have to strengthen our capacity to act with partners where possible, alone if necessary. And your report highlights that this does not mean that the European Union is forsaking its partnership; on the contrary, it will make the European Union itself a stronger global partner, and it will also benefit NATO, because a stronger European Union and a stronger NATO go hand in hand. Let me highlight the importance of the Permanent Structured Cooperation and European Defence Fund. You, the Parliament, will have to decide the amount of resources devoted to this defence fund as much as to the Peace Facility, which will be the cornerstone of our future CSDP projects. Many things can be said about what we are trying to do, and your report covers them very well. I can say that I agree a lot with everything you present in this report. I just want to stress the importance of the new frontiers of artificial intelligence, which will have geopolitical implications by empowering both competing state and hostile non-state actors. We need to remain in the lead, both in the global discussions on norms and rules as well as in the development and application of all technologies to promote our own security. I’m sure Europeans are not aware of how important this issue is: what are going to be the consequences of the developing of artificial intelligence technologies for our security in the future to come? Not a long-range future; the next five years will be decisive for that. Space and maritime are other strategic sectors where we need to ensure our coordinated use of different European Union internal and external policies and instruments. Here I would like to highlight, as your report does, that the European Union Satellite Centre will require relevant structural funding, especially from the European Union budget, to maintain its contribution to our actions. It’s becoming quite impossible to believe that we can develop actions all over the world if we are not able to observe how the world is. We have a satellite centre that cannot be lacking resources in order to fulfil its mission. In conclusion, the stakes are high and the challenges formidable. We need to keep the momentum on strengthening our common security and defence policy, and there are some problems in our immediate neighbourhood and the immediate future that will represent some proof of the capacity and the willingness of the European Union Member States to play this role. Libya: let me give this example. Just imagine that there is a ceasefire, and in Berlin we get an agreement in order to build a political solution – let’s imagine. But any ceasefire can last not a couple of weeks without a strong monitoring procedure. Are we going to be ready to do so? That’s a question that we will have to answer in the near future. (Applause)

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The call from this Parliament to our executive can only be that we finally do our own homework when our immediate interests are affected. In Libya, for example, I do not believe that we really have different interests. High Representative, please ensure, therefore, that all EU governments are on the same page, and as things stand, this can only be the side of the internationally recognised government; then it does not have to turn to Turkey for support. In the Sahel, please urge all EU governments that are able to engage in their commitment at French level and ensure that the funding for the Defence Fund and military mobility is not cut. That is very important. To end on a positive note, we should take advantage in realising that we have an island in the east of Asia where we have seen a democratic election in a Chinese society. So let's congratulate the people of Taiwan for the election that they have held: a sober and democratic one. That is a wish that we should have for the whole of eastern Asia.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, during this Plenary we adopt two important reports for our foreign policy: the report on the common foreign and security policy and our report on the common security and defence policy.  First of all, I would like to thank Mr McAllister, our rapporteur on foreign policy, for his work on this report, with which we have been able to work side by side.  These two reports are made from the absolute realization that the world facing Europe today, which is addressing Europe, is different from that which had developed over the last few decades. Competition between great powers is threatening our way of understanding the world: a world based on rules, multilateral structures, which believes that cooperating is better than competing and that rules go hand in hand with cooperation and dialogue. In the face of this finding, Europe must decide to take its own fate into its own hands. And so we make a strategic commitment, for our autonomy, for our sovereignty as a continent, to have our own capacities to defend ourselves and enforce our interests and values. It seems that Europe today is a herbivorous continent in a world of carnivores. In this reality, what it must do is mobilize sufficient resources, have new defence capabilities, also strengthen its partnerships, especially with Africa and Latin America, and coordinate its efforts, all of them those of states and those of the European Union. And for this, the high representative has a capital role for the next five years.

name: Urmas PAET
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madame President, for the European Union to be heard in global matters and be taken seriously, it needs to have one voice. This includes the areas of foreign policy, development cooperation and foreign trade, as well as security and defence policy.  Quite a lot has been done in the CSDP compared with some years ago, but more needs to be done, and this idea of common EU defence needs to be taken seriously by all EU Member States. With EU strategic autonomy being the goal, the EU can and should greatly contribute to the strengthening of European and transatlantic security. The EU must work together with NATO and like-minded partners. To have stronger EU defence does not mean undermining NATO: a stronger EU is a stronger partner for NATO, be it by bringing about more European military capabilities, investments in defence technology invention, or by some other means. Taking into account the size and capabilities of the EU, it is only elementary that it should be able to defend itself. Also for that reason, very good cooperation with NATO, the US, Canada and others is extremely important.  But to be able to defend the principles of international law and multilateralism that form the basis of the EU defence and security dimension in its international relations, the EU must have also a military capability. So the EU, in its defence policy, must aim to have everything from military capabilities in personnel and technological capabilities to an effective defence industry. This requires enough financial contributions and overcoming political disagreements, otherwise we will not have a say in matters next to big players like the US, China, Russia and other rising powers. In addition to the concept of EU defence and its substance, there are quite a few very imminent challenges we are facing that demand our attention and need to be addressed already.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work she has The acquisition of world political capability, as Jean-Claude Juncker has called it, is the centre of our common foreign and security policy. And I agree with you, Mr Borrell, that means that we must not rest in the status quo, we must be prepared to take on new responsibilities. However, we must be clear in our direction of defending our own values and interests, without falling into the trap of our own great power policy, not wanting to become the third superpower, but also preventing us from being crushed between the two existing ones. To this end, the EU must be a pillar of a multilateral order and resist development, which would make the international rule of law only a nostalgic reminder. Mr McAllister's report is a good one. Thank you very much for that. I would hope that we could also reach a much better agreement with colleagues from the national parliaments in this direction.

name: Anna BONFRISCO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mrs McAllister and Mr Danjean for their excellent work and for their reports, which help us to better understand how, for example, a few kilometres from our borders the crises in North Africa and the Middle East have developed without the European Union's efforts producing any results. After five failed years of Juncker management, Libya is now slipping into the hands of Russia, Turkey and China, while iran's much-vaunted nuclear deal crumbles at first difficulty. But the question is simple, Mr Borrell: will the political instruments and resources we devote to European industrial policy and defence, and your claim to strategic autonomy, have a real security impact for those who elected this Parliament, namely the citizens of Europe?

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I was among that small group of Conservative MEPs elected in 1999 to try to change the direction of travel of the European Union and to reform it, so as to better reflect the real concerns and aspirations of our citizens: mainly for a common market, rather than the federal obsessions of a small political elite, and to protect our national sovereignty. Nothing, perhaps, is closer to the bone of national sovereignty than our national armed forces – so increasingly, of course, the EU wants to bring them under its control. I also recognise that the top strategic priority for both the UK and the European democracies must surely be the continued, wholehearted commitment of the United States to our security and defence through NATO. My concerns on both these points were the reason that I have led the opposition to CSDP – what some might call the EU army – throughout my time in this Parliament. The reports before us advocate qualified majority voting on matters which should be national prerogatives. We find that Mr Danjean’s report is all about ‘strategic autonomy’. Basically, this means ‘separate from the United States’. It gives little thought to the implications of this; it pays lip service to NATO; it devotes one paragraph to the United Kingdom, the leading military power in Europe; it seeks a European defence union – at a stroke, the separation of Europe from our transatlantic allies, otherwise what would be the point?  The lessons of the past have not been learned. We all need to enhance our national military capabilities. We all need to be more capable and willing allies. We all need to do better in explaining the need for strong and credible defence to our citizens, but that democracies need to stand in solidarity in the great NATO alliance and not build alternative structures that will deliberately lead to division. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 171(8))

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: blue-card question. – Mr Van Orden, you have not always been with the majority on these issues and we have not shared many points of view, maybe with the exception of our view on NATO and the need to strengthen transatlantic cooperation. Will you still allow me to hope, as this is your last plenary session in this Parliament, that you will be at least a little bit nostalgic when you think back on the work that we’ve been doing together?

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: blue-card answer. – May I first of all say that I accepted your blue card, which I am very happy to do, and I was astounded in a previous debate in this Chamber so that I had two fellow countrymen who refused blue card requests from me.  I will leave this Parliament with some degree of sadness, I have to say. I spent 30 years as a soldier, I’ve spent 20 years of my life here as a politician, and we’ve achieved some good things together. But there is this whole tendency now, which is accelerating with the prospect of British departure and which is taking things in thoroughly the wrong direction, and I am very concerned about it.

name: Idoia VILLANUEVA RUIZ
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, the recent escalation of tensions we have experienced in Iran following soleimani's extrajudicial murder has placed the world in maximum tension. Do you really believe that European citizens can be given security by following Donald Trump's incendiary policy? Let us not confuse, once again, security with military operations. Security is to have institutions that provide the right to a dignified life with guarantees, with access to employment, to basic services. But security is also not to suffer or participate in military interference in another country, nor in orchestrated coups from the White House, or in drone bombardments. Security is to be an actor to ensure that international law is respected. We need to strengthen multilateralism, but that takes a look of our own, oblivious to external interests. We are at a crucial moment not only for the countries in conflict but for the European Union's own destiny and for millions of people around the world. Let us prioritize dialogue, diplomacy, democratic control of military operations. Let's bet on security. Let us bet on the just development of other countries, the care of the planet, feminism and democracy. Then we'll be betting on security.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, clear things: the two reports are preparations for new wars by the European Union. In the name of multilateral autonomous action and the new "Geopolitical Committee", together with or without NATO, it is in the interests of European groups to support their competition with their respective American, Chinese and Russian groups. More imperialist interventions are being announced in third countries, increased nato armaments, and beyond, while The European Union military mechanisms are multiplying under the umbrella of the European Defence Union, such as Pesco, the CARD-type military assessment, the Defence Fund, the European Neighbourhood Mechanism, the provocatively falsified 'Peace Mechanism', and the European Security Council are being promoted. All this has nothing to do with defending borders and sovereign rights, as the Greek governments claim, complacently. That is why the European Union is simply concerned about the arbitrary Turkish-Libyan pact. So against the plans of the imperialist wolf alliance of the European Union, the peoples fight for any change in borders and conditions that define them, by scraping all foreign bases and mechanisms.

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, the McAllister report, as well as the Danjean report, are excellent guides to moving forward, to create the vision we need to give the answers that we do not find today. I will, however, refer to the Danjean report, in particular, because it rather presents a vision, given that defence is a specific area and is at the heart of the national sovereignty of the Member States. In the field of defence, Member States have a strong mandate and do not share a common understanding of European defence. Member States have strategic differences, for example: there is no common perception of threats, there is a wide range of views on the use of military force, and there is also no common view of the role of the European Union army.  The International Institute for Strategic Studies estimates that it would take about 350 billion euros to eliminate the capability gap in a scenario where Europe would have to defend itself without the US military capabilities... (The President withdrew the speaker's word)

name: Attila ARA-KOVÁCS
text: – Madam President, dear Colleagues, On csdp, we received a fundamentally good text, thanks to Mr Danjean! And as a joint work of Parliament's political groups, a truly excellent material was finally born. As a shadow notary, I believe that we have succeeded in achieving a kind of balance, because I believe that important elements have been included in the report for all democrats in Europe, such as the necessity of implementing qualified majority decision-making and strengthening Parliament's role. Furthermore, the whole report emphasises the need and intention to achieve deeper integration.  We consider them so important because we believe in the idea of a United States of Europe, a strong Europe, and that we can act effectively in the face of security and defence policy challenges if we provide united and swift responses. Only a strong and united Europe can counter increasingly aggressive populism and cyberattacks, as well as disinformation campaigns. With this report, I feel that we are one step closer not only to our goals, but also to our dreams. That is why I ask you to support this report.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: – Madam President, in 1999, the EU thought that it had solved the Henry Kissinger question: ‘who do I call if I want to call Europe?’. A new high-profile post was created – that of the High Representative of the EU for Foreign Affairs and Security policy. Today, we all know that the Kissinger question is anything but solved. We see it today with the situation in Iran/Iraq after the death of General Soleimani: everyone is calling everyone. Mr Borrell, you go calling Mr Zarif; Charles Michel is calling Guterres, while Macron is calling Rouhani and Merkel is calling Trump and Erdoğan. We have to make things less ambiguous and more efficient – not only for the Kissingers in the world, but to better defend our European interests. Let’s call Mr Borrell, your boss, not ‘High Representative’, but just like all citizens understand, ‘EU Foreign Affairs Minister’. That I can explain to all European citizens.  ‘Give you the ability to act’. That means abolishing the unanimity rule in the European Council so that you can take the plane to Tehran or Washington tonight.  Let’s develop a true European defence union, and – if I can choose – a real European army, so that we can protect our interests, border and neighbourhood. If we could learn one thing from the Russians and Americans, it is that a strong foreign policy backed by a strong military goes to the heart of a nation. So let us fight for a stronger Europe in the world. Mr Borrell, we will fight with you here in this Parliament. (Applause)

name: Hannah NEUMANN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The situation in the Middle East reminds us once again that more weapons do not make a region safer, and what we need is, above all, mediation, disarmament and prevention. Unfortunately, however, we find little of this in Mr Danjean's CSDP report. Critical analysis of existing EU missions – misreporting, more money for crisis prevention – was rejected, even though it is in Mr McAllister's report. And with the European arms export policy, which is partly responsible for the armament, everything can supposedly remain that way. Instead, the report repeatedly calls for military spending to be increased to 2% of gross domestic product. So, and this is where our constructive cooperation really ceases, because we are concerned with a rules-based European security policy, one with an appropriate mix of civil and military measures, because that is what the European Treaties say and because that is the only way to achieve real peace. That is why we recognise Mr Danjean's attempts at conciliation, but we will vote against the report if our essential amendments are not adopted tomorrow.

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: Madam President, in the area of diplomacy, security and defence, David McAllister and Arnaud Danjean are voices that I listen to with attention and I would like to commend their work. Members of the EPP in their respective countries, they give the feeling of still believing at least a little more in the nation. Unfortunately, while I readily share the relevance of some of their analyses concerning the rise of Islamism and the demographic and migration challenge, the lessons they learn from it are incompatible with a vision of a Europe of nations cooperating freely and they succumb to federalism. To hope for the rise of the European Defence Fund, which will support programmes disconnected from the operational needs of the staffs which are and will remain national, to wish to implement the qualified majority rule on foreign and security policy issues, to evoke the strategic autonomy of the European Union, all this is to defend a project of a federal Europe. This is not the choice made by the peoples, expressed in the treaties. The rule of unanimity, which I am sure will not be called into question, guarantees the primacy of nations. Through numerous amendments, including the one aimed at limiting the eligibility of research and development programmes to European companies alone, we will try to restore these two reports to a national breath in line with the interests of the peoples.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Madam President, I will focus on the CFSP, which is my area now. There are many positive provisions in the report, for example freedom of navigation, and challenges and threats to this notion from the Strait of Hormuz to the Azov Sea. Yet I can also see red lines, for example qualified majority voting. Today’s debate on Iran assures me that we are still very divided in this area within the EU. Moreover, the introduction of qualified majority voting may harm the possibility to further strengthen multilateralism.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, this annual report on the implementation of the common security and defence policy represents the pressing demand for militarisation of EU administrators and it doesn’t seem to matter that this trend goes against the constitutional commitments of certain Member States. The establishment of permanent structural cooperation (PESCO) has raised defence cooperation to a new level, which directly threatens Irish neutrality, as described in the Constitution. With the multiplication of defence funds, which this report encourages and supports for future development, the peace project still cited by EU devotees tends to join the global upward trends in armaments. In contrast to this report, which welcomes the effective implementation of PESCO and praises its provision in the Lisbon Treaty of 2009, which makes it legally binding, we don’t agree with the external effect of this provision on the national legislation of Member States. These latest developments in the common security and defence policy have put great pressure on the concept of Irish neutrality and have brought into the national debate the questioning of the concept and the reference to certain amendments. It should be noted that the European Court of Auditors’ defence support did highlight the fact that the drive to increase the militarisation of Europe is not shared by all Member States.

name: Carles PUIGDEMONT I CASAMAJÓ
text: – Madam President, one of the strongest assets of our union is our soft power: our credibility in the defence of democracy and human rights in order to defend minorities and democratic opposition to totalitarianism around the world. This is why we should question ourselves. Imagine what we would say if the United Nations Working Group on Arbitrary Detention said that a third country had imprisoned nine people unfairly and that they should be liberated. We would be outraged; our Chamber would protest; the Commission would make a strong statement on political threats. What if one of these countries was a Member State? All this has happened in Spain, and therefore I am very interested to know if there is a double standard when these things happen within the European Union. Double standards are one of the worst problems for the democratic credibility of our foreign policy, and the Commission must require of the Member States the same criteria that it requires of the rest of the world.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support The main objective of our external security policy must be to ensure the safety of our citizens. This requires eradicating terrorism, effectively protecting our external borders, halting illegal migration and preventing new waves of migration from arriving, avoiding regional conflicts. This is all necessary to preserve peace and stability. The implementation of a common European defence system in the common security policy is to be welcomed. But in the meantime, strengthening our defence capabilities requires national efforts. Therefore, my country is currently under a large-scale force development programme and we will spend 2% of our GDP on defence spending by 2024.  The role of the Western Balkans region and the trust of its peoples are key for the Union and enlargement must therefore be taken seriously, opening accession negotiations with Albania and Northern Macedonia as soon as possible. At the same time, I must say that I do not agree with the transition to qualified majority voting, as this would take away the opportunity, especially from the smaller Member States, to display their sovereign national interests equally on issues that are important to them.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Dear Chairman, congratulations to the rapporteurs on a job well done. The report on the implementation of the Common Foreign and Security Policy was adopted consensually. It highlighted the role of the European Union not only in promoting peace and security, but also as a responsible actor in exacerbated global circumstances.  Regarding the Joint Security and Defence Policy Implementation Report, I hope that we will adopt this report in a similar way in the future. I support the continued work on developing Europe's strategic capacities.  In growing instability, as evidenced by the first weeks of this year, the European Union must act faster, stronger and more constructively, in a spirit of multilateralism, to promote key European values of peace, cooperation and progress. The response to many challenges is strategic autonomy with a pronounced need for the Union to better coordinate existing and continue to develop its own security and defence capabilities.  I believe that more emphasis should be placed on the Western Balkans as a priority of the Common Foreign Security and Defence Policy. A stable neighbourhood is a guarantor and a stable European Union. Activity, cooperation and a European perspective are messages that we must send to our partners in the south-east.  I am confident that our new High Representative will also be committed to advocating for a strong Europe in the multilateral world, as there are many challenges, and our citizens expect decisive and timely action, of course, in line with our principles.

name: Nathalie LOISEAU
text: Madam President, Mrs von der Leyen has announced a Geopolitical Commission and the state of the world agrees with her. Europe is surrounded in its close neighbourhood by conflicts that are stretching and spreading: in Syria, Libya, the Middle East, Ukraine, the Sahel, the crises are dragging on and affecting us all. We need to get out of the 'time of innocence', where the European project, because it is a peace project, should not be concerned with defence. I welcome the realism and ambition of the reports on the CFSP and the PSDC, which are subject to our votes. They remind us of the importance of our alliances and our commitment to effective multilateralism, but they also call for building a robust European defence that allows us, at the same time, to fulfil our commitments to our allies and to act autonomously whenever the defence of our interests requires it. Europe's strategic autonomy has now become a burning necessity. We must stop blaming our American allies for overdoing it or not doing enough in crises and in areas that directly affect us. We must do our part, all our part, in the prevention of conflicts but also in their resolution, by making use of all the instruments that are at our disposal. Let us be mediators, let us be facilitators, but let us also be actors in the return to peace when our interests are at stake. We must accept to weigh with all the political weight that our economic power gives us. We can no longer leave it to other powers to shape our geopolitical environment without our voice being heard: Europe is used to speaking, of speaking again, it is time for it to start acting.

name: Filip DE MAN
text: Mr President, I hear a lot of expensive words and fine principles here, but above all a lot of woolly talk. Indeed, the greatest threats to our security are the rampant mass immigration and Islamisation and the increasing number of terrorist attacks that result from mass immigration. The EU's security, defence and foreign policy so far has not reduced these threats, quite the contrary.  We therefore propose that the sovereignty of the Member States should not be undermined and that the EU should not impose mandatory policies. Cooperation must, of course, be there in terms of material and so on. There must be information exchange between Member States. All this is effective in the fight against – as I said – the major threats: mass immigration, Islamisation and terrorism.  Our recommendations are therefore clear: no further enlargement of the Union, an end to rapprochement with Turkey and closer cooperation with partners such as Russia and the United States.

name: Charlie WEIMERS
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for When I came to Brussels about five years ago, I had a pretty clear idea of what the common foreign and security policy would mean. It was a fundamentally intergovernmental cooperation where we could make efforts together, but where Sweden and other countries could conduct an independent foreign policy. Quickly I realized that this house was trying to counter that concept with all its might.  Instead, it wanted to give the EU military power, and it was a kind of alliance between federalist and anti-American forces that drove that development. They wanted to shift power over these policies to Brussels – as has happened in so many other areas.  Last year we read in the resolutions on European armed forces, now we are reading about strategic autonomy and how qualified majority voting should replace national vetoes. This is something that jeopardises transatlantic cooperation, and which lacks popular support.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: – Madam President, the European Union is a political project based on the rule of law and the rule of law. It was founded to overcome and to combat even radical nationalisms. In Europe there is no place for those who do not respect the law or the rule of law, who mock it, who trampl it, even who flee it. In this Chamber today we have to listen to a fugitive from justice, whose only destiny is the courts to answer for their crimes.  And now I move on to the debate before us today, Mr Borrell. We are in a very complex, interconnected, multipolar world. The European Union has to be a global, effective player in order to defend its interests and values. Separated we will fall into irrelevance. I have to thank both Mr McAllister and Mr Danjean for their respective reports. These are full reports, which also insist, in addition, on Mr Danjean's, also on the defence dimension, which is increasingly relevant to the European Union and where progress has been made lately - fortunately too.

name: Sven MIKSER
text: – Madam President, let me limit my remarks to the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) report. Our Union started off as – and continues to be – primarily a peace project. In the area of defence, we are a bit of a late starter and that’s probably why there still appear to be colleagues who are very uncomfortable with discussing defence and the European Union in the same sentence.  I believe there are at least two different strains of critics of the EU’s defence ambitions. First, there are good people who seemed to sincerely believe that all conflicts in the world can be resolved without any use of military force at all. Secondly, there are those who insist that the EU should leave all military operations to the Atlantic Alliance. I do not believe in the first category, and as to the second, well, while I do believe it’s preferable, when possible, to act in unison with our friends and allies on the other side of the Atlantic, I’m afraid that there will be occasions when we have to act on own, and so we also need the means to be able to do so. In this Chamber, I’ve heard many colleagues lament the limited role our Union plays in helping to resolve the world’s crisis and conflicts. The limited ability to play a role is in remarkable contrast with the ambition we have expressed, including in our global strategy. Being able to meet our ambition is dependent on us having the necessary capabilities, which do not come for free. They don’t even come cheap. So if we really do not want our calls for a greater role in global affairs to ring empty, we will have to be ready to provide the necessary resources.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, let me thank both rapporteurs for the excellent work they have done. The EU’s common foreign security and defence policies must be accompanied by a mutual understanding of prevailing challenges and by joint action. In addition to boosting and ensuring the interoperability of our security and defence capabilities, we must be prepared to address challenges unravelling in close proximity to our borders.  For this reason, the South and East Neighbourhood Policies should effectively combine political financial security and the defence dimensions. It is time for the action—based EU partnerships with aspiring democratic neighbours. The list of such valuable partners is shrinking dangerously and they deserve a corresponding status in our European policies.  Moreover, economic interests should not overtake our security concerns. It’s self—deceiving to think that such projects as Nord Stream 2 are only about the economy. On the contrary, it enables Russian geopolitical interests to employ destructive policies in Libya and Syria.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Madam President, with the aspiration of our new geopolitical Commission to improve the European Union’s external policy and our positions and impact on the global level, this debate on the two reports is a great opportunity for us to reflect upon Parliament’s view of the common foreign security and defence policy.  I would like to congratulate Mr David McAllister and Mr Arnaud Danjean on the excellent reports that they have done. In these first reports, the European Parliament clearly recognises and explicitly underlines that no European country is able by itself to address the foreign policy and security challenges we are facing. For me, the key issue in this regard is EU relations with the Western Balkans. Apart from the overall common foreign and security policy objectives, we should guide these countries towards the accession they deserve. In the meantime, we continue with the common security and defence missions, such as Operation Althea (EUFOR) in Bosnia and Herzegovina. It’s a first European mission that works well on our continent and plays a pivotal role for the security and stability of the EU and the European continent as a whole. We as a Parliament should do everything within our possibilities to show our support for the region’s European perspective, and in this regard, we should strengthen Parliament’s involvement in the external financial instruments. As the co-rapporteur of the Instrument for Pre-accession Assistance (IPA) III, I strongly advocate that Parliament needs an improved oversight and increased role during the scrutiny and the steering of the programmes. In our immediate neighbourhood, the Western Balkans region belongs in the European Union and it’s a security issue. It’s about time that our institution embraced that fact and works towards this enlargement and to finish the business that has been started.

name: Joachim SCHUSTER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I believe there can be no doubt that we need to deepen cooperation in security and defence policy. Under Trump, the US has become an unpredictable ally, Russia sees military intervention as a normal means of asserting its own interests, and many conflicts in our immediate neighborhood are fought militarily. But what is crucial is not only that Europe cooperates more closely in the field of defence, but also how it does, and there are already differences here. I cannot understand at all, for example, why the intensification of cooperation should be accompanied by a drastic increase in the cost of armaments. First of all, THE military expenditure of the EU states is already many times that of Russia's military expenditure. Secondly, if European arms cooperation is to be more efficient than parallel national development, why do we need even more money for armaments than we do today? And thirdly, the current conflicts that exist are usually not to be resolved either militarily or through more armament. We need a closer European security and defence policy, focusing on diplomacy, strengthening international institutions, limiting arms, disarmament and clearly limiting arms exports.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Madam President, Mr Borrell, I want to thank the rapporteurs Mr McAllister and Mr Danjean for their comprehensive reports. Indeed, the multilateral order is changing. It is put under question by multiple conflicts, hybrid wars and terrorism. In this complicated situation the EU is obliged to play a global role in order to protect its citizens but also democracy, rule of law, the respect for human rights and global cooperation. The Middle East is burning, Africa is starving and our neighbours on east and south need EU support because the events there have a direct impact here. Therefore, the EU needs to revise and strengthen its neighbourhood policy by supporting the sovereignty and territorial integrity, promoting stability and fostering cooperation with the countries. Moreover, the EU urgently needs a credible EU enlargement strategy in the Western Balkans as enlargement has been, and will continue to be, one of our best foreign policy tools. We must deliver on what we have promised to the region and keep the European perspective of the Western Balkans alive.

name: Andrius KUBILIUS
text: – Madam President, I would like first of all to thank my colleagues for the really very good reports. I will make just three remarks.  First, the first goal of our foreign and security policy should be very clear: Europe whole, free, and at peace. The only effective policy to achieve this is enlargement and integration. This is how even the success of Ukraine can be created, and the success of Ukraine is the only instrument whereby the House can assist with the long-term transformation of Russia back towards democracy.  Second, it’s time to go to qualified majority voting on security and foreign policy issues, otherwise we shall have the strategic autonomy to make empty statements but without strategic autonomy of real strength and power. Finally, when we are speaking about European strategic autonomy and NATO, I would suggest that you use much clearer language. We need NATO and American nuclear deterrents on the European continent because of an aggressive and nuclear Russia. And because the EU’s neighbourhood is becoming more unstable, we also need to have the real strategic autonomy of our diplomatic and military forces to stabilise our neighbourhood.

name: Raphaël GLUCKSMANN
text: Madam President, thank you to our two rapporteurs. The fables of the 90s about the end of history or the happy globalization of rights and freedoms are definitely to be thrown in the trash. Today, we have to decide. Deciding whether we will remain forever teenagers who pay each other with words and who, with each crisis, will join the arms of Dad America or if we want to become real adults. If we want to become adults, if we want to build European strategic autonomy, if we want to be independent, if we want to weigh in this dangerous world, then we must give the means to build this European defence, because the current situation is untenable. We cannot have French soldiers dying in the Sahel, countries that spend large sums of money in their budgets to build this European defence and other countries that pretend that the end of history is always a valid myth. It is therefore important to choose and I thank the rapporteurs for their clear language.

name: Lukas MANDL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I shall be voting in favour of both reports, and I thank David McAllister and Arnaud Danjean for these reports, especially for the formulation that 'the security situation around Europe has deteriorated dramatically'. That is a mandate for us, and that is a mandate for the European Commission and, in particular, for the Council. For this and other reasons, we need a new EU Treaty. The Treaty of Lisbon is old, it cannot keep up with today's challenges. We need a Europe with more external strength and more internal freedom. A new EU treaty must also provide that the principle of unanimity on foreign policy and security issues falls in the Council, that it is finally possible for Europe to be able to take decisions.  It's like personal life: not making a decision at all is often the worst decision. Europe must be able to take decisions and, High Representative, I expect – and I think I am speaking on behalf of many in Parliament, we will see it in the report decision – that you take care of this and, in particular, security and defence policy, as provided for by your mandate from the President of the Commission.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Madam President, outbreaks of instability are multiplying around us. This new reality highlights the need for a single foreign and defence and security policy. Unfortunately, we are far from that objective, under the responsibility of powerful states, and this has very serious consequences today. With your will, you have allowed matters of the utmost importance for the security of the peoples of Europe to be handled by Trump, Poutine and Erdoğan. Some people overlook this view, because you simply do not border on countries that do not respect international law. Greece, for example, spends a very significant chunk of its budget on equipment, reducing funding for the social state, health and education. However, it is not for some people alone to bear the full burden of protecting common borders in the face of common threats. It's time to do what you didn't do in the past. It's a matter of justice and solidarity. The Union should become strategically autonomous and develop its own defence structures. Something that today seems utopian is a one-way street for the future.

name: Kris PEETERS
text: Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the two rapporteurs for their excellent report, and it goes without saying, of course, that we are experiencing geopolitical stormy times. The multilateral world order is shaking at its foundations, organisations such as the UN and NATO are no longer a beacon for stability, agreements are ignored and agreements terminated. However there is no better world order possible than a multilateral world order. In order to strengthen multilateralism, the EU lacks a military capability that can be deployed quickly and autonomously. A number of steps have already been taken, but the ultimate goal, European strategic autonomy in defence, has not yet been achieved. I call on the Member States to put the European goal first in consultation, so that at the end of this mandate we have an efficient, effective and flexible common European defence, because in May 2018 51 million EU citizens voted for the EU to take action on security and defence.

name: Juozas OLEKAS
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank both rapporteurs for a  very good job, but, if the European Union would like to play a real role in today’s challenging world, if we have the ambition to be ahead not only in this role, first of all, of course we should strengthen our diplomatic and economic activities trying to de-escalate the situation around the EU borders, but this is not enough because in our neighbourhood we have unpredictable regimes in Syria, Iraq, Iran and Russia. We should increase our resilience and build up capabilities. Authoritarian regimes understand only dialogue with powerful players and if we would like to be an autonomous powerful actor, we need to allocate enough resources to build effective capabilities, and for that to allocate resources, and 2% from GDP for defence in each Member State should be our nearest target.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Firstly, I would like to congratulate the report-takers on these reports. Both the European Union and Hungary support ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity, a negotiated solution to the conflict in eastern Ukraine, so that peace and security can be found in the country as soon as possible. I welcome the relaust of the process of resolving the conflict with the Normandy Four meeting, which resulted in another prisoner exchange on 29 December. I hope that this conflict, which has been going on for several years, will be put to an end quickly. In order to resolve the internal tensions in the country, which is the result of the nationalist policies of the previous government and the legislation that limited fundamental minority rights, I see that President Zelensky is also attempting to unite ukrainian citizens in his New Year's greeting speech, despite the differences between them, which is a positive sign, and I hope that the legislation will reflect this.  The European Union must play an active role in promoting peace outside its borders, but it must take more effective steps to enforce human and minority rights and democratic principles, which are also the main instruments of stability.

name: Vladimír BILČÍK
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank both rapporteurs for excellently balanced reports, and let me make a couple of remarks on the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP). I want to welcome the rapporteur’s horizontal approach. It’s important to strengthen the EU’s tools and institutions if we are to defend multilateralism, respect for international law and Europe’s strategic interests around the world. In particular, we must uphold our commitment to the European Union’s neighbourhood. The neighbourhood is the testing grounds for the common foreign and security policy. Most tangibly, Europe – not Russia, not Turkey, not China – must succeed in the Western Balkans. Here, I want to underline the EP’s role in the resolution of political crises in the neighbourhood, but the EP alone will not succeed. We need to join forces, Mr High Representative, with the Commission, with the Member States, in order to bring tangible and concrete results and to put the European perspective on the ground in the Western Balkans. Only concrete results will convince those who doubt Europe’s international role, and we must achieve it this year.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, the Netherlands and most European Member States are now defending themselves within the framework of NATO, and I would like to keep it that way. And that is because, in the end, in that partnership, it is the national parliaments that decide on the deployment of their wives and men to dangerous areas. I very much hope, of course, that my country, among others, will now quickly meet the two percent standard for NATO defence policy.  It is true that in the annual report that is now before us, there is absolutely no idea that there should be a European army, but de facto, among other things, paragraphs 116, 118 and 120 do open the doors to such an army. I find that a little complicated. I think NATO is very important and fortunately important words are being given to NATO, and I would like to keep it that way.

name: Loucas FOURLAS
text: Madam President, in order to take a position on this subject, we must first ask ourselves: 'What Europe do we want?', 'what Europe do we need?' "How do we want to build our common home?" For me, ladies and gentlemen, the answer is very simple: We need a strong Europe, a Europe that does not need third parties to guarantee its security, because it can do so itself; a Europe that no third country can threaten and blackmail, either by hitting a Member State or by refugee flows, without repercussions. We need a Europe where every Member State, however small, has an equal voice; a Europe where citizens take part in decisions about their common future. This is the Europe we need. For this Europe we must fight. This Europe must be the common future of all of us.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, Vice-President Borrell, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work A picture says more than a thousand words, and the picture that you have sat on the one hand, on the commission's side, in the debate on Iraq and Iran today, and that you are changing seats during your stay in the European Parliament in this debate on the common security and defence policy, shows that we do not have a common foreign, security and defence policy. This is shown in this picture, it expresses the rift. And when we are torn, we are not credible. When we are torn, we are incapable of acting. And if we want to make the Commission the spokesman for the continent in the world and the European Union fit for world policy, we need a common foreign, security and defence policy. I ask you to do everything possible to make us a defence union, a security union, a political union. They play a very important role in this debate. Please quit the game of seat change, take off your various hats and promote this strong Europe in the world.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Madam President, first of all I would like to thank the efforts of my dear colleagues Danjean and Mr McAllister, who are truly worthy of congratulations, for the excellent report that each of them has already done. I believe that strong defence and security in the European Union is the huge deficit that the European Union carries on its shoulders, it is the big bob, it is the big stigma. As early as yesterday, the European Union had to have defence and security. We're already late! In order to be able to protect its borders, as it proclaims, and to safeguard, as is its obligation and duty, the sovereignty of its Member States, it must allocate money from the budget and start building its defence and security from now on.  No Turkey could have imagined that it would invade Syria and Libya, that it would hold Cyprus, that it would invade the Cypriot EEZ, that it would threaten European Union countries if there was this defence and security of the European Union. But I believe that, until we reach uniform defence and security, the Member States of the European Union must react. And it would be a good step, Mr Borrell, if there were a first decision by the Member States, in the context of solidarity, to react united against any attack on a Member State of the European Union and a violation of its sovereignty, and that reaction to be by all means.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: – Mr President, in recent years the European Union's common security and defence policy has taken truly positive steps. Nevertheless, if the European Union wants to be a strong, united, credible global player, we must be able to respond much more quickly and coherently to crises. And that won't work if unanimity is required. That is why I very much support the principle raised by the Committee on Foreign Affairs in its own report – that we need to move on to qualified majority voting on issues where this is already possible without any agreement having to be amended. These issues include, at least, issues relating to human rights, economic sanctions or civilian security policy operations. This change could be made very simply by decision of the leaders of the EU Member States. I therefore encourage the Commission and the High Representative to take this forward in order to speed up decision-making, to be a stronger, more cohesive actor and to act credibly in global for a.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, first of all my congratulations to my two rapporteur colleagues. A few years ago, the formulation of a common foreign and security policy for the European Union would have been an ultra-aspiring theory. Today, developments and conditions of globalisation require this if the European Union wants to maintain its economic stability and soundness but also to safeguard European and international law. In particular, without energy security, for example, we are vulnerable to threats and blackmail. But action requires protection and security from military threats and terrorist attacks. For peace, it is not enough for us to want it. Those who still call Erdoğan a strategic partner will unfortunately regret it.  Mr Borrell, I’ll say this in English: Libya, Syria, Afrin, northern occupied Cyprus, the Aegean and the eastern Mediterranean. The problem has a name: expansionist neo—Ottoman Turkey.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, the Annual Report on the Implementation of the Common Security and Defence Policy again contains a section on the Western Balkans, which apostrophies the importance of this part of Europe for the security and stability of the European Union and stresses the need for stronger engagement by the Union, inter alia, through EU missions. I can agree that peace and stability in our immediate neighbourhood is a priority, both for my Croatia and for the entire European Union. However, I believe that serious progress in the countries of the so-called Western Balkans cannot and will not be achieved by pampering autocratic leaders as it is in the case of Serbia or by ignoring the systematic violation of the political rights of the Croatian people as it is in the case of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Indeed, the Union can contribute to the progress of these countries and to improving relations in this part of Europe, but not by turning a blind eye to the problem, but by entering their core and actively working to eliminate them.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, in contrast to this report, I don’t welcome the implementation of PESCO, I don’t praise its provision in the Lisbon Treaty – something we had to be forced to vote on twice in Ireland – and I’m deeply concerned at the developments in the common security and defence policy, which have put tremendous pressure on the concept of Irish neutrality, and we will be strenuously resisting any attempts to move to qualified majority voting. The militarisation of the European Union and the drive to a European army is something that is not in the interests of the citizens. A new EU white paper on security and defence, as required by the report, would be a new step, not a favourable step, a step that seems to be pushed by France. Interestingly, 13 of the new projects involved in the PESCO pact approved last month were French ones. Macron seems to be very determined to arm Europe while he’s ignoring the pensions at home. If we want to make Europe safe, let’s stop interfering in other countries. The report should be mentioning Article 2(4) of the UN Charter, limiting the use of force against the territorial integrity of sovereign states. If you want to be safe, that’s what you’ve got to do.

name: Özlem DEMIREL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her PESCO, military mobility, armoured roads, combat troops of all kinds and the European Defence Fund are just a few of the buzzwords. What is clear is that the EU should now cut back on social and regional funding projects in order to throw billions into the throats of the arms lobby. They are thus violating European law, because Article 41(2) prohibits expenditure from the EU budget on military action. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, it is true! The world political situation is fragile and there are many conflicts. However, simply mentioning them in the report without mentioning the role of the EU and the Member States seems hypocritical. EU economic policy, trade policy or an increasing increase in arms exports from the Member States in hot fires are also exalongerting these conflicts in the world. If you are serious about peace and democracy, we must put an end to arms exports all over the world, and then we must put an end to this insane spiral of armament. Stop transforming the EU into a military union, defend disarmament treaties and expand them. That would be a sustainable security policy and not what you are doing. This is rather dangerous.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. Madam President, I thank the two rapporteurs. I think these are two very interesting contributions to the great debate on the European Union's foreign security policy. Someone said, 'You were sitting there, you changed places.' Yes, this is the Commission, this is the Council, and you are well aware that the High Representative is both someone who represents the Council and someone who sits on the Commission. Therefore, as long as that is the case, I will have to change places and that is not the case, we will have to change the treaties and, believe me, we will not do it tonight because it takes a little longer. I do not understand some Members who are afraid that we will build a monster in the service of multinationals or that we are going straight to the federalist cliff: today, whether we like it or not, the Commission, a federalising body, or at least a Community body, has no competence in foreign and defence policy. You could say: it is strange, if it does not have the competences, why was the Defence Union created? Because the Defence Union has nothing to do with defence policy but with defence industrial policy. It is based on defence and the defence industry, but defence is still a separate thing. So, like it or not, today we are in a world where the common foreign policy is managed unanimously by the Council. It is still a far cry from what you call "federal." What kind of federalism is that?  The same goes for defence policy. I do not understand the fear that some people have when they say, ''We are going to rush into the black hole of federalism'. We're a long way from that. I believe that the European Union needs to deepen the dimension of its capacity to act together in the world. I honestly believe that, but I think some members of this Parliament do not believe it. Frankly, I believe in it and I defended it when I ran for the position. I believe that we Europeans, through our Union, must be able to have a more determined and stronger action on the international stage, and that is why we are trying to work together, by defining a common policy. However, common does not mean unique. Remember, when we had the common currency, it was not unique. We had the shield and everyone still had their change. For some things we worked together and for others, each at home. How long did it take Europe to move from the common currency to the single currency?
