How long did it take for Member States to renounce monetary sovereignty? Twenty years? More than that. And money, while being a symbol of sovereignty, is not even the strongest symbol.  Defence, peace or war, international relations, the defence of the interests of every country in the world, all this is much closer to sovereignty. It is therefore not surprising that it takes time to move from the common policy to the single one. This report shows us very well what the difficulties are and, believe me, I was confronted with them in person. When we try to discuss a subject as close to us as the situation in Libya, we immediately find different national positions. And that's where our weakness lies. It will certainly be a long road, but in my opinion we must build common capacities in order to have the opportunity to decide, not unanimously, but by qualified majority. These reports show a bit of a way with all the difficulties. That is why I welcome them and thank the authors. I hope to have the opportunity to discuss this further and directly because the future of Europe will be built around its capacity to act in the world. It is impossible to believe that we will solve problems within our borders.  Everything requires action to the rest of the world. Everything: climate change, migration, today everything is geopolitical, that's the buzzword. And it's true, everything is geopolitical. And to be a true geopolitical player, you have to have powerful military and diplomatic capabilities. It is often said that you have to choose between being an "actor" (player) or a playfield. I think, for my part, that we are an actor, but an actor in search of identity. We don't know yet what kind of actor we want to be. It is through such reports that this existential question for the future of the Union can be deepened. I thank all the Members who wanted to participate in this debate. It's a pity there's no no more Members interested in a debate of this importance. Thank you for staying until 10 p.m. to follow a very interesting and decisive debate for the future of our society in a world in difficulty.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, the High Representative and Vice—President just spoke about many issues. Since we're running late, I would suggest that I keep it very short. I would just like to thank you all for your contributions. I would like to thank you for an honest and open debate. It was a pleasure for me to witness that a majority of speakers in this House is in favour of acting towards a stronger common foreign and security policy of our European Union. A lot of work lies ahead of us. I have, in particular, the ongoing negotiations on the next multiannual financial framework in mind in these upcoming negotiations. Dear Mr Borrell, we not only have to ensure the adequate financing but also the coherence, the effectiveness, the responsiveness and the flexibility of our external financing instruments. Let me also finally thank the High Representative – not only we are still here in the plenary but also he himself, for many, many hours now. I think this shows the respect that the High Representative is showing for the European Parliament.

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, thank you to all the colleagues who took part in this debate. There have been many interesting contributions I regret that some interventions are always marked by a kind of trial of intent. I find that our reports are not ideological relationships. These are rather pragmatic reports that point the finger at a reality, which is that of an extremely troubled world, in which Europe must be able to play a role, including on the military level. I hear colleagues indignant at the militarisation of the European Union: it is a fable, it is a view of the mind! I hear a colleague say that we need to rebalance things between the civilian and the military in the common security and defence policy. But if we rebalance the civilian and the military in the common defence security policy, we must do a lot more military because today, the common security and defence policy is almost exclusively civilian! We have 11 civilian missions in the CSDP and five are military, so we have to be careful what we say. The reality is not exactly what has been described by some colleagues and it is a bit of a pity because, once again, I have acquired my convictions on this subject in contact with reality, exercising modest responsibilities but in just about every crisis area in which the European Union is present. I see everywhere the need for Europe but for Europe in the form of its Member States, in the form of the Commission, in the form of joint troops or national troops. I was going to say, whatever, let's be pragmatic. But there is a need for Europe. To my colleagues who are concerned about decoupling with NATO: no one replaces NATO in terms of collective security, but on the other hand there are places where NATO cannot intervene or places where NATO has no interest in intervening. I hear, earlier this week, President Trump announce that American troops will drastically withdraw from Africa, thus Somalia, Mali, Niger. And we have to rely on the Americans? Of course we have to be able to take on responsibilities on our own, that is exactly what I said in my opening remarks. There are places where priorities are not the same, that does not mean that we are not allies or that a historical relationship is being challenged. It is simply common sense that Europe must be able to affirm, display and assume its priorities and interests where others are not able to do so alongside us. This seems to me to be a matter of course and common sense, and if we do not want to disappear from the geopolitical map, it is a responsibility that we must assume.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place on Wednesday 15 January 2020. Before moving on to the Libya report, allow me to inform you on behalf of the EPP Group that the President has been informed that decisions have been taken to amend appointments to committees and delegations. These decisions will be included in the minutes of today's meeting and will enter into force on the day of the announcement.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Libya (2019/2984(RSP)).

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: VPC/HR. – Señora presidenta, señores diputados, las cosas en Libia están yendo desde lo malo a lo peor. Quizá en los próximos días podamos tener algún rayo de esperanza, pero desde las Navidades los ataques de las fuerzas de Haftar se han intensificado, los bombardeos sobre áreas civiles también. La matanza de treinta militares cadetes en la escuela militar de Trípoli. Condenamos este ataque. Pero nos pasamos el día condenando ataques. Y el coste humano de esta guerra por delegación está empezando a ser insoportable para el pueblo libio. Bueno, hace tiempo que es insoportable. Hay trescientas cincuenta mil personas desplazadas en el entorno de Trípoli, miles de combatientes, trescientos civiles muertos, ataques a hospitales, incluyendo personal sanitario y ambulancias, doscientas cincuenta escuelas cerradas. The war has been fuelled by several external players sending more weapons and mercenaries every day. It is no longer the war without warriors, as it was called at the beginning – a war without warriors. No – now there are a lot of warriors coming from many different countries, and it has become expanding and escalating, augmenting the risk of terrorism, regional instability, migration in our borders. The United Nations special envoy, Mr Salamé, came on Friday to the Foreign Affairs Council, and he said that no other conflict ever saw a gap between nice words and helpful actions so wide as in Libya. Since April, the United Nations Security Council met 15 times to discuss about Libya and failed 15 times to call for a ceasefire. The Security Council: 15 times. But as I said, there is hope that a ceasefire maybe can enter into force. We hoped it was going to enter into force yesterday, but this morning we knew that there was no agreement in Moscow and that General Haftar left Moscow without giving his agreement to this ceasefire. We have been repeating many times that the Europeans have to overcome our divisions, our rivalries, and that we have to be more united in order to face the situation. Germany is about to announce (I don’t know if it has already formally announced – there were some rumours that it was going to be announced today, but I don’t know exactly) if there is a formal call for the Berlin Conference for next Sunday, after months of preparations, in which we have actively taken part. It should give way to a roadmap for the consolidation of the ceasefire, de-escalation and a return to political negotiations. This could be a good occasion. The Special Envoy was coming here on Friday, Prime Minister Sarraj of the internationally-recognised government was in Brussels. He visited President Sassoli and President Michel; we passed the same message. It was impossible to have a meeting with the other party, with General Haftar. We have been talking with several regional colleagues – Egyptian, Russian and Turkish counterparts. Everybody seems at least a bit concerned that things in Libya are getting out of control. But I cannot assure you that the ceasefire will take place and that the Berlin Conference will take place next Sunday. At the last Foreign Affairs Council, I called for talks about Libya and Iran. We strongly supported the Berlin process. We tried to travel to Libya, but it was not possible due to security reasons; I wonder if it was really for security reasons or there was a lack of will to receive us. The fact is that we had to meet here in Brussels, where we had the visit of Sarraj but not the one from Haftar. Now we have a mandate from the Foreign Affairs Council to strongly engage with all parties. If there is a ceasefire, and if there is an agreement on the framework of the Berlin process, then we will have to deal with monitoring the ceasefire and effectively controlling the arms embargo. But I wonder who is going to do that seriously. We are spending a lot of money in Libya: more than 630 million in cooperation in the last five years. The African Union-United Nations agencies have been able to evacuate more than 5 000 people needing international protection and sent over 50 000 migrants back home voluntarily, with reintegration support. But there are 700 000 sub—Saharan people in Libya. Not all of them want to go to Europe; most of them have a job and a livelihood, and they prefer to stay in Libya as far as the conditions allow them to do so. But if the situation becomes worse and it is impossible for them to stay in Libya, maybe they can try to go to Europe. So there is another threat of a push of illegal migration through the central Mediterranean, where the Turks and the Russians are taking the lead. Six months ago in the central Mediterranean these two actors were not present, but today they take the lead, and this is a big change in the geopolitical structure in the Mediterranean basin. Six months ago we Europeans were more or less active but we were alone. Now, we are still more or less active – more active today then six months ago – but in fact the Russians and the Turks are having a strong leverage because they have engaged militarily on the ground. Not directly, not through the regular army, but everybody knows that the flow of arms is increasing, and Libya is a kind of cancer which has been metastasizing to Sahel. What’s happening in Sahel has a lot to do with the fact that the big amount of arms and the fighters in Libya are contaminating the whole area. Now intelligence reports tell us that a lot of Sudanese, Syrian and people coming from the Middle East are arriving in Libya to fight on one side or the other. This is the situation. Maybe we will have good news in the next 24 hours, maybe not. Maybe the Germans will call for the conference, maybe not. Maybe we are going to have a ceasefire, maybe not. I really don’t know. I hope that we will have a window of opportunity. Libya is a rich country, one of the richest countries in Africa, despite years of civil strife: rich and with a small population, only 6 million people, who could and should lead a secure and prosperous life. Instead, it is entering the ninth year of an immensely destructive and disruptive political crisis. It was never going to be easy for Libya to emerge from 40 years of an annihilating dictatorship and miraculously become a stable democracy. It was going to be difficult, we knew, but no one ever imagined a catastrophe like this – and yet it could become even worse for the Libyans, and for us, if we do not try our very best to halt this conflict and find a political solution. With the support of all Member States and of the Parliament, for sure, I really intend to do just that, hoping that this strong engagement can be part of the solution to keep Libya united and to look for a peaceful solution to this conflict, because we are saying that there is no military solution. But this mantra – there is no military solution – we have been repeating about the Syrian war. ‘There is no military solution, there is no0 military solution’ – and at the end there has been a military solution. So maybe here the same thing can happen. We Europeans, since we don’t want to participate in a military solution, we barricade ourselves in the belief that there is no military solution. In Syria there has been a military solution brought about by the Turks and the Russians, and this has changed the equilibrium in the eastern part of the Mediterranean. I cannot prevent such a thing happening, and this is something that should be of very great concern to all of us, because I’m sure nobody will be very happy if in the Libyan coast there is a ring of military bases from the Russian and Turkish navy in front of the Italian coast, controlling both routes of illegal migration towards Europe in the eastern Mediterranean and now maybe in the central Mediterranean. At this time, at this hour – 10 o’clock at night – I think we can speak frankly among all of us and deal seriously with the situation we are facing. Let’s hope that we are going to have good news in the next hours.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. We have just heard it from the High Representative: there is a political drama taking place in Libya, a political and humanitarian drama – right on our doorstep. For far too long, this drama has received far too little attention. The United Nations figures are well known: since The start of General Haftar's offensive in April, more than 1,100 people have lost their lives, there are more than 340 000 internally displaced people, and 900 000 people are in need of humanitarian aid, two thirds of them women and children. The need is great. I believe that the ceasefire in Libya, which has been in force since Sunday, is a step forward. However, we have heard that the country and the people need lasting peace. The Federal Government, and the Federal Chancellor in particular, have been supporting activities to establish a lasting peace in Libya for some time. And this conference, Mr High Representative, which I understand will take place next Sunday in Berlin, is intended to make an active contribution to this. What we, as representatives of a European Parliament, must also make clear is that this is not the first time that we have debated this conflict. All states directly or indirectly involved in this conflict must ensure that this civil war can finally end and that peace can be restored in Libya. Libya should in future be a sovereign, peaceful country. Only if this is successful will we be able to talk about reconstruction in concrete terms, and then it will also be a special task for the European Union to provide support.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President I would like first of all to say to the High Representative how much I appreciate – also at this time, in this plenary – his honesty and frankness on foreign policy debates, and how seriously he takes these debates in the European Parliament. Mr High Representative, although I have prepared a speech, I commit next time to just listen to your intervention and then to come with some political remarks instead of something I prepared in advance.  Early this morning, Khalifa Haftar walked away from the negotiating table without signing the ceasefire agreement that would have formalised the fragile truce in Libya that went into effect last Sunday. This is, of course, a major blow for the suffering people of Libya, for peace, and for the stability – as you said – of the wider Sahel region. Over the past nine months, 280 civilians and 2000 fighters have died, and almost 150 000 Libyans have had to free the violence. Increasing external interference, including Turkey’s recent decision to send troops, is turning Libya into another proxy conflict right on the EU’s borders. It is of vital importance that the current informal ceasefire holds, to prevent further escalation and misery.  High Representative, I commend your indispensable efforts of the past week and call on you to continue doing everything in your power to facilitate the ceasefire’s formalisation and implementation. The UN—led Berlin conference planned for this Sunday remains critical, and together with you, we all hope that it will take place. A final remark: the Libyan people deserve a long-term perspective of peace, security and reconstruction, and that’s what we’re all fighting for.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, thank you, Mr Borrell, everything you have said, I participate in this. But what's surprising is our surprise. Because anyone who had listened to the actors on the ground, the actors on the ground, would have known that today's tragedy had been going on for nine years. We are now surprised by the attacks on Tripoli, but it was evident, because that began in the contradictions in the Sjirat Agreement, which was a Frankenstein agreement between two absolutely unethical powers. There was nothing more to listen to the parliamentarians of Tripoli, Khalifa Haftar or Fayez al-Sarraj, who represent absolutely no one. In this Parliament all we have done is listen to the legality, which in Libya is non-existent, and all we have done was listen to Fayez al-Sarraj's spokesmen, thinking they were speaking for Libya. Libya speaks for what is happening on the ground today.  I am absolutely against the war. I'm very afraid, Mr Borrell, that the news is going to go from bad to worse. And ceasefire isn't the solution either, because it's not going to happen either. There is a military imbalance on the ground, which will not stop with beautiful words. It will stop if the European Union truly acts. Because right now we're surprised by Turkey and Russia. But Turkey and Russia are, because Europe has never been. Because we have been in the metaphysical legality of Fayez al-Sarraj and we have not heard reality on the ground. We have to have true, effective and discreet actions. And if, moreover, Italy and France each act for free, what we have is our perfect irrelevance. That's the reality; the rest, beautiful compositions.

name: Mounir SATOURI
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, when it comes to contributing to peace in Libya, the European Union welcomes, thankss, regrets and consults. She talks, she talks a lot but doesn't act much. No concrete strategy, not the slightest effort of coherence of the Member States. One wonders, Mr Borrell, if you are not asked to be the guarantor of the European Union's non-existence on the international stage. Finally, not quite, because when it comes to outsourcing the management of our borders, at the cost of massive human rights violations in Libya, here we contribute blithely. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, we are all responsible for the worsening humanitarian situation in Libya. Yet, Mr Borrel, it is never too late to make Europe's values exist. Let us become indispensable on the diplomatic scene, get involved on the ground for the implementation of the ceasefire and respect for human rights, accompany migrants and refugees. There is still time to promote an alternative to detention and inhumanity.

name: Anna BONFRISCO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Borrell, as it says at the entrance to this Parliament, 51 million Europeans voted because they want to see Parliament act on our security and defence: the defence of borders, the defence of Europe, the security of European citizens. Does the European Union acknowledge that it endorsed a regime change in Libya in 2011 to reduce it, in 2020, to a failed state? Who will judge the European Union for having contributed to so much human suffering? Added to this is today's mockery, which sees our natural role played by Turkey and Russia, while in the background there are even Saudi Arabia and China. It is the sad result of seventy years of political convergence on the internal market and no convergence in foreign policy, and that is how Mediterranean security is the eternal test for us. Because Europe is the Mediterranean, or it is not Europe.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, High Representative, colleagues, again, no one in the House calls things by their real names. There is no way that the representatives in this chamber, who are interested in the topic "Libya", do not know that the shameful deal between the so-called "Libya" and the "libya" is not the same as the one in the world. Prime Minister Sajraj and Turkish President Erdogan include not only the relocation of Turkish soldiers to Libya, it involves not only the sharing of territorial waters in the Mediterranean to the detriment of Cyprus, to the detriment of the State of Israel, if you like and to the detriment of Greece.  No one is saying a simple truth, and it is that farage and Erdogan are now moving Islamists from Syria to Libya together. Islamic State fighters - those fighting a bloody civil war in Syria, those who beheaded people - are now moving to Libya. Libya under Sage and under Erdogan has become a new stronghold of Islamic State. We cannot remain silent on this subject, Commissioner, you cannot remain silent on this subject, it is your duty and you must say so.

name: Özlem DEMIREL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which There is currently a fragile ceasefire in Libya, and a serious political solution is indeed uncertain. In 2011, NATO bombed Libya and overthrew the lone ruler Gaddafi. The result: total chaos, a brutal civil war and, at its core, a proxy war ever since. This NATO war now has several actors in Libya. In addition to regional powers, almost all major powers are also involved. Everyone is concerned with oil, gas, geopolitics, spheres of influence and power. That is the bitter truth. But war means death, suffering and misery for the people on the ground. And what does the EU care about? What is Mr Borrell talking about? Mainly about refugee defense! Most EU states work together with the Sarradsch government, which, together with militias from the so-called Libyan coast guard, is keeping more and more refugees out of the European Union. This must stop! Arms exports to all parties to the conflict in Libya must now be stopped, and all foreign powers must withdraw. That would be a contribution to a sustainable peace in Libya. The people there need peace, not further escalation. With war and arms spirals, we will not achieve peace – neither in Libya nor anywhere else.

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Madam President, the European Union is not only not absent, as some say, on the contrary, together with the United States of America and NATO, they have heavy responsibilities for the imperialist intervention, the civil war in Libya, for the dismemberment of Syria. The consequences are devastating for the people, and again today European Union-US-NATO rivalries with Russia and China, involving countries such as Turkey, Egypt and others, for energy control have created an explosive situation in Libya and in the region. In this dangerous environment for the people, Turkey's bourgeoisie is seeking, and with the unacceptable Turkish-Libyan pact, to arbitrarily draw up maritime borders in the Mediterranean. The narrative of Greece's powerful allies and the complacency cultivated by the Greek government have gone bankrupt. The United States, the European Union and NATO consider Turkey a strategic partner. With this attitude they sharpen its aggression. The answer is the intensity of the coordinated popular struggle for any change of borders, against foreign bases, against imperialist associations, for the peoples to live in peace, with their own authority, with respect for sovereign rights.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are all waiting for the Berlin Summit and we hope that it will produce positive results. I'm not very optimistic. Unfortunately, Europe has been non-existent at this stage: the European Union has been non-existent, the different countries of the Union have been influenced, they have not given the necessary support to the High Representative, there has been no political initiative of any kind other than wishful hand. The results can be seen: Russia and Turkey are the guarantors of the situation, not only in Libya but throughout the Mediterranean, with ever greater risks: think of a possible offensive of terrorism, let us think about immigration, until the problem in Libya is resolved. Then there is the big energy issue. The Turkey-Libya agreement, which has cut off the rest of Europe, is not going in the right direction. There is another gas pipeline that is being created, eastmed, which should connect Israel, Cyprus, Crete, Greece and Italy, which should guarantee energy self-sufficiency. I believe that, from this point of view, Europe must also commit itself to protecting the energy self-sufficiency of all the countries of the Union.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are following developments closely, as the High Representative/Vice-President said with great honesty, hour after hour, and it is now, in the last minutes, that Haftar has decided to attend the Berlin Conference on Sunday. We follow all this with great concern and tension and sometimes feel the risk of our futility and ineffectiveness. In these cases, the only opportunity, the only possibility we have at our disposal is the resource of politics: not to give up politics, to have our objectives clear – to strengthen diplomatic, political and institutional action; to ensure the cessation of hostilities and a ceasefire; to allow, if possible, the Berlin Conference; to put in place a proposal for aid for the many Libyan citizens, especially the many Libyan citizens, especially the children involved and victims of the ongoing war; to create the political and institutional conditions for strengthening libya's unity, integrity and full sovereignty; put in place a force of deterrence. I believe that this is the appeal on which we should work: a deterrence force that helps the success of dialogue and peace, because it is not only done through diplomatic action if we do not put in place a European deterrence force and do not leave the field to other forces and other institutional and political realities. Well, I believe that this should be our task at this difficult time, knowing that we are playing a fundamental role for the future of Europe. A decisive game is being played in Libya for the very future of Europe, of the whole of Europe, and it cannot be a game played by individual states, starting with countries such as Italy or France. I believe that this is the work we should be doing and that we should encourage the High Representative/Vice-President, Mr Borrell, to carry out this function fully, because we are really playing a decisive game for the new Commission and the new Parliament throughout this parliamentary term.

name: Klemen GROŠELJ
text: – Honourable President! Libya, the poor conscience of the Member States of the European Union that have actively participated in the military intervention against the Gaddafi regime, is becoming a europe-wide headache.  Libya, which has become the centre of inhuman and dirty human trafficking linked to illegal migration through a dangerous Mediterranean route that is home to the profits of the only organised crime group and various and diverse militias, is approaching a new round of hell.  Turkey, officially still a candidate for membership of the European Union, has opted for a risky military adventure that runs counter to our strategic interests both in the Mediterranean and in Libya. With Turkish intervention and active Russian measlytic civil war, it could transcend Libya's borders and become a regional war hotspot on the EU's doorstep, given the extensive military manoeuvres of neighbouring Egypt.  Therefore, the EU must, through strong engagement, political and economic, prevent the deepening war in Libya and demand the withdrawal of all regular and irregular forces from Turkey and Russia, and force the warring parties in Libya to a real ceasefire and start a political process that will bring peace and stability to the country and the region.

name: Erik MARQUARDT
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Thank you also, Mr Borrell, for your efforts and also for your efforts to achieve peace in Libya. I believe that no one believes that it is easy to secure peace in Libya, but I believe that we can do more, even as the war rages in Libya. Since 2014, 32 638 people have drowned in the Mediterranean, and I always wonder what we would be missing if these people were still alive. I myself was on the Mediterranean for the rescue of the sea, and when you talk to the people who are being rescued there, you realise that they are simply not being treated like human beings in Libya.  Of course, it is actually completely inhumane that we, as Europe, are helping to ensure that these people, who are fleeing war at the risk of their lives, are then returned directly to this war zone. I wonder why we, as European states, have sent more patrol boats to Libyan militias than lifeboats to the Mediterranean. I think that we are making ourselves small when we have an important discussion here, but we are not doing what is obviously possible and at least saving the people who are fleeing war, torture and detention centres in Libya. I believe that we could evacuate more people, we could also ensure more sea rescue in the Mediterranean, and in fact I also believe that the European idea requires us to do just that.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: Madam President, the Western powers intervened in Libya for the greatest harm of this country, its neighbours, all of Africa and therefore of Europe. Today, slavery is a dispute with all trafficking, the tribes hitherh subjected under the yoke of Mohamed Gaddafi resume their ancestral clashes for the control of the roads coming from the Horn of Africa or the western part of the Sahelian strip. On the ground, the chaos would now boil down to the clash between Marshal Haftar and Sarraj. The latter has also toured european capitals, leading to a concurrent debate in this Parliament. Tobruk will be defended for the second time by Turkish special forces, which speaks volumes about Erdogan's interest in Libya. And we here in Europe are palatable, while President Erdogan becomes the de facto strongman of the two countries that form the migration bottleneck that controls these migrations to Europe, namely Turkey and Libya. How can we allow our naivety to spread out in broad daylight? Mr. Borrell, yes, the solution will most likely be military, but we will be absent. If we are absent in Libya, perhaps we can at least be present at European level today to help French soldiers who are the only ones in the whole Sahelian zone to fight Islamism.

name: Emmanouil FRAGKOS
text: Madam President, being here, and representing Greece, I can only resist Turkey's involvement in Libya. Do we understand where Turkey's involvement in Libya is aimed? Is there anyone in here who believes all this Erdoğan's nonsense about applying the law? If one looks only at Turkey's recent past, only crimes will be seen. Massacre of thousands of Kurds in Syria, illegal drilling in Cyprus, daily violation of Greek borders. And now he's illegally sending mercenary jihadists and weapons to Libya. Erdoğan's desire to illegally claim EEZs through Libya is clear at the expense of Greek sovereign national rights. Is the European Union aware of this? How long will the European Union financially and politically support criminal Erdoğan?

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, yesterday's meeting in Moscow with the presence of Al-Sarraj and Haftar sends us two clear messages. The first is that the EU is still not strong and united enough. Despite the whirlwind of diplomatic initiatives by the various Member States, all useful but no resolution, we have unfortunately abdicated the possibility of playing the role that Russia and Turkey have taken on – and this is the second news – have been able first to fit into the dynamics of the Libyan conflict in order to pursue their agendas and then to obtain a temporary ceasefire. The bad news today is that the truce has not been confirmed, Haftar is not signing. Everything to be redone then? Yes, but this also opens up an opportunity to be seized: if we want to prevent a new Syrian scenario on our borders, we must prepare for sunday's Berlin Summit by putting on the table a new proposal, a United Nations fact-making mission with the participation on the front line of European countries – first and first of all my own – of the neighbouring countries – i.e. the United Nations, the European countries. , for example, Tunisia and Algeria – representatives of the Arab and Islamic world and of anyone who cares about the future of the Libyan people, who most of all are suffering from this proxy war. Only in this way will we have the neutrality and the capacity to proceed with the reunification of the institutions and disarm the militias: a great mistake not to have done so before, after the unfortunate intervention of 2011. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: blue card question. I have great respect for your point of view. I have known you well over the past five years and I wanted you to tell us your opinion on the following subject, so that Mr Borrell can hear it: the regime in Tripoli, Libya, has reached an agreement with Erdoğan, on the basis of which Turkey has, as he claims, acquired EEZs in the Eastern Mediterranean, with a state so far away , which is kind of like Turkey could regulate EEZs with Costa Rica too! What would you advise Mr Borrell to do to counter Turkish aggression, given that Turkey says that in the coming weeks it will send research ships there, to the place where Greece's sovereign rights are, as it did in the Cypriot EEZ?

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: answer to a "blue card" question. Mr Mavrides, Mr Costas, as you know, I have repeatedly criticised this agreement between Turkey and Libya, which does not seem to me to be heading in the right direction at all and, above all, which also jeopardises the interests and legitimate protection of the interests of two Member States such as Greece and Cyprus, and I do not believe that this unilateral attitude is tolerable on the part of a candidate country for accession to the European Union. It seems to me that the conflict is rapidly escalating, within the Libyan theatre, towards a real clash of the regional geopolitical powers present in the theatre itself, and this absolutely must be avoided. It is precisely for this reason that it is essential for the European Union to be more present, and i therefore have confidence in the high representative's action, to ensure that concrete initiatives, such as the interposition force, are actually discussed in Berlin and that we move towards the reunification of the institutions before it is too late.

name: Vangelis MEIMARAKIS
text: Madam President, I have listened very carefully to the analysis made by Mr Borrell and I must tell you that we all understand that we are not analysts here, we are politicians. And politicians have to make decisions. We must not be spectators and monitor developments, but intervene in developments and provide solutions, because that is what citizens who are anxious and concerned about peace in the region want. From the analysis he gave us, it appeared that Russia and Turkey are the dominant forces in the region. Why is it? Because we left a void, which they came and covered. Therefore, Mr Borrell must take initiatives for peace in the region, and all of us will support these initiatives. The main problem is Turkey. It is Turkey's behaviour that creates and discredits the principles and values of the European Union. Turkey is showing us with its provocativeness that it wants to follow its own path. Does anyone today dispute that this behaviour is so provocative that it forces us and urges us to intervene in order to bring peace? We will support all initiatives that will be in this direction. Europe must show that it exists and is present in the region, for peace.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Dear Chairman, tonight we discuss a topic that has remained in the shadow of tensions in Iraq and Iran in recent days, and is of utmost importance to the European Union.  We have witnessed an agreement between Libya and Turkey, which also directly violates international laws on the sea and sovereignty of third countries, and Turkey, formally a NATO ally, is again negotiating actions with Russia in our immediate neighbourhood. In Libya, opposing sides Russia and Turkey tried to establish their positions and negotiate a ceasefire, but that attempt failed today.  At the same time, members of the European Union are still failing to find a common policy towards Libya and a coordinated response to this crisis. It should be stressed that military interventions cannot solve the chaos in Libya, but they can spread it. Our policy towards Libya cannot even be reduced to migration policy.  The European Union and the geopolitical Commission must play a more active and productive role, especially in the immediate neighbourhood. The Berlin process and cooperation with the United Nations are a path to be supported at this time.

name: Bernhard ZIMNIOK
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The deployment of the armed forces in Libya is, after the refugee deal, The next wise move by Erdogan in the blackmail game with the EU. This will further strengthen his already very strong position as europe's bouncer. And let us be realistic: at the moment it is not we who are in control of the migration crisis who decide the escape routes via the Balkan route. That is Erdogan, that is Turkey. It determines the extent of illegal mass migration. It is very easy for Erdogan to threaten the next wave of refugees, and we are already trailing. Now, however, a new dimension has been reached. Now, with Libya, Turkey wants to take control of the African country from which most illegal migrants are arriving in Europe. The consequence is that Erdogan has Europe in a stranglehold, we are even more blackmailable. We must finally use our economic and military strength. We must continue to prove ourselves to be equal opponents in this game. The EU must therefore do everything in its power to put an end to the Turkish operation in Libya, to terminate the refugee deal and finally to take over the border protection itself.

name: Carlo FIDANZA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the proxy war that is being fought in Libya once again demonstrates the European Union's inconsistency on the major scenarios of the international crisis and also the intervention – sincerely, for heaven's sake – of Vice-President Borrell this evening is nothing more than a monument to powerlessness.  This absence is also aggravated by the arrogance and mistakes of some governments, starting in the past with the French, which has played an unscrupulous game in Libya since 2011, handing us war and the migration crisis. And while Turkey is pursuing its neo-Ottoman plan, while the Gulf monarchies are regulating their accounts a stone's throw from our house, with the absence of the whole of Europe, it stands out – unfortunately as an Italian I have to say – also that of the Italian Government, which stutters relying on powerless international bodies, while large nations share out what was an area of fundamental influence for our country. So, Mr Solana, there are only a few days left to change towards and avoid a catastrophe.

name: Ioannis LAGOS
text: Madam President, I am really surprised and angry, at the same time, at what I heard a moment ago from Mr Borrell. He has officially admitted that Russia and Turkey are in charge of the region. And especially when we talk about Turkey, we are talking about a killer state, about a state that is stained with the blood of innocents, millions of innocent citizens from many countries, and we are doing at the moment that we are not seeing this thing. And we also say that the government of al-Sarraj is recognised; We know very well that Erdoğan has taken jihadist forces fighting in Syria and transferred them to Libya — so he has moved the problem even closer to Europe — he is illegally giving weapons to al-Sarraj, and we here say that we recognise him. This is unacceptable.  It is also shameful for the Greek Government to tolerate Congo and Algeria attending the conference in Berlin in a few days' time and greece being absent. But what you're doing in my country is embarrassing, too. You have no right to defend Turkey and to wrong Greece. After all, Greece is a member of the European Union. How is it possible to act continuously in favour of Turkey? Just so you know: We are not prepared to leave Greece and we are not prepared to stop the fight. We will defend our country at any price. Everything you've known so far about some people bowing their heads, forget about us.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Vice-President, it is becoming increasingly clear in the debates this afternoon and now late in the evening: we do not play a role in the trouble spots of the world, even on our doorstep. And we feel that we are tumbling back and forth between powerlessness and powerlessness, hope and appeals. I lack political unity, I lack the political project and the action. Libya is also a reflection of the state of European asylum, migration, neighbourhood, foreign and security policies, not just in the Middle East region. Russia and Turkey are entering this vacuum, as Mr Meimarakis has already said. We have only one chance that, at the summit in Berlin at the weekend, a concerted European initiative will contribute to a change in change and take the issue into its own hands. Please tell us what our ability to act in Berlin will mean.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Madam President, Mr Borrell, you have described a libyan situation that is indeed unbearable. Unbearable for the Libyan civilian population, dangerous for regional stability, in the Maghreb but also in the Sahel, as you mentioned, and finally dangerous for European security. In addition, there are massive human rights violations on Libyan territory, stranded migrants trafficked, murdered and missing activists - MP Siham Sergewa, who has now been missing for more than six months - and women who have been ill-treated by the Libyan regime. If the solution is not military, it is not authoritarian either. However, it seems that with the Turkish, Russian and Egyptian interventions, not only is the military taking over, but the model they are defending is far from being a model that defends human rights. Europe therefore once again has a role to play, an important role on the diplomatic and political stage: the Berlin conference, of course, mediation and dialogue with all the interlocutors and finally the promotion of democracy and human rights. Thank you for your action.

name: Anna-Michelle ASIMAKOPOULOU
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is imperative and also an obligation for Europe to claim a leading role in developments in Libya, because first we here in Europe will suffer the consequences. So we welcome the Berlin peace process, which Turkey torpedoes with its insistence that the invalid and unsubstantiated memorandum of cooperation between Turkey and the Tripoli government be implemented, with the result that Haftar has left the table today. The European Union has taken a clear position that Turkey's memorandum with the Tripoli government grossly violates international law and does not produce any legal effect. You must therefore, Mr Borrell, immediately demand that Erdoğan and Sarraj tear up the illegal Turkey-Tripoli Memorandum as a minimum sign of commitment to the peace and security of the Eastern Mediterranean. The unanswered Turkish challenges no longer only threaten peace but damage Europe's credibility and, ultimately, undermine its own future.

name: Susanna CECCARDI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the management of the Libyan crisis has highlighted the embarrassing inadequacy of the Italian Government on such a sensitive and strategic issue. But it all started with Gaddafi's deposition ten years ago. Ten years later, would Europe repeat that choice? The European Union has left a vacuum in which Russia and Turkey have entered, playing a leading role on the Mediterranean chessboard. Ankara is taking the keys to the southern migration corridor, with the peace of Italy, which has very important economic, energy and strategic interests in Libya. The facts are merciless: the inability of the current Italian Government in foreign policy has been certified by this affair. The truce in the Libyan crisis was not signed yesterday in Moscow; it should perhaps have signed in Rome, and that was not the case, but the whole world now expects to be signed in Berlin. If Europe fails again, this will only be yet another step backwards in an international policy that sees us as increasingly marginal.

name: Giuliano PISAPIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative/Vice-President, you rightly said that things are going from bad to worse in Libya. Today's debate also reveals a ruthless judgment, which must give us some thought: unfortunately, the Erdoğan model and the Putin model are prevailing in Libya. There are many of our responsibilities. We must overcome the unanimity of the Member States, which all too often prevent us from acting and reacting. The equidistance between al-Serraj and Haftar has not helped and does not benefit our credibility. Without the involvement of the tribes there will never be peace in Libya. I share the desire for dialogue, but unfortunately good intentions alone do not stop a war. There is an urgent need to reactivate the Sophia mission, to impose an arms embargo and to deploy a European intervention force. I remember john kennedy's words: 'We can never be afraid to negotiate but we can never negotiate out of fear'.

name: Danilo Oscar LANCINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in Libya, despite the many declarations of intent, we see that the EU has decided not to decide, successfully leaving the field open to Russia, the United States in an anti-jihad key and Turkey. The commitment to an arms embargo has long been openly circumvented by Turkey, the Emirates and Egypt. Europe's main responsibility is to have let the Tripoli government be supported in concrete terms only by Erdoğan, first with weapons, drones and military advisers and today also with regular troops and jihadist groups from Syria. A situation that today risks further increasing the destabilisation of the area, damaging the interests of companies present on the ground, especially Italian ones, and mortifying human rights. A recent Associated Press investigation into the recipients of European funds, followed by a question of mine, then revealed how UN agency officials are aware that a considerable proportion of the resources sent to stabilise the area and improve conditions in detention centres actuallyed end up with Libyan militias and criminal organisations. This scandal, combined with the constant increase in influence in the area by Russia and Turkey, certifies the failure of European policies in Libya.

name: Loucas FOURLAS
text: Madam President, Mr Borrell, the critical situation in Libya at the moment must not leave anyone indifferent. Libya is now in danger of becoming a second Syria. This is because some countries, such as Turkey, have hegemonic tendencies in the region, Mr Borrell. Turkey has set foot in Libya, and we are watching not knowing how to react, clapping. Right now, fascist Erdoğan is doing what he wants in Europe.  Do you have the impression that you will go to Berlin and make a decision that Turkey will respect? Tell me what decision or agreement Turkey respected, and I will agree with you. Our task is to monitor any developments in the refugee crisis and the possibility that Turkey will once again blackmail the European Union, in addition to refugee flows to the Greek islands and Italy. The European Union, Mr Borrell, cannot be a tail of developments.

name: Evin INCIR
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Mr Borrell, i would like to thank you for your support. A little less than 10 years ago, I remember how steps were taken towards the light in the tunnel in the Middle East and North Africa; the light that would free the region, including Libya, from dictatorship and oppression; the light that would bring peace, freedom and security.  I myself visited the MENA region several times over those years to show support for the democratic forces. I am firmly convinced that peace throughout the world requires the freedom of all peoples.  Instead, an oppressive regime was replaced by another chaotic regime in Libya, where democracy, human rights and the rule of law remain a dream. Instead, the oppression and the nightmare of fear have continued to be a reality.  The situation in Libya requires a formalised ceasefire that is respected by all parties, so that constructive discussions on a long-term political solution can take place. Here I am convinced that europe can take an even greater leadership role, a role that puts important principles at the heart of it: the democratic and human rights of the Libyan people and a system based on ... (The speaker was taken from the floor)

name: Jordan BARDELLA
text: Madam President, on all major international issues, the European Union is absent subscribers. What role did it play during the Turkish offensive in Syria? No. What role at the time of the escalation between Iran and the United States? No. And what role does it play in the crisis in Libya? Still none. It is Turkey and Russia that are the masters of the game in this region, yet so strategic for our continent. But how can we still be audible in this country, when in 2011, some did not hesitate to plunge Libya into chaos on the pretext of humanitarian reasons. The former French president, Nicolas Sarkozy and his muse, Bernard-Henri Lévy, are of course among the culprits of this disaster, as well as all those who followed them under the banner of NATO. What about Mr Barroso, then President of the European Commission, who called for Gaddafi's ouster, resulting in the destruction of the African country at the highest level of development and the opening of a massive migration corridor to Europe?. Far from being our strength, the Union, your union, often makes our weakness. A reminder is necessary: diplomacy remains above all the work of nations guided by their own history, as well as by the best interests of the people who make them up.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I agree with some of the comments you have made. Others are wishful thinking. You have to... You have to what? You have to ask Erdoğan to cancel his agreement with al—Serraj about the ... – I can ask. And what?  The problem is that we haven’t been united on Libya. Let’s tell the truth. We Europeans have had different positions with respect to Libya and now maybe we are paying the price for the fact that we haven’t been able to represent a political approach shared by all Member States. It’s true that some regret that Turkey has a role, but Turkey has a role and Russia has a role.  The latest news we have is that, after not signing the ceasefire – he is a man who refuses to sign the ceasefire because it seems that it would require them to agree with the agreement between al—Serraj, who is heading the internationally recognised government, and Turkey. But he will commit to staying in Berlin next Sunday – so the bad news is that there is no ceasefire and the good news is that it seems that, in spite of not having a ceasefire, they will be at the Berlin Conference. Maybe there we can make the first step towards a political agreement. Maybe you have been following all the statements that we have been delivering about Libya from the Foreign Affairs Council and by the High Representative himself. Let’s hope that in Berlin there is a possibility of reaching an agreement between the parts and then we will have to deal with the implementation of this agreement. This will require two things: first, to monitor the ceasefire; and, second, to control the arms embargo. I will present to the Foreign Affairs Council concrete proposals for the Europeans to be more engaged on fulfilling these two duties. Let’s see if we have enough will in order to act all together and start a new period of engagement with Libya.  That’s what I can tell you right now. Other aspects have been dealt with by many of you. I cannot answer all your questions one by one, but I think I can summarise by saying that, if there is an agreement in Berlin, subsequently there will be a ceasefire and then it will test the political will of the European Union to be more engaged on the Libyan issue. Thank you for your comments.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – The contemporary reality of Libya is a consequence of the aggression carried out by the US, the EU and NATO in 2011, aimed at geostrategic control of the region and dominance over the country's natural resources, in an unequivocal violation of international law. This aggression resulted in a civil war, with unheard of situations of suffering, violence and destruction. Far from bringing freedom, it has only created political instability, social collapse, ethnic conflict, religious intolerance and serious human rights violations. In the context of THE EU's migration policies, it has also become the centre of a network of slavery and human trafficking. The struggle for the social and political rights of the Libyan people, far from the yoke of the imperialist military presence, deserves all our solidarity. The promotion of peace, sovereignty and independence in Libya deserves our full support. These are the consequences of policies of undisguised colonial clipping! We trust that it will be the struggle of the peoples who will defeat them.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Writing. – When the EU does not care about its neighbourhood or has other priorities to satisfy, someone else will try to fill that gap. Turkey, with its neo-Ottoman expansionist movements, set itself the goal of intervening in the Eastern Mediterranean and found an ally the collapsed Tripoli regime, which cooperates with jihadist organizations such as the so-called "Muslim Brothers". It is Turkey that has maintained the war situation in Syria, resulting in the loss of thousands of lives and millions of refugees. Today we have a replay. He has been the same conqueror for 46 years in the northern occupied territory of the Republic of Cyprus in the EU. Same lies. Same crimes. The same hypocrisies and purposes. I wish the voice of the children of Kurdistan, in Afrin, Syria, and Cyprus and elsewhere could have come this far. I am sure that EU culture and principles will prevail in the end. I only regret that so many politicians submit to the small interests and sacrifice the greatest interest. The values of our culture.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – A main reason for the ongoing crisis in Libya since its inception has been the interference of foreign powers which were – still are – following hidden agendas. Among them feature Member States of the EU. The hidden agendas include access to oil supplies; strategic interests in sub-Saharan Africa; occult financial operations, past and present; immigration towards Europe; aspirations to achieve greater influence in the Mediterranean space. Foreign interference has increased in recent months. Along the years, its has exacerbated the instability already inherent in a predominant feature of Libyan society – its tribal organisation. One can see little prospects of peace in Libya unless the hidden agendas are made explicit and aligned with the interests of the Libyan people, only they – those living in the coastal cities and in the hinterland. Formal conferences that try to bring ‘all sides’ together but retain the hidden agendas are quite likely destined to eventual failure. I for one hope that this will not happen. But if it does, and the current turmoil persists, then only one solution will remain that could over the medium term make sense, again in the interests of the Libyan people – a military one that brings stability and internal security to the Libyan territory as one whole.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: in writing. – The continued deterioration of the political situation in Libya and the consequent escalation of violence are calling for greater attention from the European Union. The recent decision by turkey's national assembly to authorize military deployments to Libya further destabilises the country and exacerbates a conflict whose humanitarian situation has already reached dramatic proportions. In view of this situation, the European Union is required to play its role as a mediator in the peace process and promote dialogue as the only solution to reach a political solution. In addition, it is also necessary to evacuate and immediately close Libyan detention camps, places of ignoble torture and slavery, and that these people be guaranteed legal and safe routes out of the country. In this regard, I consider it imperative that all international partners fully respect the UN-declared arms embargo and support the efforts of the UN Special Representative and the Berlin process as the only way to a peaceful, stable and secure Libya.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Venezuela following the unlawful election of the Presidency and Presidency of the National Assembly (2020/2507(RSP)).

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, a few weeks ago this plenary discussed the Venezuelan humanitarian migration crisis that has markedly worsened over the past year, because of the political deadlock in the country. Unfortunately, we are here today to address a further deterioration of the political crisis. This is a result of the outrageous attacks against the constitutional and democratic functioning of the National Assembly, and the takeover of legislative power by an illegitimate President.  Force and violence were used against President Guaido and many lawmakers on 5 January to prevent the legitimate election of the National Assembly executive board. Impeding access to the National Assembly is not a major attack against democracy and the rule of law, it is, but it also polarises further and creates more obstacles to a peaceful solution to the crisis. The so-called election of Luis Parra is not legitimate. It did not respect the legal procedures nor the democratic constitutional principles. There was no verified Quorum, there was no voting majority and general legal provisions were not respected. Any acts or decisions taken by the assembly over which Luis Parra presides cannot be recognised by the European Union.  The EU and the International Contact Group reacted swiftly and rejected the attacks against the National Assembly, reiterating clear support for Juan Guaido as the legitimate President of the National Assembly.  Many other international actors qualified the harassment acts as inadmissible and condemned this violation and expressed support for Juan Guaido. These developments require a strong response, and further restrictive measures targeting those responsible for undermining democracy are being considered. Of course, these measures shall in no way harm the Venezuelan people that are already dramatically affected by the crisis. Targeted sanctions cannot be the only tool, we need other complementary constructive avenues that can contribute to a peaceful solution. Even though the future looks bleak, and we don’t see prospects for a short-term resolution of the political impasse, we must continue trying to create political space for negotiations. We continue to believe that a sustainable resolution of the crisis can only arise from genuine negotiation that leads to an inclusive and representative negotiated electoral path.  When we talk about restoring public institutions we mean in particular restoring the credibility of the National Electoral Council and the Supreme Court of Justice.  Without them, there can be no free and credible legislative and presidential elections and no lasting solution for Venezuela. We have said many times the EU will spare no efforts to continue helping a genuine and inclusive process towards a reinstatement of democracy and rule of law with free and fair presidential elections. Another dimension of our efforts is to craft a more consultative approach to the Venezuelan crisis by the international community. I intend to ask a special adviser Iglesias – don’t mistake which about Iglesias I’m talking about; I am talking about Enrique Iglesias – to make a tour to outreach to key international actors and assess what more can be done.  As closing remarks, I will say that we will continue to follow closely developments, in contact with other key international actors. One thing is sure, we need more concerted efforts by the whole of the international community and we need them urgently. This is what I can summarise – what they wanted to tell to you – and I’m sure that the debates will go to these conclusions which I am anticipating. We need more concerted efforts by the whole of the international community and we need them urgently. We need them urgently. The stalemate cannot last forever, and that’s what we will try to do in the following days, looking for strong support from all actors involved and asking the Contact group to continue working. The so-called Oslo process is also in a stalemate, and the suffering of the Venezuelan people and the political situation require that we push stronger in order to look for fair and free elections, as has been required for a long time without any success, but what has happened in the election of the Presidency of the National Assembly puts a marking point on the dynamics of a situation which requires from us a stronger commitment. We hope it’s going to happen in the next week.

name: Leopoldo LÓPEZ GIL
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Mr High Representative, the truth is that this debate, having heard the previous one, makes me think that we are not on the same course as we are not doing too late. Usurpador Nicolás Maduro attempted a desperate coup d'eer with military support to prevent Venezuela's only legitimate power, its National Assembly, from elected its authorities. This regime has shown its true intention, which is to prevent first and foremostic all attempts at democratic transition and to remain legally in power. This Parliament must once again confirm its support for Juan Guaidó, not only as legitimate president in the National Assembly but also as interim president in the Republic of Venezuela. More than sixty countries and institutions in the democratic world have already done so. One cannot forget the causes or causes of this Venezuelan crisis, nor this attempt to strike the National Assembly. We continue to insist before the high representative on the urgent need to establish u2012 as he himself previously suggested sanctions to those responsible for flagrant violations of the rule of law. One-person sanctions, which do not affect the general population. May they ensure that the culprits do not go unpunished before their misdeeds and that citizens, who are suffering the atrocities of the regime, receive justice. The worst sanction we can impose is the lack of action in the face of the continuation of human rights violations and letting these people, in the midst of violence, be mired in the worst of famines and have no future.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, as indicated by the high representative, Josep Borrell, today we are here to denounce what was an attempted parliamentary coup by the Government of the Maduro regime. Avoiding the proper functioning of Venezuela's democratic assembly, an attempt was made to restore legitimacy, creating parallel institutional realities, to prevent Juan Guaidó from continuing as president. In addition, a source of legitimacy for many countries of the international community, a huge majority of European countries, to place him as interim president of the country. We would like to recall that we play a constructive role from the European Union, in a sometimes very frustrating way, for a regime that finds no democratic and peaceful way out of the situation of a country, that of Venezuela, which is unbearable, with a humanitarian situation, with a humanitarian crisis, unparalleled. That is why we will continue to work in a clear place, such as Venezuela, to propose individualized sanctions and, at the same time, from a constructive point of view, also with the Contact Group, to find a democratic exit with free and fair elections in the country.

name: Jordi CAÑAS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, Commissioner Borrell, this resolution is beyond a mere parliamentary debate or one more statement in this House. This Parliament, through this resolution, condemns, recognises, challenges and speaks at a key moment in Venezuela's history. He condemns and denounces the tyrannical regime of Nicolás Maduro for attempting to orchestrate a parliamentary coup d'e rule to control the only democratic institution that demonstrates the farce of his regime. And it does so in an absolutely intolerable way from harassment and violence to democratically elected and elected parliamentarians. He recognizes and supports Juan Guaidó as legitimate interim president of the Republic of Venezuela and the National Assembly as his only chamber of democratic representation, while demanding respect for his deputies, denouncing the harassment and intolerable repression of the Maduro regime. It challenges the European Union and the High Commissioner to lead and intensify efforts to restore democracy to Venezuela by following the roadmap adopted by the National Assembly and the various initiatives with the Contact Group. It requires extending and intensifying sanctions to those responsible for human rights violations and repression. And he calls on the Member States that have not yet recognized Juan Guaidó as the legitimate president to do so. It also calls for its political representatives to be recognized as such. And finally, this Resolution speaks directly and fraternally to the Venezuelan people and tells them, with a strong and clear message, "you are not alone". This Parliament demonstrates, through a large majority of its representatives ⸻algo who say that the different can agree on the defence of democracy⸻, that it will work alongside you, alongside the Venezuelan people, relentlessly, to return democracy to Venezuela, initiating a process of political, economic and social reconstruction that allows Venezuela and Venezuelans to look back to the future with enthusiasm and hope.

name: Roman HAIDER
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The situation in Venezuela is staggering. The Austrian Ministry of Foreign Affairs, for example, characterizes the situation in this oil-rich state on earth with the following indications: unstable political situation, deaths at protest rallies, brutal robberies, widespread use of firearms, progressive economic and medical emergency. So far, so sad, so well known. But what is always very shamefully concealed is the cause of this violent chaos, and this is a brutal left-wing, socialist dictator who clings to power with all of them, literally by all means. If we do not make it with votes, we will make it with weapons – as Maduro recently summed up his motto of domination. Nevertheless, or perhaps precisely because of this, this regime has been and continues to be praised by leftists throughout Europe as a model of flagship. That is why the fight against violent left-wing extremists is particularly important, not only in Venezuela, but also in Europe, so that it does not get as far as in Venezuela.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: ECR Group. – Madam President, I am very pleased with the change in tone that I have heard here, and which has also been noted in the broad agreement, which I believe we will have, for the Resolution on Venezuela. At last there are some who have decided that we really have to exert mass pressure on the criminal regime, this regime of communists and drug dealers who have kidnapped Venezuela, and who no longer disguise anything, as they demonstrated in their assault on the National Assembly.  Much stronger sanctions, sanctions for all involved, Maduro, Godfather and so many others should not be able to dispose of a single dollar outside Venezuela. In Spain there are leaders of the regime who hold wealth. In addition, their ties to the Spanish communists, who are now in government, are alarming.  We have to end this dictatorship because it is a danger to the region, because it kills its population every day and because it also has a power of corruption that is jumping the Atlantic and that is very dangerous.

name: Manu PINEDA
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, it is curious that this Parliament is trying to support an individual who has even lost the backing of the majority of the opposition, who, not wanting to be represented by a corrupt coupist, has elected Luis Parra, another opponent, as president of the National Assembly. Guaidó knew he didn't have enough support and so, instead of walking through the door like a normal person, he decided to ride the number and jump a fence like a goat. Later, being faithful to his coup tradition, he again proclaimed himself president, this time in the writing of a newspaper. Some here must start assuming that their candidate is a fraud. Let us remember that, in addition to his obsession with proclaiming himself president of anything, he has taken the funds for humanitarian aid. And he continues to call for sanctions against his people, outside military intervention and the army's uprising. It is logical that Guaidó is supported by those who are calling for a military uprising against the Government of Spain. For example, the honourable Member who has preceded me. After all, they are heirs and nostalgics of the Spanish fascist dictatorship. What is surprising is that Members of this Parliament with proven democratic concepts share speech and position with a cancer that until recently seemed removed from Europe.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: – Señora presidenta, saludamos ante todo a los diputados venezolanos que están aquí, son defensores de la democracia en su país, seguidores del presidente Guaidó, presidente interino de Venezuela y presidente de la Asamblea Nacional, elegido democrátically, en contra de las fuerzas del señor Maduro, el dictador, de colectivos militares que intentaron matar otra vez la democracia en este país de Latinoamérica.   That is why I believe that Europe must have the strength to react and not worry, as has often been the case, that everything is resolved by humanitarian aid. We need more strength, we need more courage from the whole of the European Union. This Parliament was determined to recognize Guaidó first as interim President of the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela; It will do so again by voting for a very important document, which reaffirms illegality and reiterates everything negative that Mr Maduro is doing against his people, destroying democracy and stifling freedom. That is why I believe that it is right to impose sanctions on all those responsible for the regime, and these sanctions must apply to all those who have violated human rights. From an economic point of view, too, the families that have benefited, the families of Maduro's accomplices, must be affected. I believe that it is important that the European Commission, the High Representative and all of us finally have the courage to take a tough, decisive and definitive stand against Mr Maduro and the Venezuelan dictatorship. We cannot give up courage!

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: – Madam President, the events of the past day 5 in Venezuela, preventing democratically elected representatives of the people from accessing the premises of the National Assembly and freely carrying out their functions, represent the overtaking of a red line that can never be tolerated. Events such as these only serve to exacerbate the polarization of Venezuelan society and hinder efforts to promote a political solution, and thereby prolong the crisis and suffering of the Venezuelan people, in the face of the severe effects of a humanitarian crisis that has put 90% of its population to live below poverty levels. Only since the beginning of this mandate have three debates on Venezuela taken place in this Parliament. In the last two years the situation in this country has been discussed in plenary eight times and this will be the seventh resolution on Venezuela to be voted on in this period. We have to move from words to deeds! The Venezuelan people are tired and can't take it anymore. Therefore, Commissioner, I support your determination to apply sanctions directly linked to those who promote the violation of democratic rules and the violation of human rights in Venezuela, and at the same time concertation within the Dialogue Group to promote democratic, free and fair elections, supervised internationally, to return the floor to the people... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker)

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Madam President, Mr High Representative, we ended 2019 with a debate on Venezuela and started 2020 with another debate on another crisis. Imagine seeing our President of the European Parliament being blocked by police outside this building, watching him try to climb a fence to enter this room. It sounds absurd, but that's what happened in Venezuela last week with Assembly President Juan Guaidó. Unfortunately, facts like these no longer surprise in Venezuela. It is becoming increasingly clear that Maduro has no intention of leaving power or negotiating a true democratic transition. Democracy will only come when pressure forces the regime to negotiate the terms of its exit. I will therefore not tire of insisting that the European Union must continue to put pressure on the regime with selective sanctions and extend these to the relatives of those sanctioned, while supporting peaceful dialogue.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, we have already lost count of the debates on Venezuela in this Parliament. With each new debate the creative delirium increases and the lie grows in tone. While feeding the fantochada they sponsored and the failed coup attempt that they have been trying to legitimize for a year, they omit the escalation of sanctions – already existing in the United States, but also of the European Union against the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela – that stifle their economy, with the terrible consequences for the Venezuelan people that result, but also for the foreign communities residing there , such as the expressive Portuguese community. But they seek above all to hide, without success, the answer they did not expect from a people that is not sold, the firm resistance of a people that continues to assert its sovereignty, to reject the maneuvers of external interference, but above all to unequivocally defend the right to freely build the future of a country that will no longer be colonized. And it is to these people of Venezuela who resist that we express our solidarity.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: – Madam President, the regime of Nicolás Maduro has consistently violated the Venezuelan Constitution repeatedly. The most recent episode, perpetrated by a lightning operation and, as it was said here, without a quorum, attributed the presidency of the National Assembly, legitimately occupied by Juan Guaidó, to the Chavista deputy Luis Parra, a supporter of maduro's dictatorship. The disrespect for the basic principles of democracy, without shame and in the sight of all, is responsible for the suffering of many Venezuelans. This Parliament has already said this clearly, through several resolutions, several debates, in which it expresses its support for Juan Guaidó and the legitimate and democratically elected National Assembly, and repudiates this form of usurpation of power. We also strongly condemn the serious violations that have been going on for too long, for too long, by Maduro, his regime and his allies. It is deplorable to see continued threats, torture, arbitrary decisions against members of the National Assembly. Allow me, Madam President, to regret only the speech of Mrs Pereira, who has just mentioned – I have even pointed out – which is a delusion, a fanofchada and an external interference. Say this to the suffering Venezuelan people, and to these left-wing parties that support the governing solution in Portugal that stop systematically closing their eyes.
