It is a situation that is a regrettable reality. My solidarity, our solidarity at this moment with the entire Venezuelan people.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, only a few days ago we witnessed yet another act of violence and overpowering by Maduro, who, under his regime, condemned a people living in one of the richest places on earth to starvation, exodus and death from trivial diseases. I want to give four numbers. The first is that 4.5 million Venezuelan refugees have already left the country; 11 are the kilograms of average weight that venezuelans lost in 2017; 85 is the percentage of medicines that are impossible or difficult to find according to the World Health Organisation; 95 is the percentage of GDP contraction since 2013 according to the International Monetary Fund. Mr Solana, the European Union, which cares about democracy, freedom and the lives of Venezuelans, must, through its diplomacy and through the sanctions that you have announced, force the Maduro regime to surrender and support the process towards new democratic elections. This is a strong signal, which must be sent not only to the Venezuelan regime but also to its global supporters, first and for all Russia.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, high representative, the mature regime's crude and violent attempt to take control of the Venezuelan National Assembly deserves our most resounding condemnation. His Government is responsible for the deepest humanitarian and cohabitation crisis that recalls the country's history. But overcoming it requires maintaining support for the president in charge, Juan Guaidó, recognizing his representatives abroad, supporting a survey commission that values the situation on the ground, and continuing to support the efforts of the Foreign Action Service and the Contact Group to find a peaceful and democratic way out with free elections, without excluding personalized sanctions for venezuelan authorities involved in violations of fundamental rights.  Maduro must leave power, because real Venezuela abandoned him years ago. He enjoys an opulence and living conditions that isolate him from the poverty and suffering suffered by the citizens who suffer from his dictatorship.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, most of the comments from the many Members were responding to our a priori approach. How can we interpret them – so many different things, events, that have been widely broadcast all over the world? For me it’s clear; for our delegation in Venezuela it’s clear. We cannot consider the election of the board according to the rules, and we have to continue accepting the fact that Juan Guaidó is the President of the National Assembly of Venezuela. This is not going to solve the problem, but at least it is a coherent position from our part. I take note that there is strong division in this Parliament about what’s happening in Venezuela, but we have to stick to the facts, and the facts for me are clear: Juan Guaidó is still, for us, President of the National Assembly and as a consequence remains the President in charge for calling for elections in Venezuela. We will continue to work on that, Madam President. Thank you for your contributions to the debate.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: Six motions for resolutions have been sent to me in accordance with Article 132(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday 16 January 2020. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: in writing. – The global community, bar a few rogue outliers, has rightly condemned the outrageous abuse of power in Venezuela and human rights abuses that are being perpetuated on its people. Since Maduro came to power in 2013 there has been an increase in human rights abuses and a shrinking of civil and political spheres. He has stifled dissent, targeted the opposition and presided over the collage of the local economy. Insanity is doing the same thing over and over again, and expecting a different result. Repeatedly, socialist dictators come to power promising the sun, the moon and the stars, and we get the same result: collapse of economies and abuse of human rights. The proven oil reserves in Venezuela are recognised as the largest in the world, totalling 300 billion barrels. The United Nations Human Rights Office has denounced ‘widespread and systematic use of excessive force’ against demonstrators, saying security forces and pro-government groups were responsible for the deaths of at least 73 protesters. The EU must send a strong and clear message that it supports democracy and the rule of law and opposes dictators.
